text: Seafood jambalaya without rice, presentation was better then the food.a bit pricy for what you get. Still good, but nothing special.fries were excelent. great outdoor seating for people watching and relaxing. Great Nola bear selection!

Amazingly delicious! is my first comment. Must try it!  This is our first ever visit to Pittsburgh and my wife and I enjoy new foods. We ate lunch today in Market Square and the waitress recommended a neighboring restaurant called Nola's for dinner. She explained they have a jazz band and the food is good. We walked over after lunch to make a reservation. The earliest was fir 9:15 because "it's Saturday night" the friendly host said. When we arrived the band was playing easy jazz music and laughter filled the restaurant. We were seated immediately and likewise greeter by Greg our waiter. He sports a great handlebar mustache.

We looked over the menu and decided to choose the frog legs appetizer. We never had them before - another first. They were quickly served in a mushroom in lemon and bacon sauce that was so succulent we immediately decided we would try other items on the menu we've never had.

We then tried the fried alligator also off the appetizer menu. Again it arrived shortly thereafter. Amazingly savory spicy flavors with the alligator.

We the had the oyster stew. Again a deliciously savory taste to the stew.

Continuing on with the theme for the night we had the wood roasted quail. Another first. It's served on a bed of rice pilaf and cranberry Pinot noir with fresh asparagus.

This was and evening if firsts and we truly enjoyed topping our visit to Pittsburgh. My wife and I have been married for over 31 years and she has always enjoyed great food. Nola's was an experience which quickly and easily jumps to the top of our list of favorite places to eat.

Great food, great service in a great environment accompanied the great companionship with my wife.

Me and my date stopped in last night and loved this place! The bartender was very professional and extremely friendly, he knew the menu and the drinks very well. The atmosphere and music was great. We had the BBQ shrimp, it was fabulous! I would definitely go back!
Read some of the reviews and just had to go it was worth the walk great food and drinks.... :)

We got lucky and were able to walk in and get a table- no reservations.  Having been to New Orleans, we were excited to get Gator as an appetizer.  It was every bit as good as what we got down south.  
Our food was delicious, and my husband discovered that he likes fava beans.  
The service was great as well. 
We will eat here again.

I love NOLA! From the drinks to the food to the ambiance. I went on August 17th and had a very enjoyable experience. Out waitress was very helpful and knowledge about the drinks they had including the different beers (I love trying new and different beers so this was very nice to have someone who knows). 
My friends ordered the oysters and the crab special. While they seemed like small plates for the price, they appeared as if they were well enjoyed. We were given one of the pizzas courtesy of the chef and I must say that it was one of the best crusts I have had since moving to Pittsburgh. I would order the crawfish and andouille sausage any time. 
For dinner, everyone at the table got the Steak et Frites. AMAZING! You can tell alot of care went into the food as the fries are well seasoned, the salad is perfectly dressed and the steak was tender and delicious. 
The crowd tended to be older but it was still a very nice atmosphere and I had a great experience.

Visited Nola for the first time in awhile and so glad I did!  We stopped by this afternoon between lunch and dinner. A great time to go because it wasn't too busy and we actually found parking in Market Square.  
We were promptly greeted by a personable hostess and seated quickly.  Our meal started with two appetizers, Fried Green Tomatoes and Potato Chip Crusted Catfish.  Both, so good! I am a true fan of southern food so I was quite happy to find fried green tomatoes - and done well! 
I selected the soup and sandwich duo which I felt was reasonably priced at $12.  I received a full cup of french onion soup, a turkey Cuban sandwich and french fries. Everything tasted great.  The soup broth was very flavorful and I liked the twist on the Cuban sandwich with the smoked turkey.  The fries were also tasty with a nice mix of seasoning on them.  
I wish we had saved room for dessert because everything sounded so delicious.  I think next time we'll just go for coffee and dessert to truly enjoy the experience. 
What impressed me most with our experience was the service.  Very quickly on we were told our waitress had a large table in another section but the service didn't suffer at all.  Everyone from the hostess, bartender, another waiter, even the Manager, stopped by to help our dinner service go seamlessly.  Our waitress was also just so sweet and really personable.  She was very informed as to the menu and also offered suggestions for coming back during Happy Hour.
NOLA has great ambiance too. I enjoyed the decor and music, everyone we encountered was very pleasant. Overall just a great experience!

The service was amazing, the food was the best, and the mixed drinks were so yummy!   I have tried this place for the first time yesterday and plan on making it a regular of mine.  The waiter was so very nice and very helpful on what to choose based on our taste buds.  He knew alot about how the food was made and the history of the resturaunt.  I cant wait to go again and would really reccomend everyone try it.....you 2 will become a reguar!

Authentic New Orleans fare in the heart of downtown Pittsburgh. Informative server who was helpful with his thoughts on the menu, all choices were wonderful. The Jazz band was a wonderful backdrop to the evening.

My alligator bites were more like alligator crumbs. I had rice and beans which were serve lukewarm. My granddaughters fried green tomatoes tasted watery and were not crisp. A very diappointing experience. Would not go again or recommend it to anyone.

I had high hopes for NOLA.

My boyfriend's family lives in New Orleans, and we visit yearly.  When I first walked into NOLA, my first impression was that this is kind of like the Disney World version of New Orleans.  It is over the top, cliche, and kinda cheesy.  That's fine, I can deal with that.  Cheesy can be fun, and the music was great.  I tried to keep a positive attitude.

I ordered a Sazerac, a classic New Orleans cocktail, and it was served warm.  It was also very heavy on the absinthe rinse.  Friends have told me they've had great Sazeracs at NOLA, so I'm hoping this was a fluke.

Next, I tried the alligator appetizer.  It was pretty tasty, but the presentation was not great.  The tiny nuggets of fried alligator were dwarfed by the huge rectangular plate they were served on.  It just seemed like an interesting choice. The red beans and rice dish was pretty awesome, but it wasn't as good as those I've had on the Gulf Coast.  They weren't as thick and creamy, and they were lacking in spice (a bottle of hot sauce fixed that).  Overall, NOLA did not do justice to the awesomeness that is New Orleans cuisine.  

I love New Orleans, and I want to love NOLA.  I'll definitely give it a second try.

Some perks:  live music, $5 valet parking after 5 (for all of Market Square), good service, fun ambiance

So glad I didn't spend $27 on shrimp and grits. Funny exchange on that. When I mentioned the high price, it was explained as being a function of the grits from NC. Yeah- me too, from NC and grits are poor people food!  The shrimp and sausage should be the money in the dish. So, I went salad and flatbread. Got out more cheaply but this place confirms my Market Square theory: you eat there to sit there -in the square- and not to actually eat a high quality meal.

New Orleans atmosphere with food to match considering it is so far removed from the real deal. BBQ shrimp, shrimp and grits, and gumbo were excellent. Red beans not cooked down enough in the red beans and rice dish.

Scotch and wine choices adequate. I will plan to return when my travels take me back to Pittsburgh.

It's not Cajun food - what we had....oysters (how do you mess those up?), gator nuggets or whatever they call it, and the étouffée was awful. Awful. Étouffée was not even close. Better experience could be had at south hills village (local mall). Desert was decent......which is why it gets one star vs zero. Waitress was nice but literally could not open a bottle of wine. Pittsburgh deserves better - heck mall food courts throughout North America deserve better.  To say this place sucks is an insult to the word "suck". Go if you want to lie to yourself or if your  best dining experience includes a free cookie

Went there on Wednesday after work for dinner and must say it was delicious.  We split the alligator, he had the gumbo (extra spicy), and I had the leak/brie pasta.

The alligator was disappointing not because of the tastes, it was extremely delicious.  It tasted like a mix of chicken and calamari with a spicy seasoning.  Heavily breaded and heavily spices.  The sauce that came with it tasted almost like the onion petal sauce from the Outback.   However it was so small and it came on a long plate.  There were 12 small pieces of it.  There was more sauce than alligator and it was $13!  Never again.  

His gumbo wasn't particularly spicy and it had too much tomato sauce but it was close to New Orlans.  Can't complain too much considering how far away we are.  My pasta was extra saucy and small.  The dish it came on was huge too.  Why the excessive presentation?

Biggest complaints?  No po'boys, no ghost peppers, and no jazz through the speakers!  Plus the decor looked as if they were getting ready for Mardi Gras.  Nice artwork though and the waiter was a sweetheart (thanks Miles!).  He was attentive and polite.  

All in all I probably will not go back for dinner.  Granted we tipped Miles well the cost was just excessive for how little we got.  Will try again for lunch one day.
What an incredible  jambalaya! Best I've ever had. Service was good  atmosphere comfortable, and priced right. The entire menu was terrific.

What an amazing New Orleans experience! The decor was phenomenal and the live band set it off! The Nola truly captures the Bourbon Street ambiance! Our waitress Cassandra was phenomenal in her menu expertise. Our party included a small child and our waitress was very accommodating to her needs putting a rush on her food and bringing her crackers while we waited. The Drink menu has a great selection of craft beers and speciality drink. The menu is traditional New Orleans  . I highly recommend the frog leg appetizer it was exquisite. I have ate them from many establishments and these were by far the best! I truly enjoyed my experience and felt like I was in the French Quarters!
I eat there over a year ago and it was very disappointing and since have had 2 friends eat there and felt the same. I guess my evening was not a fluke.
Really enjoyable experience on market square.  Loved the live music and atmosphere. For the food we got po boys and pizza.  All excellent. Will be back for sure !

On a Thursday evening, without a reservation we tried to get a table here.  The hostess was very welcoming so we waited and scored an awesome table outdoors!!!  We enjoyed the glorious evening - the music was at a conversational level.  The server (and I'm mortified I didn't catch her name but she is expecting) was warm and engaging.  She had us trying alligator (+++) and was spot on with her individual recommendations to us.

The food was really good but I couldn't give this place 5 stars because of the 2 bartenders..
Especially the blonde girl bartender..terrible attitude , rude and slow
I ordered a Stella draft which tasted flat and water down..when I told her the beer was no good she took it to the manager who took a sip and they both looked at me like I was crazy..never came back n apologized just asked what other beer I would like..every time I finished a beer they would take the bottle n not ask if I would like another one or I would have to wave my hand to get another beer because they all stood at the end of the bar talking instead of taking care of the 3 ppl sitting at the bar..shout out to the chef and the server who brought my meal to me at the bar they both did a great job

This was my first time here. I had tried a few times for lunch but never was able to get a table. 

A client took us here for dinner. We sat in the back room and it was empty. We had the entire back room to ourselves. I did like being so close to the kitchen. 

We started with the fried alligator. It was good and would have again. 

I had the jambalaya. It came out steaming hot that I could barely eat it. It had a nice variety of seafood in it. It had two large scallops, a few grilled shrimp, a few pieces of chicken and a good red sauce that had a little heat. 

I nearly finished the entire plate. 

Nice to try a new place and really liked the new place. 

Service was fast and friendly with some southern charm.
Good quality food, not necessarily authentic New Orleans food, but very tasty. Slow service. Nice ambience. Very clean. Would go back!

I love creole, I know creole, I cook creole myself.

So I was beyond excited to try this place, and thrilled to see this style of cooking introduced to Pittsburgh. 

It didn't stand up to my standards, I guess if you don't know creole food it can pass for a poor imitation.

It simply lacked heart, which for me, is everything with this style of cuisine.

I found the atmosphere tacky and cliche.

Our server was well-trained, but again lacked heart and personality.

An overall corporate feel, when to do a true cajun/creole menu you need soul.

Before I dive into the negatives, let me say that the entire staff was friendly and accommodating. I had absolutely no qualms about the service. 

This used to be one of my favorite lunch/dinner spots for memorable and delicious cuisine. However; ever since the menu/head chef was changed, the menu appears to have nose dived. The frog leg appetizer portion has been cut in half and covered in an unnecessary sauce. The soup cups were so shallow, I only got a thimble's worth of broth. Lastly, my pulled pork sandwich was 60% un-chewable fat. I had noticed that the appetizers were lacking during a recent happy hour, and I had written it off as a one-time fluke. Sadly, it appears that the menu quality as a whole is not what it used to be. Can't say I'll be going back.

Wow does this place have awful service. Waitress only came over to take orders and give us food, never to check up on us. We were sitting right next to the kitchen and could see all the employees standing around not doing anything. It took them 30 minutes to make a side salad! Even if food is made to order, it shouldn't take an hour to make a waffle. No apologies for the wait either. Also, when the waitress brought the food, she unceremoniously dumped it on the table without a word. No drink refills either as she seemed to be hiding from us in the bar area. Food was ok, but pricey and a bit heavy on the salt. Would not return.

I love Southern food, especially from New Orleans so of course we had to give this place a shot.  Definitely a great place for appetizers and lunch, but I think we should of ordered different items for dinner, wasn't pleased but definitely l wasn't displeased.   For what we paid I think we should of gotten more, but to each their own.   I suggest avoiding this place if you see a large group present too.  Overall though we were happy and probably will try it again, but for lunch only.  The service was definitely great here though,  the employees definitely had their knowledge on the food they offer.

Finally got to try out NOLA a few weeks back with a group of friends. I made a reservation in advance however we still waited 30 minutes to be seated.  If we had been seated quicker I would give NOLA  5 stars.

We started with the alligator. Very good and something new for all of us.  I got the Nola Salad and it was delicious. My friend got the Scallops Mac Daddy and really enjoyed it. Another got the blackened red fish and said it was great.  Our waitress was extremely friendly. 

We were seated towards the back and could see the kitchen which was neat as well. Overall a good atmosphere. The place was packed and everyone appeared to be having a good time.

8 of my coworkers and I came to this swanky bar while training in Pittsburgh for the week. We had explored a lot of the city at this point, and had enjoyed several great restaurants and bars. Nola took the cake. 

The place was beautiful. Different. Alive and cozy at the same time. 

Everyone's food was delicious. 

The cocktail list was to die for! I had the New Orleans Milk Punch, which I still talk about, and one of the hot drinks a bartender had recommended. I forget the name, but I believe it had: Brandy, Grand Marnier, Cacao, Cinnamon, and Butter?! It was fantastic.

The servers and bartenders were wonderful and kind. 

And the manager was dressed to the nines when he came by our table to check on us and thank us for coming in. 

We return to Pittsburgh the first week of December. I will definitely be visiting again.

I've been here multiple times now for lunch during the week and it is completely hit or miss.  I've gotten food lunch that I just love and crave and then the next time I come it's terrible. 

My "new" biggest beef with this place is that on one visit the server helped himself by upping my tip.  I pay with a credit card and I always tip 20%, I round up for good service and may round down for poor service but never less than 15%.   I had gotten the lunch combo which is around $12, so with tax and tip the total was $16.  My credit card statement showed over $22.   I brought it in the next time I went to eat there to discuss with the manager and he didn't apologize at all and said he couldn't refund me the difference but today's meal would be free.  Which was a little bit more than what I was owed.  The fact that he never said that he was sorry it happened just really irked me. 

The fact that the food quality is so inconsistent and that someone on the wait staff stole from me means I will never go back.

Def not authentic New Orleans style food. We had their Bloody Mary, which tasted like Tabasco sauce. Their gumbo and shrimp and grits tasted like someone from up north make the recipe. Upset as we were looking forward to having authentic Cajun food. We will not return back.

I really enjoyed this place.  We were seated quickly, and the service was awesome.  They have a fine wine list, and will let you sample different wines so you can choose one you like.  Their usual jazz band was playing as well, and while it did make the atmosphere a bit more noisy, the music was very good.  The food was pretty good-- I had the fish special and my companion and I shared the fried alligator appetizer (which I recommend).  I also recommend the St. Charles cocktail (which is basically a dressed-up gin and tonic).  All in all, very pleasant.  Will definitely be back.

What a great experience at Nola on the Square!  Our server, Kathryn, was impeccable!  Her suggestions for food wand wine were spot on especially since she carefully listened to our food preferences...my wife being more of a fine french foodie and I a spicy buff.  

The crawfish & sherry soup was tasty, more of a bisque with chunks of crawfish.  I had the fried gator tail.  Panko breaded chunks of tail with a beautiful creamy, but spicy sauce - the meat was fresh and sweet.  

For our entrees we had the Scallops Mac Daddy - Beautifully prepared and the scallops were huge and perfectly done. I had the wood roasted quail. Two complete quail that were again perfectly done although my wife thought just a  tad over salted.

My first visit to NOLA was mediocre, my second visit, during lunch, was unexpectedly pleasant. My review here covers my second experience.

All 3 people in my party had the half sandwich/half salad/voodoo fries combination or a variation thereof.

Veggie lovers take note: The salad with watermelon and arugula was delicious! I really liked my smoked turkey Cuban (a little heavy on the meat), and the voodoo fries are good. My companions would recommend NOLA's jambalaya as well.

For $12 each, our meals were good and the price point is VERY competitive among the other restaurants serving the downtown lunch crowd. I will be back!

So, just......not great. At all. Was our second try with this place. We ordered apps for the table, didn't get plates to eat them on. Waited a full five minutes for the server to come after a food runner delivered apps, he never showed. Had to get up and go looking for him so we could have some plates.  Server took our silverware after we finished the appetizers, didn't give us new. Had to take them from a neighboring table because he went MIA again. The menu is heavily overpriced, the food is nice but definitely not worth the prices. Disappointing in that regard.  This place could be really fun and cool, it's trying so hard to be upscale and it's just so not. It's a Cajun/creole place, to me them atmosphere should be all about that. Fun, good zydeco music.....something?? Service was poor at best. We won't be back, too many great places downtown to eat that get it. We wanted to like it!

Wow. Just wow. After reading other reviews I was hesitant. The service was razor sharp, no empty glasses, no plates laying around, nobody waiting for more liquor. 

I ordered the fried alligator appetizer , gumbo soup and jumbalia for dinner. If you haven't tried alligator, do yourself a favor and do. Great dish with smoky thousand island dressing sauce. 

The gumbo soup was spicy and hearty. I'm going to look into making my own for cold winter nights after this experience.

The scallops and shrimp in the jumbalia were very well cooked, it as well was served (physically) HOT and spicy, it was everything I could ask for. When I asked for the hottest hot sauce they had, it was delivered. Not just Franks Red Hot like I'm normally served. It was a unique brand of fire death. Perfect.

Overpriced yeah. But I left with a new taste for cajun cooking. I did not want to rate this establishment 5 stars, but I had too.
Good shrimp and grits, po boys, and gumbo. A few unique twists on classic drinks, decent beer selection, and great service.

being from both new orleans and cajun country, i go into restaurants outside of louisiana who offer louisiana food with very low expectations.  that being said, my rating for nola is a combination of the atmosphere, service, food and especially abita on tap (which i totally appreciate).  

i had the red beans and rice which wasn't bad - it needed more flavor and heat but is made correctly with the bean paste.  i also had the abita battered shrimp which comes with a pepper sauce - not bad but it's better for the heat to be part of the batter rather than the cooked shrimp sprinkled with chili powder.  also, the cole slaw was not good.  finally, we had the griddle grits which was ok.  the flavor was strange at first but it grows on you.  the presentation of all the food was nice, but $11 for a few shrimp and $17 for grits is overpriced.

the service was attentive and good.  the kind of music played was spot on.  finally, one recommendation would be to put hot sauce on the tables, which is standard in louisiana and needed for what was served.

I love NOLA! I have food allergies. They were super nice and accommodating with that. I brought friends back and then returned again.. so 3-4 times I've left Nola feeling happy and excited to go back.

I tried this for lunch, the atmosphere is pretty good with inside seating and outside on the square. The service was fine and the lunch combo was a good amount of food for the money. I ordered the gumbo and roast beef poboy which also came with fries. I found both the gumbo and sandwich were way too salty, to the point where I didn't finish either and had a salt aftertaste all afternoon. The fries were probably the best part. 

I may try NOLA again, but would try something else from the menu. Unfortunately these two New Orleans staples did not deliver.

I love NOLA. If it were less expensive I would eat here all the time. Alas, it is on Market Square so the menu prices are high. I've eaten dinner here twice and also came once for brunch. The first time I was here was for a pre-theater dinner. We were seated in the dining room next to the windows into the kitchen so I could watch all the food being prepared. I've read reviews claiming that the jambalaya must be pre-made and frozen. It isn't. I watched a chef make it to order and put it in the brick oven. The second time we were seated in the dining area in the front room near the bar, and the third time I ate at the bar. Thus far I've had grit cakes, shrimp and grits, fried green tomatoes, seafood soup, and beignets. As far as I can tell this is the only place in Pittsburgh that serves beignets. They aren't quite as good as the ones in New Orleans, but they are a pretty good approximation. The food is well prepared and (as the server told us on my first trip there) adapted spice-wise to Pittsburgh, meaning that the Cajun/Creole flavors have been toned down a bit. They will give you hot sauce upon request to spice the food up. As far as drinks go, they have a pretty nice wine list. I had a couple of cocktails when I was there for brunch and I wasn't blown away by them. They seemed a little weak. Also, the service here is hit or miss. They sometimes seem a little disorganized in terms of who is handling which tables. I can live with that though since the food is so good and the atmosphere at the bar is so much fun.

We stopped in for lunch on a Friday afternoon. Ordered a Shrimp Po'Boy with Cajun fries and Jumbalaya -- both were very good and flavorful. Portions were perfect sizes for lunch, we didn't feel overly full afterwards. The waitress was nice and attentive and even had a suggestion of dipping my fries in the hot sauce as an alternative to ketchup. I would most likely go back again if I had a craving for some NOLA food!

Its nice to see a Louisiana style place open in Pittsburgn and the location is great.. However, after just being to New Orleans and coming here I can say its not really comparable to a nice restaurant down there. Food is pretty overpriced and just doesn't taste quite right. Service was pretty good, and its a big restaurant with free valet parking. Its decorated tastefully too.

The servers are really nice. I came during happy hour and ordered the red beans and rice ($1) and the Catfish Fingers ($3)

1st- the beans had the right flavor (being from New Orleans I grew up on this dish) but the beans were not cooked all the way. I do feel sorry for my intestines when they have to break them down. They were way harder than canned beans, and need 30more mins in the pot

The fish was pleasing, I love the presentation of both dishes. I would love to give this more than 2 stars but I know that they should do way better. I'm no chief but I know good cooked food when I taste it. 

I did let the server know about the bean and she was very understanding. Feedback is always the key!

We've dined here a few times now. I've only been disappointed once as they ran out of oysters. I'm looking forward to lunch as they have a few New Orleans classics which are not on the dinner menu (that is a mistake in my opinion).
We ate there on a Tuesday night,  and received excellent service.  I had the steak and salad.  The steak was very good for the price.  ($25) overall nice dinning ambiance.

I'm from the Gulf Coast and grew up a stones throw from New Orleans. My step-dad is no-shit Cajun. So, I have high standards. 

Went for Sunday brunch. This is the run down:
+ Breakfast grits: ok but I would've liked to have tried them as described on the menu. They were out of peaches. 
- Gumbo: too mild for authentic gumbo. 
+ Fried Green Tomatoes: really good, but I would've opted for remoulade instead of ranch. 
+ Bloody Mary bar: nice touch but it would've been nice to have toothpicks for the olives and pickles and such. 
- Strawberry Shortcake Waffles: good but too spongy. 
+ Beignets and coffee: the beignets were really good but a little small. I'm used to Cafe du Monde where the beignets are pretty big. But these stood up in taste. The coffee was a little weak. 
- Chicory coffee: iced chicory coffee? Wtf? In my humble opinion, chicory coffee should never be iced. 

Other than that, the service was a little slow but things were good. I'll have to come back and try them for lunch or dinner and see how they really stack up.

Wow great choice on a very warm Friday night , got a table outside on market square and enjoyed the surroundings ,I ordered the seafood Mac Daddy .it was over the top ,the lobster and shrimp were done to perfection ,I highly recommend ,so give em a try .
Never had a bad meal here! Fried gator app is amazing! Had several entrees- scallops Mac daddy, seafood jambalaya, and catfish all where great!

Food was fantastic, staff was friendly and courteous and overall just a great place. Never been here before but glad we took the chance - will definitely be back again! 

We recommend the shrimp po' boy, voodoo fries, and red beans and rice. All were seasoned and cooked to perfection - best food I've had in Pittsburgh so far! Dessert, anyone? The bourbon ball is absolutely amazing - not too sweet and not too much - perfect way to end the meal! Thank you for everything!!!

I wish I would have found this place sooner. It was a welcome surprise to find. Being a Louisiana native now living in Pittsburgh, you rarely find any cajun food anywhere and if you do, it's not what it should be. 

Everything I had was delicious, the chef was more than helpful with preparing an item I had requested and then just went ahead with making the entire meal an amazingly delicious experience that reminded me of home. 

The bartender did make the oddest version of a Hurricane I had ever had. I don't think that particular person knew what they were doing, but my review is for the food, not the bar. 

My only other complaint, would be that the waitress didn't seem to know much about the food. She served my husband and I a tasting of etouffee, but never brought the rice to go with it and had not come back to check on us so we just had a few bites of it by itself. It was good, just not served properly. Being in the service industry myself, it really makes me a lil picky about how I get treated when I dine out, and I was turned off that a place this unique to this area, where especially most people here don't know this type of food, should have servers who know what they are serving.
A little taste of Creole! Enjoyed the oyster poboy although it was a bit expensive- $15! Fries with Cajun seasoning were fantastic!

Loved it. Fantastic food, service, cocktails &  music! We were seated earlier than our reservation. I think our servers name was Al. He was out of this world. We had: fried green tomatoes, alligator, shrimp & grits and jumbalaya. Then beignet and creme brulè fantastic!! .

I enjoy the city of Pittsburgh. And I enjoy trying new things. 

So suffice it to say, I was happy to combine those two things this when my wife and I and two friends were hanging out in Market Square and PPG Place the Saturday of Light-Up Weekend. One of them suggested Nola, as she had eaten there once before. Since we hadn't, we went along. 

I've been to New Orleans, and the first thing I noticed walking in: the place smelled a lot like that city. That was a good thing. Also a good thing: our timing. We were told that normally on a Saturday night, there would be a lengthy wait for a table, but since we had beaten the dinner rush, we only waited about ten minutes. 

Once we were seated, a lovely lady named Mariah was our server. She was very knowledgeable about the menu and even when she wasn't sure about what that day's specials were, she let us know that she'd get us that information: which she did - and I was glad, as I wound up ordering the fried chicken, which was different from any I had ever had before and very good. It had a sweetness to it and a bit of a kick - much like the aioli that came with crispy fried alligator, which, along with the frog legs we ordered and the fried green tomatoes made for great appetizers (and I don't even like tomatoes). 

I didn't try the flatbread, but it got rave reviews from my friends and my wife, who did. At the end of the evening, a manager came up and asked us how we liked the fried chicken, as they were experimenting with it and wanted a customer's opinion. At that point, I hadn't tried it, but my wife had and she assured him that it was very good (something I'd find out later). 

For drinks, we kept it pretty simple, though my wife did enjoy the Canyon Oaks Cabernet. 

We didn't wind up getting dessert, because we were very full. Too bad, because I imagine that they make a great beignet. 

All in all, it was a very good dining experience. Can't wait to come back.

Hard to knock this place.... Ok it's not New Orleans ..but the drinks are good, the food great and the music awesome....gumbo is delish, flavor profile on the pork great , and bread pudding yummy.   oh yeah the service was on point....

We tried this place because it looked good. I will say, it was good. The menu sounded delicious. The prices were decent. I can't complain about that. However, as I sat down and had my glass of wine, I started to see gnats flying about. They got worse for some reason. When my food arrived, I was swarmed by them to the point I couldn't eat. We asked to be moved and since it was packed they just moved us to a different table, still outside. I could not eat my food because of the gnats. I know they can't help the outdoor elements, but I mean, seriously a big issue I had to leave the restaurant, my wine glass ended up with 3 gnats floating inside it. It was gross.

Do yourself a favor, and get the alligator. No it is not "kinda like chicken." It's a different taste, a different texture and whole lot of goodness. The sauce drizzled on the lightly battered, crispy pieces of alligator tail meat has the right amount of kick to make you close your eyes and go, "yummmm" and secretly wish that your dinner buddies that you are sharing this with would disagree and not eat a lot of the crunchy, fried alligator bites and so you can devour them all. 
Well, that ain't happening! It is THAT good!
I got the quail as dinner. I didn't want a piece of blackened fish or something that I could make myself! So quail it was! The bed of wild rice and oyster dressing is delicious. The quail itself is juicy with a crispy skin. 
One of my friends raved about the gumbo. Another had the cornmeal crusted tilapia (special) of the night. The cooking here is done very very well. The cornmeal crust is just perfect, crusty, yet juicy fish on the inside.
The experience is truly great and kinda unique. The bar is crazy busy, the seating area is vibrant with people of all ages enjoying their food. A happy crowd is always a sign of a great restaurant.

The portions here are more on the Pittsburgh portion side. The place has valet parking, I didn't know about it until I parked, so don't know the details. There are quite a few garages around Nola.

Absolutely delicious food! Today was my first time at Nola today, and I will definitely go again. I had the Grilled Chicken Panini with the fries. The fries were incredibly good! The panini was yum too. 

The only problem with this place is that the service is ridiculously slow. It has been a while since I waited 30 minutes after I ordered to have my food served. I don`t know if it is because it was a lunch time during a weekday, or if it is their usual routine. But I would recommend carving time on your calendar longer than the usual if you would like to go this place during the week and sit down to enjoy your lunch. 

Highly recommend it - will try the drinks next time which I heard are also really good!

$40 for a cup of Gumbo, Jambalaya, a Pepsi, and tip. Very, very spicy, to the point of overwhelming any flavor. Jambalaya was a bit salty and greasy, with dried out chicken, definitely not worth $23. I won't be rushing back any time soon.

Last night my husband and I had a very short baby sitting window to grab a few bites and drinks. After stopping next door at Sienna for a drink and app we decided to head over to NOLA next.
I have been there once before a few years ago with a girlfriend and I had the best oyster stew I have ever had. That is why I gave a two star review. Unfortunately this time we didn't get to try anything to eat. 
We sat ourselves at the bar after alerting the host that we were there for a drink and an app. It seemed fairly busy. Not crazy, but decently busy. We sat and waited for anyone to acknowledge our arrival. Down the bar we saw a barback polishing glasses. A couple employees farther down chatting it up with each other. So we decided to give it a few minutes before making any rational decisions. 
Another minute or so goes by. The manager walks right by us with glasses without even looking at us or any of the other guests at the bar. At this point we realize that we think there is only one bartender for the whole 20 person bar. My thing is if you only have one bartender and barback maybe help your employees out a little bit? 
So another couple minutes go by. We decide to give it another 60 seconds. And alas, nothing. So we missed out on our stew and drink we were looking forward to and decided to get up and leave. 
I don't know if anyone noticed the two people sitting at the bar got up and left. I honestly hope they did. We are both in the restaurant/bar industry and the first thing you do when you are in the weeds is at least aknowledge to new guests that you will be with them shortly. We may have been more forgiving if someone at least said hello to us. 
Maybe one day we will try to include NOLA into our downtown restaurant hop date-night again. But probably not in the near future.

Great Cajun food and good service. The waiter was able to answer all our questions and provided awesome recommendations. I had the Blackened Red Fish (Red Beans & Rice with Blackened White Fish and Coleslaw) and my friend had the Jambalaya. Both dishes I recommend trying. They were awesome. We had the fried alligator for a appetizer. A little tough and chewy. I guess it was good, never had alligator before--Just had to try it.

Great atmosphere, service and food.  Only thing that keeps me from giving it a 5 star rating is the fact that they didn't serve bread or rolls and the time between our appetizers and dinners was a little long.  I had shrimp and grits and it was absolutely awesome!  My husband had a Mac Daddy pasta dish that was chockfull of seafood, my son had the jambalaya, also full of seafood.  My other son said his peach cobbler was the best he ever ate!  Food portions were large, we all had a doggie bag for home.  Everything was perfectly seasoned, felt as if we were eating cajun food from they bayou!  Bar area noisy, we ate in the dining area--quite nice!

The dinner preparation was excellent, unfortunately service was flawed. Our utensils were not cleared between courses, and unbelievably the server handled our utensils during the meal. Perhaps Tuesday night was training night, but the poor service cannot be forgiven easily

We couldn't resist stopping in at this place. The outside eating area is small and can get somewhat uncomfortable when many people are waiting to find a seat. This is made up for by the amazing band that was playing and the general ambiance of market square. Many people stopped to take pictures of the restaurant, patio, and band. This restaurant really adds to the market square environment. 

We were told to grab any open seat on the patio since the indoor seating area was unavailable due to our lack of a reservation. This did not bother us and they were polite. The draft beer selection was good and their "house" IPA was decent. The alligator starter is crispy and smothered in a zesty sauce. Good stuff! The pork chop was huge and worth the price. Overall we loved this place due to the good food, service, and environment. Check it out while it is still warm.

I've been to Nola a few times over the years and it's always been enjoyable. They must be under new management now because the drinks and the service were terrible. We saw one female manager  who either sat at a table watching tv or was yelling at the servers who all seemed like they had no idea what they were doing. It was very uncomfortable. Also who doesn't have luxadaro or amarena for an old fashioned?! Very disappointed about the drinks and the price we paid for them

The main entrees at Nola are great and consistently tasty!! However, the desserts are absolutely terrible!!! The creme brûlée is more like a cake, the bananas foster taste like brown sugar, and the cream on top was a tasteless blob of goo! Where are the bananas?? I definitely recommend Nola's for their great main courses, however the owner needs to look elsewhere for a real dessert/pastry chef or get them further training perhaps!! Eat at Nola's but save your $$$ on dessert pick this up elsewhere (dunkin doughnuts next door would be better)!!!

Food was good. Had a daily special of duck with butternut squash and some pasta. The duck was a little over spiced, but made up for hte pasta being under spiced. Added a little salt to help. 

The service was a little slow, but the rest of the evening was good. Servers were very freindly, Price was a little steep. Overall, I'd go back.

Made an impromptu visit to this restaurant, glad I did. The coffee was nice and hot, fresh. We sat on the patio while eating our brunch. I had a simple meal with breakfast potatoes and eggs (don't remember the name of the dish), I asked for mild seasoning and they did it just right. My boyfriend had a voodoo Mary and he says it was fair. Overall good experience, would want to experience dinner here.

GOOD FOOD AND DRINKS WITH FRIENDS

I came here on a week night, even on the week night it was a little loud.  This wasn't an issue for my friends and I.  We had several drinks (good Hurricanes) and some small bites of food.  The French Onion soup was very good, a little too salty but very flavorful overall.  The baked oysters were very good overall.  

Our waiter (Shane) was very good and helped us learn more about Pittsburgh and the surrounding area.

It's not the best place for an intimate dinner, however a great place for drinks and food with a group of friends.
Great Waldorf salad awesome blue cheese dressing. Shrimp and scallop Mac and cheese was incredible. Wife had shrimp and grits creamy grits tons of flavor

WOW... granite I have not been to Nola's in about a year. We went there over the weekend just because I have always loved their fried shrimp. They limited their menu to absolutely nothing. Fried shrimp was taken off. No biggy, although for a New Orleans based restaurant, how can you not have fried shrimp. Thats ok, I ordered the craw-fish... waitress said, I am sorry, we are out of craw-fish. Again New Orleans based restaurant without shrimp nor craw-fish. I then ordered the pulled pork sandwich that stated it came with onion rings on top, literally, one onion ring. The sandwich was cold, the bun was hard. Ohhh and when I tried to go healthier with fruit cup. Sorry, we are out of fruit cup, I went with the fries, please change your oil more then once every six months please. We also ordered the Gumbo and flatbread. Those were not to bad, but we had to ask for silverware and napkins. The restaurant was not crowded at all, there was no reason why we needed to ask for utensils. So disappointed. Please try another restaurant before stopping here. I don't know if you are under new management, but please get it together.

I just had lunch there-Oyster stew and NOLA salad. Also ordered Fried Green Tomatoes which they forgot. They oyster stew was sooo salty it tasted an entire shaker of salt was dumped the pot.  It would have been really good otherwise.  We mentioned to the waitress who said everyone has been complaining all week and that is how it is supposed to taste because of the seafood.  I'm sure the chef did not try this prior to serving. I can't understand why after several complaints they would keep serving and not address this.  They were also out of the Mufaletta sandwich which is a New Orleans staple.  They need to hire some better chefs and waitresses apparently.

Maybe some of the worst food and service I've ever had...anywhere. I think our server had never ever even eaten in a restaurant before starting work at Nola. We were there for almost two hours since it took  so long for food and she came to out table three times.  We had to ask the manager where our food was after an hour.  It was a Sunday and the restaurant was about a third full. The 'bone-in' short ribs was a fatty pot roast (literally sitting in a clear pool of fat on my platter) there were no bones or flavor.  The grits had a dried layer on top from sitting under a heat lamp. I used to frequent Nola when it opened. It was great and I don't know what happened.

Nola never disappoints! I've been three times in the past 6 months and it's always just so yummy. The service is wonderful and it's affordable.  I don't so much like the decor. It feels dated somehow, but that's just personal taste. Try the red beans and rice! To die for!

TERRIBLE..Woodfired flatbread pizza, sausage and crawfish. Not a flatbread just pizza dough that was very flimsy. Way too much cheese. Crawfish disgusting, fishy flavor. Sausage ok. Also had gator app. Best part was the creole sauce. Plates were dirty. Nola is a nogo

NOLA was ok, but I probably won't be back. Two of us dined --One really enjoyed the Mac daddy (seafood Mac n cheese).  The other didn't eat the tomato mozz flat bread (it was very soggy and oily). Server Cory was awesome, really above average. The atmosphere was ruined by the fact that it was absolutely freezing. Like cover your arms with napkins freezing!!  Other guests were complaining about the temp, too.

New Orleans in Pittsburgh! Ate here on a Saturday evening early. No happy hour on the weekends. We opted for the outdoor seating as it was a beautiful day. The menu selection is limited and pricey. We got the gumbo and the Mahi-mahi special entree. For the price it should have included a salad or at least bread. Food was tasty but the meal should have included more for the price. Service was great. There was no wait. We walked so parking was not an issue for us. There were

I was somewhat disappointed.  The food was just ok.  We had to ask for bread.  The salad was too 'tart' - a lot of oil.  The pasta that I had was just ok -- nothing to write home about.  The drinks were good.  I was disappointed in the peach cobbler.  The renovations are nice though.  We could see the kitchen from our table and that was nice even though my husband wanted the chef to start yelling.  I'm not sure I would go out of my way to go back.

I have visited NOLA on two different occasions. 

The first was a very casual afternoon when we had been out and about exploring downtown Pittsburgh. We sat outside (a great location for people watching in the square, by the way) and enjoyed a couple of drinks and a sampling of appetizers. Everything we had was wonderful - including the service!

Our second visit was on Easter Sunday. We had a party of 5 and were assigned to a table in the back part of the restaurant that was being overseen by William (I'll get back to him later). 

First off, I will say that this restaurant has 3 unique seating areas to choose from based upon your mood. As I mentioned earlier, the outdoor seating area had a very nice café feel with a great view of Market Square. Then there is the bar section, where various televisions were broadcasting sports programs while jazz music played in the background. It had a very fun, New Orleans feel to it. This particular location seemed to be a pretty happening area for people in their 20s & 30s given the loud music and sporting event coverage. The place that we were seated was located in the back of the restaurant. It was quieter and had much more of an upscale feeling than the front two sections. This was perfect for us as we had just come from a theater production and were anxious to discuss the details of the play. The kitchen, which is located in this area, was open and visible to us, although we were not bothered at all by the noise level. They workers seemed to be very conscientious of keeping it that way. The food was fabulous and so was the service - which brings me back to William. 

William, our waiter, was AMAZING! Not only was he extremely familiar with the menu and the available specials, but he made sure that each one of us had his individualized attention as we were ordering. Each of us had different tastes which he personally evaluated before offering suggestions of those dishes he thought matched those qualifications. We all loved the selections we had made thanks to his input. Also, many times waiters and waitresses can tend to be over attentive, in that they strive to make sure that their customers' every need is met. This, however, can become a bit complicated when you have a group involved in deep discussion. It took a lot of though and insight on his part to know what times were best for him to step in and which times were better for him to quietly remain available in the background. Somehow, William managed to juggle this task in the most efficient and least-intrusive way possible. Although he never interrupted a conversation or thought, he made sure that he took care of all of our needs including drink refills and plate clearing with almost no notice of his presence. 

I would highly recommend this restaurant. Service and food are fabulous...and make sure to request William if you want superior service. Way to go, William!

Live music in any atmosphere adds to the ambience. Service was really fast and the the waiter was super polite, knowledgeable and helpful in helping me choose items from the menu. I had the fried alligator which was delicious but small for the price. For my main course I opted for the shrimp and grits. Mind you I hate anything with grits as an accompaniment and I was truly surprised at how good the food was. I emptied my plate needless to say. I definitely recommended this place on a Saturday night with friends. It's a very relaxed and inviting atmosphere.

The service is fantastic! We had the pizza, amazing! My husband had the Roast beef, it wasn't what he expected and they happily replaced it for the turkey! So nice! The fries are what stole the show! Really, you must try!
Very salty and not what I expected. Was sat down and had to ask for silverware when food arrived. Needs improvements.
Food is great!  But....Server...no personality...forgot item on order.....had to flag someone down for drink refills...Thursday night... not crowded ..disappointing customer service.

Worst place waited more than an hour and now she is saying it will take at least 30 more mins to get to your order, ridicules make sure u only sit people u can serve and don't waste people's time, never going back and will highly non recommend. Professional behavior is a minimal trait expected from any business, specially the ones dependent on customers. We are leaving the restaurants after sitting here for 1 hour 20 mins without food.

Perfectly balanced Creole cooking. Just the right amount of heat and spice but never overwhelming. Great beer list too. Service was good - not intrusive or forgetful. It was a bit noisy in the front of the restaurant so ask to be seated in the back. The fruit flies were a bit irritating. Otherwise, of was a great experience.

Yay for Team Nola! 

By that I specifically mean Jackie the event coordintor, Jen the mgr, Joyce and Matt for service. I live in Atlanta and theyhelped me execute my Dad's 75th bday party last weekend even while planning from a remote location! 

We used the speakeasy upstairs and It wasan event for 30 close friends and family.  The setup was awsome, service was fun and lively, food reviews were very good. 

Our menu consisted of Crab cakes and Fried green tomatoes, Crab Bisque, Salad, Lemon Catfish, the Filet, and the Pasta. Everyone loved the fish and the filet. The pasta was a little spicey for most to finish but they still said it was good. 

As far as the service, Joyce and Matt were AMAZING and formed great connections with my hostess crew. They also helped us transform the room to a true harlem rennesance type of look and made our set up and breakdown smooth and easy. We brought, in our own desserts bar and Nola supported with brining out the birthday cake. We had music in room and people could flow downstairs for the live music if they chose. Lukily we were fun enought that no one did. :-) 

I do wish they had free wii fi to facilitate the music but that was a minor issue since I have a mobile hotspot. 

Overall I'm very excited at the end results and truely appreciate Jackie, Jen, Joyce, and Matt for helping me give Daddy an awsome memory! Go team Nola!

I would have to agree with some of the other reviews about NOLA. I experienced much of what was reflected in other reviews. My 4 star rating comes mostly from the overpriced food, and generic desire to provide customer service to us as I will explain.

A group of us (6) made reservations for 8:45pm on a Saturday night.  We arrived early and had a drink at the bar after we checked in with the hostess. 8:45pm came and went and at around 9:05 we began to wonder why we haven't been seated yet. Finally around 9:30 we finally sat down. A whole 45 minutes past our reservation time, I find this unacceptable because there where numerous open tables on the other side of the restaurant. Also the management and staff constantly asked us if we were doing good and having fun etc. I find this approach to be like walking into a department store and someone is breathing down your neck. When I made the correlation that their approach was generic was when the waitress spilled my wife's glass of wine on the table. Rather than simply asking "what kind of wine she had," and replacing it with a full glass. She actually asked how much was left in the glass and brought her another glass that was approximately a half serving of wine. Slightly tacky in my opinion. It really seemed as if they could have used more waitstaff for the dinning room.

The food was pretty good but I seriously believe that it was a little bit on the high $ side. I also thought that their menu was lacking some other staple Cajun dishes such as etouffee, boudin, boiled crawfish. Although they did have frog legs on the menu which I tried, have to say they were good. And alligator. I did think that it was weird that they did have things on the menu labeled as Cajun like Salmon??? I also tried the shrimp and grits and scallops Mac Daddy. I thought that the shrimp and grits while flavorful did not have the correct consistency of true grits. I also thought that this dish represented more of a "Southern style cooking" rather than New Orleans / Cajun.  And for $26 which I knew was high in the first place. The scallops Mac daddy was definitely the Mac Daddy. Very good rich dish with perfectly cooked scallops.

We had a reservation and did not have to wait at all. There was live jazz but I was glad to not be seated near the bar- it would have been way too loud for any conversation.
We started with a rum/milk/chocolate cocktail which was good but strong. Our waiter was friendly and helpful. We kicked off our meal with a starter of fried shrimp and it was just fantastic. The portion size was good and the hot pepper jelly was a great complement  to the flavors. We followed it up with grilled catfish. It was cooked perfectly. I am not a big fan of mashed potatoes and opted to add some hot sauce to the dish. We were offered a selection of 7-8 hot sauces. Loved it!
The dessert selection didn't tempt us much and there weren't too many choices for vegetarians. But it's a nice place and we might go back to try the other fish choices.

Ate at NOLA last night. I tried the alligator bites and crawfish flatbread for appetizers. Both were pretty good. I had the Duck Mac Daddy for the main course. It was absolutely delicious. Probably one of the best meals I've eaten. Highly recommended!!!!!!

Best french onion soup around.  Lunch prices are affordable and this is a cuisine unique to downtown.

Great addition to market square! Plus they participate in LoyalTree mobile rewards program.

Four of us went here before a Pens game.  The meat and cheese appetizer was the best item we had.  Shrimp and grits too bland.  Chicken and dumplings was too spicey.  Didn't mention that in the menu.  Seafood jambalaya was fishy.  Not very good.......sorry.

I took my fiance to NOLA on the square for her birthday dinner this evening. We're both from the south, and half of my family hails from/resides in New Orleans. We had a 7PM reservation made weeks ago, and were seated immediately upon arrival. We selected the fried alligator and red beans and rice as our starters. The alligator was PHENOMENAL(best I've ever had) and the red beans and rice was spot on! I had the shrimp and grits, while my fiance chose the shrimp and scallops mac daddy. Both were excellent. We settled on the apple/caramel bread pudding for dessert. It was great, as well as the homemade vanilla ice cream that accompanied it. My fiance had the sangria, and enjoyed it. It was a little too rosy for my liking, but it satisfied her palate. Our waiter, Sean, was sufficiently attentive, and the manager, Mark, made his rounds to ensure that each guest had a pleasurable experience. I love the open kitchen setup, which affords you the opportunity to witness the painstaking approach and dedication that is shown to each plate.
We often joke about how Yinzers (generally speaking) don't know good food when they taste it, and often make horrible reviews on good, if not great, restaurants on here. We look forward to coming back to try brunch and po-boys at lunch!
Also worth noting, parking is a premium around the square... That being said, if you make one pass with no spots available, there are a couple of parking garages that are a short walking distance from NOLA.

Cool restaurant, great location, nice interior seating in addition to patio. Pretty real deal New Orleans food with variety but thankfully not overdone or with too high quality ingredients lol. Surprisingly good all around and engaged and attentive service

I've been to NOLA several times over the years, and I've never had a bad meal. Great beer selection, good mixed drinks, and delicious food.

My wife and I are suckers for good oysters, and they know how to pick me. I'm particularly fond of their gumbo and PO boy sandwiches. You can get a nice side salad for lunch with your meal as well.

Regarding brunch I've had the beignets which are wonderful and the pancake special is always good from my experience. To top it off their coffee is delicious.

For my money, one of the best sit down options in Market Square, or downtown for that matter.

Very friendly busy happening place. Busy on a Tuesday night mainly due to happy hour. 
Great menu phenomenal beers.

I give this place props for even having vegetarian and vegan options. But everything we ordered was far too salty, smothered in oil, and served luke-warm. 

The ambiance was bad. Rickety table and horrible lighting accompanied our dingy back dining room.

Service was actually decent, and our waitstaff was very nice.
Had beers with a friend at the bar. Then we got hungry and ordered two apps: The pork sliders were awesome and the voodoo fries were delicious!   This was my first time here but it will be my last :)

I came here with my cousin and friend and we had EXCEPTIONAL service. Everyone was really nice and our food was great. I love the atmosphere and the warm ambiance. Their fries are the bomb diggity, no doubt!!

Came here with a group of twelve and had a great experience. Service was friendly, food came out rather quickly and everything was delicious. I got the Cajun catfish and loved it, it was cooked well and the potatoes were seasoned perfectly. We also got the jumbalya, steak frites, shrimp and grits, flatbread as well as the Mac cheese. Everyone was sharing and loving their meals, and all but some of the rice for the jumbalya (quite a large portion) was gone!  The appetizers were a little on the small side, but they were also delicious! We got the alligator and some shrimp something. Yum!

Nola on the square has authentic New Orleans dishes. I love this restaurant, not sure why I don't dine here more often? The menu is reasonably priced and the service is pretty good. I love that they have outdoor seating. The restaurant looks tiny from the outside, but it is surprisingly big inside. I enjoy the jazz style music they play, really makes you feel like you're eating somewhere in the French quarter. I recommend the voodoo pasta. It's really good with the perfect amount of spice, full of vegetables and I suggest adding shrimp. The shrimp are jumbo and grilled to perfection.  I am looking forward to going back sometime soon!

Food was good and so were the drinks. This was priced at $$ but it should probably be  $$$. The ribs were way better than I expected. The rib is a beef rib. The firried green tomatoes though....omg they were great! Best ones I have ever had.

I ordered the Seafood Mac Daddy, which is supposed to have lobster, SHRIMP and toasted bread crumb. Sounds great, until I was jipped and only given 2 shrimp with the tail on! On top of that, I had two chunks of black coal in my food (I HAVE PICTURES TO PROVE THIS SAD STATEMENT)... I am still upset about it.
SERVICE: A group of coworkers and I order a few items to go. Upon arriving to the restaurant we were completely ignored by the young lady working the night shift behind the bar, who unfortunately was the only employee in sight. One of my coworkers approached her and asked if we could pay for our meals, she first rolled her eyes, huffed and walked off to complain about us to another patron. Then she held another 10 minute conversation with another guy behind the counter gathering trash, then proceeded to complete our transaction. The name on the receipt is KASSANDDRA S. (December 30, 2014 10:43 pm) 

i ATTEMPTED TO CONACT THEIR MANAGER AND GOT NO RESPONSE...
The food is good. BUT the waiting time is insanely long!! We waited for an hour for the entree to be served on a Sunday morning.

I will try to make this short and to the point. 

I was in town for business and decided to give this place a try...

 First and foremost, the food was decent, but nothing special. It's a little overpriced, but it's downtown Pittsburgh so that's to be expected. 

What I didn't expect was the  unprofessional and bizarre service I received. 

The restaurant has a mature business atmosphere, but the two young males I dealt with in particular, were not suited for this environment. 

Normally, when I attend a restaurant of this caliber, the staff knows how to articulate and address their guess with respect. 

These two individuals, the host (who came to my table often) and my waiter, kept talking to me in a manner as if I were one their PlayStation or Xbox buddies. 

For example, these two individuals would say things like: 

"Man, you want something to drink, dude?"

"Umm... You ready to order yet, man?"

"Umm... You need anything else, dude?"

"Man, you want a bag or something, man? 

It wasn't anything overly egregious, but I kept scratching my head, because it was just weird and unprofessional. 

Here I am, a paying customer, in business attire, in a business atmosphere and I'm being addressed with little to no respect. 

At one point, I thought maybe this was part of the theme of the restaurant, but I doubt it. 

For the record... 

I'm sure a few people will read this and will automatically assume that these two young men were African American or minorities... 

That would be inaccurate. 

These two young men, we're both Caucasian males from Pittsburgh....

Be that as it may, although I received mediocre service at best, I still managed to give my waiter a generous tip based on the required gratuity percentage of my overall bill. 

Again, the food was decent, but I don't expect to spend any more of my hard earned money at this establishment. I don't see myself returning.

I used to really like NOLA, but I have had very poor stomach reactions (of food poisoning-degree) to the food twice now.  I know that others have as well.  My staple used to be the oyster stew but I think that this might have been the two-time culprit.  

I think generally the quality of the food has gone down.  Still a decent place for a drink, though.  

I also think that the floors are generally really dirty, and this is a huge turnoff.  

My suggestion, if you're looking for a good place to eat in Market Square, go to Sienna or Il Pizzaiolo.  In the beginning, NOLA was a novel idea (although not even authentically New Orleans cuisine).  The novelty just wore off.
Very much enjoyed the atmosphere, both staff and patrons made my evening a great time. The food was excellent, drinks affordable, and the band gave me a reason to dance. Fun!

Generic fried food. Yuck! Jambalaya was pre made and cold in the middle. When asked the waitress to fix it, she said "of they probably didn't put it in the oven long enough!!" Do not recommend. Mistake by the owners.

I want to like Nola, probably will and wish them the best.  Trying them for the first time during the arts festival was a mistake. But . . .  The service was horrible. A 7:15 reservation became an 8:00 when we were forced to hover over an outside table waiting for the group to leave. We thought the four-top was incredibly rude as they lingered over their completed and cleared meal until we realized they were still waiting for their check. They immediately produced a credit card only to wait another fifteen minutes for the waitress to return. We then got the same waitress and the same level of service. No manager inquiry and only painfully uneven service. The food--at least the things they weren't out of--was good. But I'll try again on a quieter night.

We came here for dinner on a Monday night while at a week-long conference downtown. The service was very good, and our server was very friendly and knowledgeable. Great music too, and the drinks were very good as well. Unfortunately, the food didn't blow us away. It was above average, just not great. Personally, I would have liked to see the catfish cooked a little more (you can't be too careful when it comes to undercooked seafood), but it was flavorful. Overall, I'd rate the total experience at 3.5 to 3.75 stars if Yelp would let me, and would give NOLA another shot if in the area.

We visited Nola on Saturday night for a late dinner with friends.  Overall, I was incredibly impressed with the service and the food.  My husband had the jambalaya which was appropriately spicy but I thought the tomato sauce was a bit to acidic.  However, the chef did accommodate my husband's request to substitute more scallops for shrimp (he doesn't like shrimp).  My husband also tried the frog legs which he said were OK but not great.  I tried the sauce and the sauce was spicy and very tasty.  I had the filet mignon with swiss chard and squash puree.  The steak was perfectly prepared and the squash puree was creamy and delish!  I didn't eat all the greens because I'm not a big fan of swiss chard - however, the greens were appropriately prepared and not overcooked.  We also tried the butternut squash soup with crawdad tails.  I felt it was under-salted, but otherwise tasty.  Our friends really enjoyed the duck pasta and the mushroom bread pudding.  They had ordered the fried green tomatoes as an appetizer, but it didn't appear until our meals had arrived.  Our server was gracious and had it removed from our bill.  The creme brulee is amazing and the panna cotta was outstanding!

One thing that impressed me the most was that the manager came over to check on us several times.  He also had a very thorough knowledge of the whiskey selection and was able to give our friend several very good alternatives to suit her palette.  The beer selection was decent if you're a hop head (which I am).  However, if you aren't into hops, you might find yourself unable to find a suitable beer.

I asked for a table that was near the band but not too close as to preclude any conversation.  I'm happy to say that our table was close enough the music for us to enjoy it and still be able to hear our friends.

Overall, I was incredibly impressed with Nola.  The inconsistent Yelp reviews made me squeamish about visiting, but I'm very glad that I did.  The restaurant is pricey, but the portions are decent and the food is quite good.  This is not the place to go if you have some place to be.  However, if you're in the mood for some music and a leisurely meal, I would recommend Nola.  One thing to remember, don't expect to show up on a weekend and get a table.  Reservations are a must!

Service was good, food was good, this place truly deserves to call itself NOLA.  The gumbo was very good (and I have pretty high standards), while my shrimp & grits was good but a bit too "soupy" and my colleague seemed very happy with his blackened redfish and red beans & rice.  Bread pudding for desert was also very good, in general the food at NOLA is more expensive than I would expect at home in New Orleans but I know certain items such as shrimp cost a lot more in Pittsburgh so I certainly understand.  Overall NOLA On The Square is the real deal, it's a nice option for those in Pittsburgh to experience real New Orleans food or for people like me to get some home style grub while on the road..

So, I have been to NOLA a few times and the food is decent but not fantastic, but that isn't really what this review is about. Recently, my girlfriend and I stopped by just for a few drinks. It was a nice night out and we really just wanted to relax at the bar and watch the Pirate game inside. We ordered two drinks and I asked the bartender to not take my girlfriends CC as she wanted to pay, but as a gentleman, I wanted to pay. It was a friendly argument, but the bartender was clearly fixated on my girlfriend, so he took her card instead of mine. That was strike one. As we are drinking, the bartender repeatedly interrupted our conversation not to take additional drink orders, but to flirt with my girlfriend! Being that she is a very nice and a talkative person, she spoke with him for a minute, but he wouldn't leave. Even after I repeatedly interrupted the conversation in an attempt to rescue her, he just simply wouldn't leave us alone after 5 or so minutes of conversation. That was strike two. Finally, another customer came to the bar and he had to wait on them so I thought it was over. We continued our date and everything was going fine. A few minutes later, I went to the bathroom and when I came back, guess who was leaning on the bar trying to chat up my girlfriend again? You got it - same bartender. Strike three! At this point I could sense she was feeling somewhat helpless so I just grabbed her hand and we got out of there. She was so relieved once we left, but it definitely put a damper on the evening. 

So for all you guys out there, take heed - don't take a date to this place unless you want to be repeatedly harassed by bartenders. I for one will never go back.

Great location and friendly people

But the menu and drink list needs work. Was out of a lot of things and to called this creole/Cajun food is just wrong

Well I am finally back. I have had a busy few months so I have been absent in my reviews and I am looking forward to getting back into it. NOLA seems to me to be a good place to start.

NOLA on Market Square is a great spot to get great Creole, Cajun, and Louisiana inspired cuisine. This type of food is some of my favorite on the planet. Here's an idea: let's take traditional French techniques and dishes, and throw them in a blender with Spanish, African, and American ingredients and methods. That is the basis of Creole cooking and a winning recipe if you ask me. NOLA does it better than anyone I have seen in a long time. I went there with some friends one evening for dinner and drinks. When we got there we were ushered to the back to a table by the kitchen. I was thankful for this for a few reasons. 1) we were out of the front of the restaurant that was being occupied by live music which, while very good Louisiana Jazz, was way too loud for my tastes and 2) we got to see the controlled chaos of a top notch kitchen.

NOLA is decorated with the standard Mardis Gras colors of green, yellow, and purple.The bar is long and has all the bottles lining a backlit mirror. I really dig it. It is warm, intimate, and welcoming (so long as the band isn't rocking too hard).

Service mirrored the the decor. Our server was nice, informative, and followed all the proper steps of perfect service. She seemed to be busy with a full section, yet we were never forced to wait an unreasonable amount of time for our drinks or food. Overall I found the service friendly, competent and all that I could ask for.

As far as the bar is concerned one is in for a treat. NOLA has a decent beer selection with all kinds of Abita products. Hopheads can be content with a Jockomo IPA or a a Purple Haze for the fruit-inclined. Also the cocktail list is rather impressive with all of my selections being delicious, if a little pricey.

For me however, the food is always the main event. For an appetizer I suggest the pork belly (a recurring favorite if you read my reviews). You could also try the alligator bites but they taste just like chicken. Kinda bland. For a main course my go-to is the shrimp and grits. The grits are smooth and creamy with soft fluffy shrimp tossed in all topped with scallions and andouille sausage for heat. Those who possess a spice aversion should try the steak frites. I put it up against Ruth's Chris for quality and taste. 

All in all NOLA is a great place. You will pay good money to go but it is definitely worth it in my book.
Not a fan. Food is OK. Weak happy hour. A bit too dark and a strange /cramped layout around the bar.

Came here for happy hour and was not disappointed! We got the captain mojitos which has new flavors every few weeks. We had the grapefruit one and it was so good!! We also got some $4 appetizers which were satisfying. We had the cajun andouille and Cajun cheesesticks. The Cajun andouille was pretty good-- not very standout and a little bland but good with the sauce. The cheesesticks were as expected but not much Cajun flavor. Would definitely return here for the drinks but maybe not the food.

Going to the Cultural District to see a show always brings up the opportunity to also explore some of the fun restaurants that cater to the people who work and play in this area. We've not been to Nola on the Square before, so thought we should... and we did.

The building is quite colorful on the outside and the storefront itself is quite narrow. Once inside, the decor is on the dark side with a long corridor between the bar and some table. However, it widens out towards the back (where the kitchen is) and also has an upstairs, so there is actually quite a lot of space there. We were there early, so we saw the staff doing their prep work and watching TV...  Our server did treat us well and came to check on us periodically, so the fact that we were one of only three parties on hand meant that the did not take lesser care of us for watching TV!

The menu is slanted towards either Creole or Southern cooking. In addition to the New Orleans dishes that you might expect to find in a place with this kind of a name, we also saw Fried Green Tomatoes; Chicken and Dumplings; and stuffed Mushrooms that used Pimiento Cheese! 

We ended up ordering the Fried Green Tomatoes and the Mushrooms for our appetizers; then we went with the Voodoo Pasta and the Seafood Jambalaya for our main dishes, and some Beignets for dessert. We also got a bottle of wine and were quite pleased with the price of about $70 per person - which is not high considering the quantities of dishes.

The food quality was somewhat variable, unfortunately. The Fried Green Tomatoes actually needed to be salted, but they came with a yogurt sauce which was fantastic and made the dish! The Mushrooms were disappointing in that was so little of the Pimento Cheese that you could not really taste it. The Voodoo Pasta was supposed to have Bucattini, but I swear that what came on the plate was Spaghetti! the sauce was supposed to be spicy (hence the name) but reminded me more of an Italian Arrabiata sauce than anything else. The Seafood Jambalaya was a study in contrasts: The shrimp and scallops were expertly prepared, but the chicken was charred and overcooked. The sausage was good. The star of the evening were the Beignets that came covered in powdered sugar and also with a small dish of Mango Sorbet (our choice). This dessert made the dinner!

Our waiter was highly knowledgeable about the food and steered us to the appropriate combinations for our taste. We also some saw dishes being take to other tables, and they looked very nice. I would definitely come back here as the cuisine is not the normal Pittsburgh offering and perhaps some of the faults I noted were temporary.
Delicious flavorful and interesting menu options. Well-stocked bar and yummy drinks. Fun and relaxing atmosphere. Friendly waitress.

Why did I wait so long?

NOLA had been on my radar for sometime but, I just never made it there. Then they had a severe fire in 2014 and was closed for remodeling so when my team chose NOLA for our annual Holiday Luncheon and being that I had never been I was pretty excited. 

Once we walked in we were teleported straight to Bourbon Street. I have been to New Orleans and this space has the soul and feel of N'awlins.

Not long after we were seated David K. our server greeted us and took our drink orders. There were six in our party so we decided to start off with some appetizers to share. We ordered the Red Beans & Rice, Fried Green Tomatoes (Abita Amber Ale Batter, Cheddar, Creole Mustard Ranch), Salmon Cake (Basil aioli, pickled red onions, cauliflower and Arugula hash) and Stuffed Mirliton (Chayote squash, catfish cake, trinity, dill béchamel). The red beans & rice and fried green tomatoes were the favorites of the group. The red beans & rice had some spice to them and just enough heat. The fried green tomatoes were delicious as well.

For our lunch entrees my team ordered the Seafood Jambalaya (Cajun Rice, Chicken, Shrimp, Sea Scallops, Andouille), Fish Du Jour and the Cajun Grilled Catfish (fire-roasted sweet peppers and onions, mashed Yukon potato, sautéed spinach, spicy lemongrass-citrus Beurre Noisette). I chose the Gumbo Ya-Ya. It featured chicken, Andouille, okra, Filé, and steamed rice and I also chose the Shrimp and Grits. It featured shrimp, Trinity, Abita Amber Ale, Anson Mills cheddar grits and smoked bacon) My God! They were both so good!
