Everyone raved about their food and said we had to come back! Very rarely does everyone all like their food as we have some picky eaters on our team.

After lunch a few of us went over to the bar for cocktails. I had the 504 Old Fashioned. It has Makers Mark, Peach Schnapps, Peach Bitters and a orange slice. It is strong with a hint of peach. It was quite delicious.

NOLA on the Square has great Creole food and excellent service. I highly recommend them!

Insider Tip: Come for lunch instead of dinner as the entree prices are about half that of the dinner prices.

Went for brunch on a Sunday morning and was pretty disappointed. The beignets were an absolute joke, small and crunchy, NOTHING like what you would find in New Orleans. The shrimp and grits also left much to be desired. We won't be back.

Excellent food and presentation. They're going for that New Orleans flair. I personally have not been yet, but i could only imagine from the ambiance that NOLA provides.  

I went on a Wednesday and there was a live jazz band playing. Had the filet mignon and it was cooked to perfection. It came with cream spinach and potatoes.  The spinach left a bit to be desired, but the meal itself was still delicious.  For an appetizer, I had the BBQ shrimp. 6 pieces of the juiciest most succulent shrimp ever. 

The place was a bit pricey, but I'd say it's worth it.

NOLA was wonderful.  I wish we had gotten there sooner to hear more music as the music ends at 11. 
Service was attentive and friendly. Great salads and Flatbread.  If I lived in PGH I'd visit this place again for sure. The BBQ shrimp was just as good as you get in New Orleans.

the grilled catfish was okay, nothing spectacular. crawfish mac daddy was probably the best thing of the night. fried alligator was mostly crumbs. the happy hour drinks are good. beignets were flat and overcoated with powdered sugar, but the ice cream that came with it was great.
Good service, good food & awesome atmosphere! Great addition to Market Square. The jambalaya was yummy!

This is a good place if you don't mind noise (aka a meal with some boisterous friends). I wouldn't recommend it for a cozy date-night, as it would be too loud to hear each other.  I have only tried a few dishes at Nola, as I have a shellfish allergy and shellfish factors heavily into the menu.  The catfish is my favorite, though I am not a fan of the sides.  It comes with a "corn-potato maque-choux" which (excuse the graphic description) basically looks like corn and potatoes someone already ate.  It is a watery, loose mess on the plate.  Good news is that you can substitute other sides for it.  The beignets sat in my stomach like rocks for the rest of the afternoon after I split this dessert with a friend.  The service is hit or miss. I have had great service and I have had absent service.  They have been very accomodating with larger group (8-12).

I wanted to like this place, I really really REALLY did. After moving from New Orleans we were begging for a place that had food from home. This, however, is nothing like it. Even the atmosphere was oddly wrong? Like they read a book on how one thinks New Orleans restaurants are decorated but not how they actually are. Although, the large painting of the second line is great. We did some research and the artists aren't even from Nola, they commissioned someone local. We were then shocked to discover that NONE OF THE CHEFS HAVE COOKED IN NEW ORLEANS!! And boy, it is evident in the food. Now if you are unfamiliar with creole/cajun style cooking I would guess that you would enjoy this place. If, however, you are used to real dining from New Orleans, this will do nothing but disappoint. Service was slow (hey! they got one thing right! haha), cocktails were subpar, and the food lacked the flavor depth that we are used to. I will say one thing, the boudin was pretty darn good! And while this is just being picky, if you are going to have a restaurant themed such as this, your servers should know how to properly pronounce the food they are serving-there's no 'L' sound in andouille (again, picky but in my opinion, true.) Sadly, we still have not found a place that comes even close to home :(

Great lunch spot! I've only been here a few times for lunch and once for happy hour. Both experiences were great with no complaints. The atmosphere is also quite nice, feels a bit fancy and the space is a lot bigger than it looks from the outside. For lunch, I always get the soup and half sandwich duo (with fries, of course) because it's a little bit of variety. I've tried the gumbo and french onion soup, and the shredded beef po boy (which I think they took off the menu) and the muffaletta. All have tasted great, a few steps up from an Au Bon Pain lunch. The voodoo fries are seasoned pretty well, a little spicy, so you might not even need ketchup. Nola gets a crowd for lunch, though, so if you plan on coming here, call and reserve a table ahead of time. In terms of drinks, their drinks are pretty great too. The cocktails are a little pricey, but around $10 is the going rate for most drinks downtown anyway. Overall, I think this place is pretty good and my coming back soon is very likely.

Went here with some coworkers for my boss' birthday and I have to say that this place was really, well I suppose the word to describe it is "meh". We went during our lunch hour and found the restaurant itself was not very busy, which was nice because we were seated quite quickly. Our server and the rest of the staff were very polite and attentive. Opening the menu, it was pretty small in terms of food options, normally I take this as a sign that its a restaurant that likes to specialize and only focuses on the freshest and best dishes, however these guys were clearly an exception to the rule. I myself ordered the shrimp and grits which was probably the most expensive menu item (though not that expensive), and I can't recall what my coworkers got, however I must say that when the food came out I was very, very underwhelmed. There was absolutely no kick to the food that one expects to find when visiting a "New Orleans" style restaurant and the portions were sub-par to say the least. I'd also note that the food in of itself was just kind of there, it wasn't bad nor was it good in terms of quality, just bland and I've had better for the price. In the end, I wouldn't recommend this place, at least not as a lunch spot, who knows, maybe their dinner specials/happy hours are what actually keep them in business, but I won't be one chomping at the bit to find out.
Excellent shrimp appetizer! Ok flatbread. I would return. Music was too loud and the service was awful. I'd give them another chance!

We stopped in at NOLA on a whim, and partially because it was raining and we didn't want to venture too far from our hotel. We were seated quickly, and despite being in a not so great table (no reservations on a Friday night) service was efficient. 

I had the Muffalata flat bread, it was really good, but huge - it's an app so meant to be shared, but I wished i had a fridge in the hotel to save it for a late night munchie. Instead it went away. He had the seafood jambalaya, which was fine but not very spicy and quite small for the price. 

Overall, NOLA was okay...I don't know that it'd be on my "you have to try this place in Pittsburgh" list, but I wouldn't recommend against it or anything either. Definitely just A-OK.

Lunch today. Very impressed. Fun atmosphere. Great service and food. Shrimp appetizer was outstanding. Gumbo solid and enjoyed the shrimp po boy. Not sure about the dinner menu but lunch prices very reasonable.

I guess this place is still working out the kinks. I took my parents here on a Saturday night for a delicious Cajun fiesta and left wanting more. They were out of three signature cocktails (Sazerac, Creole Julep and Le Bon Temps Roule) and the service was friendly yet glacial. I realize they are relatively new but I don't get how you can be 'out' of cocktails on a Saturday night. I settled on a Hennessy Sidecar which was slightly watered down but still delicious.

As for the food, the appetizers were alright. We started with the fried artichokes and Pissaladiere flatbread. While the artichokes were divine, the flatbread left something to be desired. Despite the rich ingredients it tasted bland and lacking. I was also seeing a LOT of black, charred edges on the flatbreads that hit the other tables. There's a difference between a bit of burn and way too much and this fell well into the latter category. My Dad loved his French Onion soup which was rich and sweet and apparently made with three types of onions.

Things improved vastly with our entrees. We had the filet mignon special, shrimp & grits and grilled catfish. Portions here are HUGE and big enough to share. I have to say I was pretty happy with the quality and seasoning of my catfish. My father's filet was so tender and wonderful that he cut it with a butter knife and my mom's shrimps were the size of my hand and super tasty. I am a huge fan of grits and the chef did a decent job with these. They are super chunky and gritty though so if you're not a grits fan, this is not the place to try them.

For dessert we split the chocolate hazelnut torte which was a rich, creamy sweet rather than sugary sweet but again, something was missing. 

We sat in the back room which was much quieter than the front bar area and offered a view of the kitchen which I'm a huge fan of.  In terms of service, I have to give props to the manager. I called around noon to make a 6pm reservation and although he said they were full, he squeezed us in. I would come back here for a cocktail but will be sure to call first.

ow, I was really blown away at NOLA at Market Square. This place was recommended to me by a work associate complimenting the food. I walked in to a busy bar that seemed lively. Come to find it was a pub crawl that stopped crawling. I ordered the squash and pumpkin soup ($6) with the Shrimp and Grits ($27). 

I Thought is was very pricey but I don't mind if the quality is up to par. The atmosphere is very authentic to NOLA but that's where the similarities stop. The soup arrived in seconds and was bitter and salty, obviously it had been reducing for days, which was upsetting because squash and pumpkin soup is usually sweet, warm and delicious. The bartender offered to get me something else so I tried the french onion soup. It took 10 minutes, the cheese was nicely baked but the soup had little onions, it was very salty, and the bread was a gel. 

At this point I was scared to see the shrimp and grits. And as expected the dish was unrecognizable from my Cajun experience. The grits were served as a cake bar which was not seasoned topped with a watery sauce that had congealed under the lamps. The celery was raw and crunchy. This was garnished with inedible garnish "to offset the color". Which is sorely needed as the color was disgusting. 

I spoke to the manager who apologized but was unwilling to try the food and didn't seem interested in my opinion. He told me this was a Pittsburgh take on shrimp and grits. And he assured me others like it and removed everything from the bill. I left hungry and unhappy with the managers attitude. If they cared about quality or service the manager would have addressed the poor food immediately.

I feel sorry for everyone there that has to stomach that blemish on Cajun cuisine. In the future listen to customers and if you're going for Cajun in Pittsburgh keep it authentic!

I've been to Nola on the Square a total of three times now, and (thankfully) every trip was better than the last.

My first trip there was a bit rocky.  Granted, I was there on a Saturday night with a group of about 10.  Plus the restaurant had only been open for a few weeks at that point, so they were probably still working the kinks out at that point.  The packed restaurant definitely took a toll on our service, which was verrrry slow.  And by the time our party arrived, our waiter informed us that they were completely out of pasta, which resulted in almost half the table having to re-examine the menu for another option, including myself.  I understand that this happens, but it still looked pretty bad to be out of pasta by 8pm on a Saturday night in a relatively new restaurant.  I ended up ordering the special dish of the night, which was steak with some form of potatoes and spinach.  All very good, but nothing to write home about.

My second visit found myself and my parents there late on a Sunday afternoon.  We walked in to find the restaurant relatively empty of both patrons.....and staff.  There were three hostesses working, and after receiving a poorly-disguised eye roll from one after I told her we didn't have reservations, they all informed us that the ENTIRE wait staff was currently in a meeting, so no one was available yet to take our order.  We then proceeded to wait 20 minutes for the wait staff meeting to adjourn before we could even order a glass of water.  But I put my annoyance at that situation on the hostessses, not the waiters.  It wasn't the waiters fault they were ALL pulled into a meeting simultaneously, and apparently it wasn't in the hostess' job description to ask paying patrons if they wanted something to drink while we waited.  But ANYWAY.  Once our waitress arrived (she was quite lovely), she promptly brought our drinks and took our order.  Our food arrived in a timely manner and was very good.  I had the smoked pork chop which was massive and cooked and seasoned very well.  So despite the horribly rocky start, our meal ended quite nicely.

So FINALLY, upon my third visit, I had a completely positive Nola experience.  My group was promptly seated and our server was very informative and attentive the entire time.  I ordered the Scallps Mac Daddy which was soooooo yummy.  It's hard to go wrong with any combination of mac and cheese plus seafood, so this dish was absolutely delicious.  I can't wait to go back for my fourth visit and get it again!

So, after working some glitches out of its system, Nola finally seems to be working like the well-oiled machine it was always meant to be!

I recently visited Nola with two friends for dinner and had a wonderful experience!  We really wanted to find somewhere fun that still had  great food and Nola certainly fit the bill.  We had a wonderful waiter who did an excellent job seeing that we had just what we wanted.  We couldn't decide what to order and so we told our waiter we wanted three separate entrees and that we wanted to share.  He suggested that he bring out the appetizer first and then the entrees in succession one after another.  We ordered the Crispy Fried Alligator as an appetizer and it was delicious and perfectly seasoned.  The first entree we received was the Shrimp and Grits and it was really delicious.  Two of the people in my group (myself included) have lived in the southern low country and are shrimp and grits snobs and this definitely lived up to expectations!  The second entree was definitely the favorite of the bunch.  We ordered the catfish and it was absolutely delicious.  Our final entree was the jumbalaya and it was highly recommended by our waiter.  It was heated in the wood stove so there was a charred flavor to the stew that I really enjoyed but two other members of our group found off-putting.  The waiter encouraged us to eat dessert but we were simply too full!  Next time, we will definitely give it a try!  We will definitely visit Nola again!  It was an all around wonderful experience!

Been here several times and each time I try something new and find something I like whether its a salad, sandwich or calzone. Because its a New Orlean's style restaurant, it goes without saying there will be creole, jumbalaya and catfish.  What most people are worried about before eating here is whether there is food here that does not fit those categories or isn't spicy and the answer is yes.  

First off, the fries are great - perfectly crispy, salty, peppery and maybe some creole in there for a side that no one will deny is fantastic.  The NOLA club is a nice twist on the club sandwich, turkey on ciabatta, with spicy aeoli, some crisp bacon, pickled tomatoes and little bit of avacado: A safe move done in a way that makes it exciting. The steak salad is also a good move for those with tenuous affinities for spice but with little flairs to make it unique.  Each dish here is tastefully created and consistently delivered.

The atmosphere is nice and is intended to make one dream of Mardi Gras but patron's won't forget that Pittsburgh is right outside. The service is friendly but nothing to write home about.  Overall the food is a 5 but with the service and slightly-above-generic atmosphere, the place gets a solid 4 in my books.

Certainly a cool spot in Market Square.  A friend and I popped in here on a busy Saturday evening when the Art Fest was going on and were seated immediately with no reservation.  We both enjoyed the jazzmosphere and vibe of the place.  Servers were all super friendly.  The food was a bit pricey, but it is downtown.

Friday night at 6:30 and it's totally empty! What?? It's happy hour from 4-7. They really do have a great happy hour menu. From food to drinks it's cheap and delicious! Tonight I have the white wine sangria, stuff mushrooms and perogies. I was underwhelmed by the perogies. They were just okay. My sangria was so good! I highly recommend for happy hour.

I had the perfectly cooked, chicory rubbed,medium rare, filet mignon steak with sheered brussel sprouts, and potatoes. I'm in love!! I shall return Chef Emeril to try some more of your dishes. Applause to the start.

This has been one of the restaurants on my list for a while and I finally went with some friends ( I had a pay half certificate). 

The place was lively for a tuesday (which I love).  We had a res but we started in the bar for a couple.  The bartenders were friendly actually they must have messed up a dish in the kitchen because we were offered a whole entree while we were at the bar (we accepted). 

We sat down at our table which was in a booth on the other side of the bar, not quite as lively but it was cozy.  We ordered the crocodile and frog legs.  I wasn't a huge fan of the frog but the 'dile was good (it was fried and tossed in an aioli so that might have helped).  I ordered the catfish with rice and beans.  I wasn't a huge fan of my dish.  I guess its a NoLa thing to put pork in black beans ( i was bummed because I don't eat pork). 

My friend ordered the shrimp and grits which sounded delish.  When she got it is was floating in oil. She said the flavor was good but way too oily. 

Pro: Knowledgeable server, lively bar, market square, crocodile was good. 

Cons: Extra oily food, not very veg friendly. 

Overall: I am glad I tried this place but maybe NoLa style food isn't my thing.

As good as it gets. EXPENSIVE. yes, great service, atmosphere, and food. It all really ties into the creole, new orleans feel, and its something different for pittsburgh. I read all of there reviews, about the alligator, the grits...etc. So my friend and I ordered the famous alligator, and being a culinary student, I was ambitious to try it. AWESOME, please try it. Our next courses were the Roasted Quail, and the Seafood jambalaya. 25$ a pop, now this may be due to the fact that the waitress asked if we were sharing, but it's still expensive. However no matter the price it was amazing, the jambalaya was smokey, and all about the seafood. Now my favorite was the Quail, just so juicy with the right spices, and the red wine reduction sauce, just my mouth is watering as we speak...and I just left. Now there was no dessert menu, not even listed on the website, and I was dying for a sweet finish, and all I wanted was a banana's foster. So the waitress Abigail instructed us that, they make their desserts day of, and they had a banana's foster bread pudding with a salted caramel ice cream. BOMB DIGGGITTTYY! I'm totally making this myself. A transformation  of the original and it was just the right finish. They also have live entertainment, I'd suggest to make a reservation via open table or what not, but I over heard the hostess talking to another guest that they do get packed when there is live entertainment. Now you would think that it would get so loud in there. No I wasn't screaming out the top of my lungs to my friend, it was so casual, so jazzy, and so a perfect night. BTW hot valet boys and complimentary at that; after 5 on the weekends I believe. Expect an awesome atmosphere, great food plus service. Just expect to spend your pretty pennies on it. All thumbs up!

I was really excited to try NOLA as I love New Orleans cuisine.  The new lunch menu looked fantastic. 

Our table was a group of 6 coworkers. Our server was new and had a huge section of tables, so while he was very nice, it was pretty slow service. One coworker didn't get to eat since he had to get back for a meeting. 

We started with fried green tomatoes & gator appetizers. The server said it would be enough food; it wasn't. Four fried green tomatoes & a small plate of gator came out. While the apps were delicious; the portions were very small. We ordered a second gator appetizer. The flavors were there but the portions weren't. 

I had the soup & half sandwich with voodoo fries combo. I opted for the crawfish bisque and catfish Po boy. The soup was very good. The Po boy was very greasy. While I understand it was fried; it shouldn't be dripping with grease. 

No one raved about their food. I'm not sure I'd go back.

We ordered red beans & rice and Gumbo soup. I don't think they gave us gumbo soup because it looked like beef tips with lots of gravy which was so salty. The red beans and rice was not tasteful either. We should've taken a picture of the 2 most disgusting meals that are an insult to the state of LA. Please just stop making food and just shut down.
We have also eaten there at least 2 more times within 2 years and it's just terrible and seem to have gotten worst.

Clean restaurant, pretty attentive server, and pretty good food. Everything was slightly above average but nothing too exceptional. 

The flatbread was a little ton heavy for my liking but I really like the fish of the day that we got. Yuuuuuum
Annoyingly poor service and subpar food for the price point. Seems like a tourist trap on the same level as a Hard Rock Cafe. Avoid.

Dined here on a Saturday night with a party of 6.  Nice atmosphere with live jazz in the bar area.  Service was mediocre at best. I started out with the Gumbo as an appetizer.  It was very good, but the rice was noticeably undercooked.  The table also shared a charcuterie board.  The prosciutto was cut at least 1/8 inch thick (everybody knows that prosciutto should be paper thin).  I had a pork tenderloin for dinner that was perfectly cooked and delicious.  I would give this place another try....I think they can do better.

I've been here twice within 1 week and it has instantly become one of my top 5 favorite restaurants to visit. I'll break down my joy below..

Food: Great! I've been to New Orleans, so I wasn't shocked by some of the offerings since they do seem to try to keep to traditional NOLA foods. The only thing (which they do mention) is that the spiciness is adapated for the Northern palate, so it's not as cajun as you might expect. The best? The red velvet bread pudding changed my world --- seriously, just try it out.

Atmosphere: I love the look, feel, and vibe of this place. It's inviting, jovial, and a lot bigger than you'd expect. I was shocked by how large the inside was. They also play live music in the bar most nights. The only issue was that the one band was incredibly loud and my second visit was near the front of the joint. They allowed the band to continue playing loud and we could barely hear eachother. We even told them about it, and the waiters seemed to agree, but nothing was done. While I appreciated the music, it's still a restaurant and not a club.

Service: Great! Both times it seemed that the waiters enjoyed working there and were nothing but nice. 

Price: They are a little expensive. You can get by with a cheaper tab if you stick to their flat breads (starting at $9) and desserts, but you'll definitely end up paying at minimum $15 (most above 20) a plate when you're considering entrees.

One of the best places when it comes to live jazz! They have live jazz 3 times a week and it's ALWAYS good! Their wine menu is also great, the decor is lovely, and the service as well! I gave it 4 stars only because the food is not that great! It's good but I wouldn't go there specifically for the food!

Food was good not great but the service was awful. I don't even know our servers name because we hardly saw her. Large party for a bday and two meals came 10 mins after everyone else's. No apology. No manager came by. We had to ask for a lot of stuff. 4 people in our party work in a restaurant and usually hook up the servers but we all agreed it was unacceptable our service. Thank goodness my meal was good. Oh and they brought out the bday cake when half of the party was gone and dishes still on the table. It wasn't completely terrible service but a large party of 15 should have more than 1 server on it. Management really needs to train staff on proper steps of service.

Big time Bummer.  This would have been my fourth time going to NOLA for lunch and the first time that I have eaten at the tables as opposed to the bar-top.  We got in before the lunch-rush hit and were seated quickly and in a friendly manner.  Our waiter was quick to ask about out interests in food, take our drink order and walk is through the menu.  Service was good, so that wasn't the issue, the issue here was the food.

I ordered the Chicken Po Boy Sandwhich with a fruit salad instead of fries.  The whole meal was a disappointing, I only ate it because I was hungry and I didn't even do a good job at finishing my plate.  The chicken on the sandwich was dry, not oops it was grilled too long fry but oh dear me this might get stuck in my throat dry.  From there it was a series of unfortunate events.  The bread wasn't up to par with past sandwiches had and I stand by the thought that the bread to content ratio for the particular menu item is skewed in the favor of the bread.  The sausage was good but there was not enough kick to salvage the palate.  I can't remember if there was tomato or lettuce or any other veggie in it mostly because the biggest bummer overpowered the whole entree--the mustard.  It was there in dollops and it wasn't good in its own merit adding to the dryness of the whole sandwich.  Lastly, I chose the fruit salad in lieu of fries ... it was warm.  Now I understand if it's at room temperate in an air conditioned setting like the dining area ... but it was hot kitchen room temperature and biting into it didn't release cooler juices that might have survived the onslaught of the ambient heat in the back.  So that was a big bummer.

I hate that I didn't like the food because my first three times were very good experiences.  When I do return, I'll have to try a different lunch entree since I don't want to risk another Po-saster.

My boyfriend and I went down to PPG ice rink to celebrate our anniversary, we wanted to grab something to eat before hand but weren't sure where to go. The sign for Nola stuck out to us so we decided to try it. Excellent food! I'm not much of a spicy food person, that's all him, so whenever the waitress said it was a Cajun restaurant I was unsure if I would like it or not but it was perfect for the both of us! Mildly hot for me and nice and spicy for him. The waitress was helpful, friendly, and attentive. I tried frog legs for the first time and was not by any means disappointed! Really cool atmosphere all together, and reasonably priced especially for the quality of food. Definitely going back!

I went to nola last night for happy hour. Cheap apps (under $5), $1 gumbo a d $1 red beans and rice a drink specials. All were very good and different. Most was not as spicy as I would have assumed! Food was quick and good. Tried the alligator bites and they were very unique and tasty ! Worth a try even though they were not on happy hour.

Food was good but services was not up to bar. I was dining with friends and we were ordering a variety of small plates. We were from out if the area so we aaked what the happy hour specials were. He got annoyed and only gave us some of the details and we had to inquiry about more. He got annoyed when we would order something.  He barely checked in and got annoyed if we had any comment. Another bartender talked to us and she was much nicer !

If the food hadn't been as good and we hadn't driven 2 hours to try it, I would have left because of that guy.

I just...wow. It isn't often that I get to enjoy a meal that leaves me content to the point that I don't have the words to describe the level of nirvana I've reached. But my long overdue first visit to Nola managed to do just that.

It admittedly took me way too long to finally eat at Nola's - when they opened I was a broke college student, when I graduated I was a broke graduate, and then for a while I honestly was more in the mood to try the many other new eateries we've seen in the last few years. But finally, they were open and I was craving something different. So a meal at Nola it was.

I came here with my family, and between the four of us we sampled a decent chunk of the menu as we traded a couple appetizers and meals between us. After that I'm pretty convinced you can't go wrong with anything here. I loved absolutely everything I tasted. Our appetizers set the perfect tone for the meal - the Catfish Croquettes simply couldn't contain any more meat or stuffing, while the Fried Green Tomatoes were the freshest and richest I've ever tasted. And my Gumbo Ya-Ya struck me as one of the most unique foods I've eaten, and was full of rice, chicken, and okra - yum! 

Even better, after salivating over the appetizers the main courses continued to impress - we sampled the chicken and dumplings and Pork Tenderloin. The first dish contained dumplings that had to have been made fresh and by hand, they were so good - although they paled in comparison to the flavor of the tenderized chicken that came covered with butter and vegetables. But my favorite dish of the night had to be that Pork Tenderloin - the meat practically melted in my mouth, and every bite of marinated pork gave you an amazing explosion of flavor, especially when you piled your fork high with the vegetables and sauces served with it. 

What I'm about to say is probably the understatement of the month - but Nola = YUM. And for the most part, the service was just as fantastic; while I wouldn't have minded a faster pace at the end of the meal as we waited for our checks and boxes, they did provide us with plenty of water and kept our tables clear of empty plates throughout the meal itself. It's probably fair to attribute the slight slowdown to the fact that Nola is just very popular and always busy. I'll admittedly have to remember to give myself plenty of time to enjoy a meal at Nola in the future, just in case, so that I'm not late to my post-dinner plans - but it'll be extra time well spent as far as I'm concerned!

My friend and I ducked in here Saturday night for a bite and drinks before the ballet...and the main reason we went is because it was too cold to wander around looking for a place to eat.  We should've braved the cold...drinks were ok, I liked my Cajun Martini which had a little kick of jalepeno, that's why it gets two stars instead of one...the catfish appetizer was tasty but very small portion to share, and I was really looking forward to the Shrimp Po Boy since I haven't had a good one in years (in Pittsburgh)...well, it's mostly bun...and slaw/tomato 'filler' ...the bun was tough and cold, and the 4 shrimp on top were heavily breaded and not too tasty...I ate one off the top and sent it back.  Definitely not a $14 sandwich.  My friend said her burger was just "ok"..and she was never asked how she wanted it cooked...it came medium rare.  So with four drinks, a burger and appetizer our bill was $70.  With lackluster service (waiter was not very friendly), and the kitchen's inability to get even a simple 'signature' sandwich right...I'll never return.

Heard great things about NOLA. Decided to go for lunch. The waiter was non existent until he decided to come over and tell us their card machine is broken and we can't leave until it's fixed bc no one can pay yet. I'm sorry, im on a lunch break and can't sit around while you trouble shoot something. Now everyone eating is getting angry he legit vanishes. Had to go up to the bar where they said you can leave us your credit card number (no thanks) so I ran to get cash out. They requested everyone's contact information for the owner. The owner called half of our group to apologize and mail a gift card and never called the rest of us.
The Gumbo YaYa and Red Beans & Rice were excellent. The jazz band was very good (cohesive). I can't wait to come back and try the entrees.

Tried this based on pressure from the group I was with. I am generally wary of restaurants in touristy squares. We shared a whole bunch of apps and mains amongst the group. All of the fried bits as starters were good. One plate had a pork shank that was really good. Mains included quail and the hanger steak. Both were tasty.  Was it an epic culinary experience? No. Was I glad we went there? Yup. The food was good enough and it was fun. The good food, unpretentious atmosphere, good beer list and great service all came together to earn this four stars.

The food here varies in quality by a very large amount. We had 4 dishes in total, the fried alligator and catfish were ok, but the jambalaya and margarita flatbread were god awful. They both had extremely strange tastes, and eating them made me want to throw up. Prices aren't cheap either, and the portions are very small.

Stopped in for a late lunch, sat outside with our dog.  The service was excellent, our waitress Olivia was super friendly and cheerful .  The app, Fried Green Tomatoes were the best we ever had, that includes the ones from New Orleans.  Super crunch and fantastic spices with a sauce that's to die for.  My wife had a chopped salad with chicken.  The salad should have been chopped a little more, plain Iceberg lettuce, chicken was so so and the hush puppy croutons was a total miss. I had the Shrimp & Grits.  The flavor and plating was spot on!  The spic had the right amount of heat, the shrimp was grilled to perfection.

It was a Saturday night and I wanted to go somewhere different. I'd heard about this restaurant and Market Square is always lively on the weekend so we chose to go here to start the evening off right.

I walked in Nola and was immediately transported to New Orleans. The music was lively and it felt so cozy inside. We got a table in the back where you can see the open kitchen...pretty cool! The service was great and the drinks...my my my. Wow. Amazing! We split appetizers of fried green tomatoes and a crawfish flat bread that was made with a really yummy olive tapenade. Both apps were very good. I can't wait to go back to try their entrees among other things.

Very delicious. Highly recommend the fried green tomatoes. In fact you can't visit NOLA and not get them. I still crave them on a daily basis. The food is tasty and the portions are filling. The drink prices are normal. Over all a very enjoyable place.

Last chance! NOLA is one of the few places that take reservations on Sunday for an early dinner. They were very responsive and put my party of 10 at a great quiet table. That was where the service ended. It took forever to get our drink order and even longer to take our food order. It was not busy and there appeared to be plenty wait staff. If you have never been to real New Orleans, you probably think that the food is authentic .... not even close and the quality of the preparation was poor.  Even though we commented to one of the waiters that the service was slow, no one even tried to make us feel better about our dining experience. Maybe they don't need the business. Won't be back.

Stopped in on a Friday night after work for happy hour and dinner. The place was packed but we had reservations for a party of 10. The service we received was phenomenal even though the restaurant filled. The food was the best Cajun food I have had outside of New Orleans. Our entire group feels that this place is The best new restaurant in Pittsburgh. Bravo to owners and chef . Highly recommend it. If I could give this experience 10 stars I would.

Not only was the food amazing, but the service was wonderful! We went on a Friday evening around 7:30, and I do suggest you make a reservation to be safe. I highly recommend the Duck Mac Daddy, which is duck Mac & cheese. It was very rich and filling but my favorite menu item. We also got the fried green tomatoes as an appetizer and they were cooked perfectly, and were topped with a very delicious Cajun cream sauce. I would definitely save room for dessert. Kira was our sever and she was attentive, charismatic, and fun, but she never once was overbearing or got in the way of us enjoying our meal. Overall, I would say a great dinner place or just to get drinks and apps!
The bartender Shane was a friendly gentlemen. The food and service were phenomenal. Shane's energy kept us here all night. It was a great experience.

Me and my boyfriend shared some gumbo and a sandwich/salad combo. The flavor in this food was very unique to most places I've been and impressed us both. We loved the Cajun salad, each bite had something new that we didn't notice before! Also a very nice atmosphere and decor.

Came here with a group. It was very lovely in the back room , the decorations were cool. The music was some sort of strange 90s/2000s station where they were playing blink 182, self esteem by the offspring, I just wanna fly, and some other odd tunes to hear at a place that was charging $19.00-$30.00 per dinner entree. 

The other reviews were right. Don't come here unless for lunch, its way overpriced for what you get, and it's not that novel. 

They're often out of the thing you want, for example, my friend wanted to order stouts, they were all out, he then tried to order two other beers, all out. My other friend wanted the sidecar cocktail.  All out. It was disappointing.  

We had a big group, but it took over an hour for our food to come out.  One of the 3 main servers that was helping with our group was nice, the other two were visibly angry that they had to help our group, so it felt like anyone in a group shouldn't eat here unless you want to be resented by the staff.  

The food was subpar. Not awful, just not great. I got the $19 chicken and dumplings, where the crispy sage leaves were the best part, overall, just some charred bird in the tiniest bit of gravy. My partner got the margarita flatbread, which had lemons on every slice. It was interesting, but not great. My friend who got the catfish wish the cornbread soufflé let me have some, I thought it was very good, decent seasoning and flavor, but small portion. 

The gendered bathrooms also didn't seem well tended too. The stalls were out of toilet paper. 

All in all, there are better restaurants in the square that'll treat you well with good food and good service. Go to them.
Really great food.  Fresh and unique.  It was a nice change!  Service was slow, though.

With my office in the PPG complex, I really love this little market square at downtown Pittsburgh. DC has our parks, but I wish we had something like this where we can sit. It feels quite European. Anyway, we wandered around looking for a lunch spot and found this place. The lunch price looked pretty reasonable so we decided to just go with it. 

Both my coworker and I decided to get the half sandwich with fries and a soup. I had a French onion soup and the pulled pork sandwich. Sometimes with these lunch deals the sandwiches are so small, but not in this case. It was a good portioned half sandwich, plus a full side of fries. Oh god their fries are so good, like the Cajun fries at Five Guys since it's covered in spices. My French onion soup I didn't like much though. All the cheese kind of gooped up together in the bowl and it was hard to eat. I hate having to bite down on stringy melty cheese like I'm eating noodles. My coworker had the gumbo and the turkey cuban and he said it was really good, and filling. 

Being a New Orleans food, the food wasn't very spicy. But our waiter told us that they don't do it as spicy as true Cajun food, because I guess most of their customers aren't used to that amount of spice. 

Great lunch spot with their lunch deal. I was definitely way too full after this lunch. I just can't resist them fries.
I stopped by for happy hour 5-7. The crawfish flat bread was tasty and the fried pickles were delicious. Service was nice. I also tried the mango captain white daiquiri. Very nice

My pulled pork Po Boy was good but arrived completely cold. I had to send it back and wait for them to bring me another. My husband ordered the shrimp Po Boy which came with exactly 4 shrimp. They were large, but it looked scarce. It was an average experience. Too bad, we were so excited about the restaurant.

Found ourselves in search of food at 10pm, and we came across Nola.  Decided to give it a try, and we were so pleasantly surprised!  Menu is filled with unusual southern dishes including catfish, alligator, and frogs legs!  My party opted for lighter fair, being so late, but the portions were much larger than expected!  I had the chopped salad and added chicken to it.  Such delicious flavors!  And it was topped with a HUGE chunk of blue cheese! Plus had hush puppy croutons.  One of my friends had the French onion soup and was full about halfway through it.  The other had a flat bread pizza, she customized it a bit, but the waiter forgot that when he put the order in.  Told us that he goofed and had sent it back, and promptly brought out the corrected order.  The service was wonderful.  Also had really good water and supplied each table with a glass bottle for refills.  I highly recommend visiting this restaurant if you're in Pittsburgh!

Great atmosphere, food & service! atmosphere is a little loud & more of a bar vibe than restaurant, which we don't mind (and while making reservations the man I spoke with on the phone made sure to point this out & recommend a seating spot for us!) although this may have had a lot to do with the band playing. The wait staff were all very nice & well trained on the menu (my husbands a VERY picky eater) side note: if you are a picky eater too there IS a "bar menu" they do not serve you if you sit in dining area. Try the fried alligator, it was absolutely delicious & the sauce served with it was fantastic! Will be going back!

Beautiful decor and ambiance. Very accomodating staff and courteous. They will prepare the food as you ask them and there is a vegetarian/vegan menu.  Had a nice team with my group of 10 that were promply seated!

This is a charming little restaurant in Market Square. We went on a weekend and had to wait quite a bit to get a table. It's a fun atmosphere with a Southern flare. 

The item that I would recommend was the frog legs. I didn't absolutely love the texture of the meat -but then again I'd never tried frog legs before. But I could rant for days about the sauce it was served in. It was probably the most delicious "masala-y" dish I'd tasted in a while and we were literally licking the bowl clean.

The french onion soup, on the other hand, was quite salty and too cheesy and overall not really worth ordering.

If I come back here, it'll be for the frog legs.

This place is located in a centralized location in Downtown Pittsburgh. There are many options to choose from but this is the only Cajun place in the area. I hadn't tried cajun food before so I was super excited to try this place. I came right after lunch rush hour so we got seated right away. The waiter was quick and made recommendations. I ordered the Jambalaya which had shrimp, scallops, chicken, and sausage! It was super yummy with its tomato spicy sauce. I recommend this plate when the weather is NOT hot. The plate was super hot so it was hard to enjoy. Either way I recommend this place.

Went to this place a while ago when it first opened.  It's a good attempt at New Orleans dishes, but missed the mark a bit. Frequenting New Orleans on a regular basis, I know what good, southern creole food is about. I ended up sitting next to a guy at the bar who was from New Orleans and he agreed. 
Did have the beignet dessert and it was a very good attempt. Nothing beats cafe du monde, but this was a pretty decent dessert.

So, the atmosphere is nice and fun and the drinks were good. The services wasn't great, but I think the server was new or overbooked. My real issue was the oysters. They don't know how to shuck them--they were all shriveled and mangled and there was no water in them. On top of that, they were warm, so I have a bad feeling they were not stored correctly. I'll update in two days if I get sick.

I was expecting New Orlean food .It was none of that .We ordered a plate of chhese and meat .I do better job at home and even presentation was not appealing .
We ordered Jambalaya .It was not spicey and full of Ketchup and very pricey for the amount of food ..It tasted like a prefrozen and reheated food .
We also ordered Cjun fish .It w3as not so bad ,but vegetable dish with it was terrible .
For the price you pay ,it would not be on my list of Pitt restaurants to visit,even if I was not paying .It seems to be busy ,I guess most people do not know NORLEAS food

Was in PBurgh for a conference this week and stopped by this place for lunch in the Market District. I had the turkey Cuban and some red beans. I will have to say I was pleasantly surprised. Very tasty, fresh ingredients with a little kick. So much food. Seriously, go for the half sandwich. It was a ridiculous amount to eat.

Service was great and fast- easily doable in an hour. Price was reasonable. A little jealous we don't have NOLA in Columbus.

Food was not worth the price. Our server is under equipped to deal with the public. He should have one table and that table should be robots and that one table should not be ours. He forgot a drink order and claimed to not have heard my food order. He is untimely to refill drinks and seems absolutely insulted to write an order. If I was the manager, he would be retrained or doing something else. I actually had server envy as I observed several servers enjoying their job.

Food: Caesar salad was made with ice berg:
Pizza lacked flavor outside of the green tomatoes
Shrimp and grits is actually a grit type cake. Disappointed from the shrimp and grits 3 years ago. 
Salad featuring Brussels sprouts was fortunate to have 2 Brussel sprouts in it. 

Music was good. Just the right combo and the right loudness. 

Nola is a no thanks!

For those who work downtown, NOLA seems to continue to be a well-liked lunch spot...  personally, I never initiate that decision.

While the food is alright, I definitely never feel its worth its cost  [for ~$12 you can get a lunch combo (choose 2-2 of soup, salad, sandwich, fries, etc.)].  In addition, the consistency is definitely not there and every time my food comes out, it looks and tastes like it's sat under a head lamp for at least 10-15 minutes.

The one consistent item I landed on was the Chicken Po-Boy, but alas, on my last journey here they updated their menu and did away with it!

Haven't had a chance to come in the evening for live music, etc., but it seems like it may have some potential for a decent date spot.
Food was 4 star and $$, however due to lack of good hosting and service they get overall 3 stars ! I will be coming back to try their sandwich menu next time! Try jambalaya entree it's really good !

We went for happy hour on a friday evening which runs from 5 until 7. We wanted to sit outside as it was a nice day and were seated quickly. After that our service was not very good. Our server had 4 tables outside and im not sure how many inside she had but she wasn't very helpful, and didn't check in on us very often. We weren't initially given the happy hour menu but a manager brought one to us when we asked. We ordered 4 food items on their happy hour. The brussel sprouts, and catfish fingers were my favorite. I would definitely go back for the catfish. I did not enjoy the pulled pork sliders or mac n cheese as much. The mac n cheese was tasty, but quite salty and it looked like the sauce had split as it was a bit oily. All the food was nice and hot. All in all, it was a pretty good experience. I would like to go back to try some cocktails and listen to some live music!

Went to NOLA for a mid week lunch retreat.  Ordered the red beans & rice for a starter and the blackened catfish for my main.  Both were excellent but had to add some extra spice with the bundle of hot sauces.  The fish was topped with a green tomato relish that included fresh jalapeños, onion, and corn!!!

This place was aight. I hated the music choice due to it being a New Orleans inspired place but whatever. I got the shrimp and grits. The flavor was pretty good. A nice smokey kind of flavor. I don't know if I would say this is a place you need to go to but if you stumble into this place with two drinks in you will be pleased.

Not NEW ORLEANS But....there food was good and service was amazing. The alligator was pretty decent and the sauce that came with it was absolutely amazing. (It was a great appetizer). I ordered the jambalaya which had a very very heavy tomato base and two other people with me thought it was spicy(I love spicy, but didn't feel it was). The size of the portion was perfect but I was not expecting more sauce than rice.

I occasionally meet friends for lunch here during the work week. I have turned into a creature of habit with this place, and usually end up with ordering the lunch salad, sandwich, and fries combo with the Nola salad and the southern chicken cordon bleu sandwich. These items are always dependable, and the fries are delicious and crunchy. I love goat cheese on salads, and there are even a few chips on top for added crunch. The sandwich is a very generous portion, even though it is only half of a sandwich.

The drinks look yummy, although I have only ordered beer on tap. The beer on tap list is decent, although I would enjoy more regional selections since the food is all about bringing New Orleans to Pittsburgh.

I love sitting outside when the weather is nice. It's easy to get a last minute open table reservation for lunch, and that way you accumulate open table points while avoiding waiting for a table. When it's too cold to sit outside, there is ample room in the dining room. There are multiple rooms, and lots of room at the bar as well.

Excellent food and service and definitely the right flavor.
On the strong recommendation of an acquaintance, I went to NOLA for the first time yesterday. I was eating lunch by myself and I asked to be seated away from the bar. I was given a nice little booth/table in view of the open kitchen. Pleasant atmosphere. 

My server (Lynette) was exceptionally courteous and attentive. She was knowledgeable and could sell the heck out of the menu and upcoming special events, but she did it in a very conversational helpful way - If NOLA mgmt is reading this, please know you've got one heck of a server and seller in her!

I started with the crawfish bisque, then a catfish and greens entree.This entree had a long mouthwatering description on the menu that I have forgotten; but I will not forget this meal for quite some time. It was a delightful blend of comfort food and fine cuisine. Execution was flawless.

After another couple of visits here, I have to give this place a downgrade. I was excited when it first opened, and may have been a bit overly enthused after my first visit. The food is good...A-OK is actually very apt...but not of the caliber that you'd find in New Orleans. The waitstaff likes to let you know that the chef spent 5 years in New Orleans, and some of the food coming out of the kitchen here reflects that. There are just too many misses for it to be 5 or even 4 star.

We were in for their Mardi Gras celebration last night, and they were offering a few specials for the occasion, which I took advantage of, as the regular menu is not large, and I've had most everything that I want to try on it already. The duck and oyster gumbo was very good, with tender duck meat as well as delightful cracklins, and whole oysters swimming in a full flavored broth with long grain rice. Thumbs up on the gumbo. I was delighted to see crawfish etouffee as a special, as this really belongs on the regular menu of any Creole restaurant. When you get this meal anywhere in New Orleans (I know, I know...I keep harping on the whole New Orleans thing. But this place is claiming that badge, so I feel justified in making the comparison), it comes as a kind of saucy stew served over long grain white rice. Maybe a sprinkle of parsley. The chef here served it over puff pastry with asparagus and house cured tasso. When I saw that description, my heart sank a little, but I ordered it anyway. I understand that he was trying to dress up the dish a little, as people outside of Louisiana might not think the simplicity of this dish warrants a $24 price tag. If I base my review on just the etouffee alone, it was not very good. Not enough creamy sauce, not enough flavor. The addition of the puff pastry and aspargus pulled it down more. The puff pastry was just in the way, and the asparagus, while perfectly cooked, did not belong with the other elements on the plate. The house made tasso lacked depth of flavor, and seemed like just strips of ham that they had put some dry rub on and aged. This whole dish needs work. We skipped dessert last night as we had 2 on our last visit, and they were both disappointing. The NOLA cocktail, which is bourbon, simple syrup, absinthe and lemon juice, had not enough bourbon flavor and too much lemon. I also need to mention service. We had three servers come to our table and say the EXACT SAME THING. One would greet us, let us know that they and another two servers would be taking care of us, ask us if we'd been here before, and get a drink order. By the third time it was beyond annoying, and my vocal partner let them know. I've said it before...team service needs to be three different people doing different tasks, so the customer isn't burdened with repetition. Again, some things here, like the redfish, flat breads, gumbo and the porkchop, are very good. Others need work.
Great food and cool decor, but terrible service. Servers and bar staff were rude and inattentive, took an incredibly long time to get anything
Great vibe.  Great service. (Maybe a little too chatty).  Great music.   Food was only good not great.  Appreciated the attention to detail but my Jambalaya was only OK.

Ups and downs.  Went on a Saturday night relatively early.  We were excited to get some fried alligator appetizers.  They were out.  Ok, stuff happens.

We were with a party of 10 (pay attention...that'll come back up) and warned that they would add automatic 20% gratuity (ok, no biggie) and would not split the check -- no problem.  A bit tacky, but ok.  We brought a pen to split it ourselves.

Everybody was happy with their entrees, and the soft-shell crab on cucumber (?) gazpacho was OUTSTANDING.  All's well.

Server brings the check -- we're ready!  Pen comes out!  Paying with 4 cards, we split the bill and give her the 4 cards -- put the balance on the last one to cover the tip.

Not sure what the problem was, but there was a minor meltdown.  She ended up grabbing the bill saying "Ugh, forget it...I'll just split it" and then came back and threw each of our bills back down on the table.  No exaggeration.  I've never had a bill envelope slammed on the table in front of me.  

Guess she got her 20%....so who cares, right?

Look, it's not that hard to split a check for a group.  It's basic restaurant etiquette.We would have let you know up front.  But it wasn't "allowed."

We left slightly offended with a bad taste in our mouths.  I'm....not sure we'll be back.

This is a tough review. A friend and I went to NOLA for dinner this weekend and we had the pierogies for appetizers and I had the jambalaya while she had the shrimp and grits. The appetizers were great but our entrees were SO spicy! 

Both my friend and I love spicy foods so it's not a matter of us having a low tolerance for heat. Both of us have eaten at numerous restaurants in New Orleans before and the entrees we both had were so spicy that it bordered on uneatable. That said, it had the *right* spices, just too much of it.

My friend had been craving shrimp and grits and she said while she was managing with the heat, she found the portion of grits to be lacking. Most people would expect a bowl of grits with the shrimps in the center but NOLA makes a grit cake in the shape of a rectangle for its presentation. There was some kind of bacon over the top that did look good. My friend said there was way too much of whatever sauce the shrimp came in so when she finished, there was still a significant puddle of it left over that felt wasteful but she thought it did taste good.

My jambalaya was tomato-based and came in a small cast-iron cassoulet-type bowl. A hearty serving and piping hot temperature-wise too. Flavorful shrimp and scallops were on top while embedded in the rice were sausage and chicken. Trust me, this was a good dish but someone went seriously overboard with the seasoning. Even the next day I ate some and it was still spicy to me and it gave my friend heartburn. I wanted to be a fan of this meal but unfortunately I'm not.

Beignet's, jambalaya, shrimp and grits, Nola burger, milk punch ice cream cake: all excellent!!! My only quibble was that the waitress was somewhat inattentive. A few of the accoutrements that we asked for we never got, and had to ask for more drinks a couple of times. They were busy but she spent a lot of time talking to other employees in the bar. As a place to eat we lovex everything we got however.

Great drinks! The Cajun martini is my favorite! The alligator appetizer is delicious was a little overdone but ok since we were mainly there to have drinks and it was late. Other times I've been here the food is really great! Nice atmosphere and live band tonight so we had a good time.

Nola is awesome because of its take on the "mardi gras, New Orleans" atmosphere. The food is definitely what you would expect it to be from alligator to jambalaya.. I personally favor the flatbreads but that's just me. The staff overall is pretty friendly. The outdoor seating is nice when the weather is right and the inside is dim lit and cooler vibe.

Nola is pretty legit when it comes to a late night three course meal. I came to Nola on a Monday night around 8:30 and it had a perfect ambiance. I honestly couldn't imagine a cajun/creole restaurant with a better feeling. Nola is as close to New Orleans as you can get in our great city.

As far as it comes to signature cocktails, I sampled two. A Gin Concoction that looked more like a white russian, but was very refreshing at the same time. And since I, myself, felt like such a amateur (girly) drinker, I had to order something with bourbon in it after. So, I went with something that tasted and looked a lot like a Manhattan, but had a much smoother aftertaste. 

For an appetizer,  we delicately chose the crab gratin, which came with six perfectly toasted pieces of french baguette. The gratin was perfect with melted cheese on top, and it wasn't filling, like some other gratin based meal that makes one feel full after a few indulgences. You could see the gigantic lump crab meat on every bite.

The entree was a bit expensive for a filet mignon at $33 for a plate of glorified steak, asparagus, and mashed potatoes. But damn, it was amazing. The steak was the best cooked medium-rare filet mignon I've ever had.  The mashed potatoes were just like something your grandma would make. 

For desert, my date and I went with a chocolate mousse, with a chocolate cake middle layer, and on top was a roasted marshmallow, which was the size of a softball. After taking two bites, my mind and stomach threw in the towel. 

The whole entire meal was perfect from start to finish. The only reason I'm giving Nola four stars and not five is because of the price. I definitely felt like Nola charges way too much for the type of establishment they portray themselves to be when you walk in and sit down. Just a thought.
THE CRAWFISH MAC AND CHEESE. Their happy hour has great specials and the food is a great take on Nola cuisine.

Excellent gumbo. Jumbalaya was ok.

Good selection of beer.

They had live music and so it was really loud. Had no shout to talk. The bad was good but just not time to chat.

Excellent. Authentic New Orleans food as good as I've had outside of New Orleans. The place looks, feels and tastes like New Orleans. Definitely worth a visit when in Pittsburgh. Also a great location right on Market Square.

Beignets almost as good as Cafe Du Monde. Po'Boys were on perfectly baked French Bread. The oysters and shrimp were perfectly seasoned and fried.

Outdoor seating seating available. 

A taste of New Orleans in Pittsburgh of all places.

Talk about world problems. It's tough to write a negative review for a restaurant experience during which you actually enjoyed your meal. HOWEVER, after three times trying NOLA it's time for an official 2-star review.  In my past experience here, the service has been very slow.  Fine, really - as long as you have the time to spare.  Yesterday's visit was no exception.  

Our party of 6 arrived to a mostly-empty restaurant between 12:30 and 12:45 for NOLA's brunch.  Three members of our group ordered the special of the day: Banana Bread French Toast.  Sounds amazing, right?!  Well, it was, but I'll get to that.  The food took a while to get to our table and when it did, it was mostly...wrong.  The three who had ordered the special were served the regular French toast instead; which was a big departure from the advertised special.  The server was very apologetic and explained that due to a glitch in the system, the regular French toast was ordered instead of the special, but that the situation would be remedied.  And each of them did finally receive the amazing banana bread French toast eventually; but not after eating pretty much all of the original French toast since the replacement order was slow to arrive.

In the meantime, another friend leaned in and, very innocently asked, "Is Eggs Benedict supposed to be cold?"  Alas friend, it is not supposed to be cold.  She sheepishly mentioned this to our server, who really was quite upset at the entire spectacle on our behalf, and he took it to the kitchen immediately.  What returned a few minutes later was Eggs Benedict.  Her previous order of Eggs Benedict, to be exact.  The same bit was taken out of the one muffin and the previously beautifully poached eggs, were now a yellow mess of luke-warm goo on top of each muffin.  

The good news is, the company was stellar and we mostly laughed through the entire visit.  We also felt bad for our server and knew full-well that most of this was likely not his fault.  He mentioned that he would be speaking to the manager since the situation was "unacceptable."  The manager did stop by our table to ask how everything was going.  We mentioned that there were a few "glitches" and left it at that.  He asked if the only issues of the day were with the French toast.  We explained that another dish arrived cold and appeared to have just been reheated in the microwave, to wish he replied "we don't own a microwave." Meooow.  No one pursued the issue and all of us were given 50% off our respective bills - even those two of us (myself included) who were served their food without issue (Shrimp Clemenceu and another who ordered Fried Chicken & Waffles).

Soooo, NOLA. What do to? The food is pretty good. The service is pretty slow. And, up until the aforementioned manager paid us an odd visit, I might've given it another go.  But that was just...well...weird.

Wow was really looking forward to trying this place out while we were in the Burgh and I am sorry to say I was not impressed. The decor and service were great but the food was OK at best. The alligator was all breading, the fried green tomatoes were lame and my blackened fish was so dry it turned to dust when I touched it. Another person at our table got the same fish and it was cooked the same way which was too much. The scallops and noodles with cheese was by far the best dish at the table but even that lacked scallops. The alcohol selection was good and the cocktail I had with milk and bourbon (can't remember the name) was very tasty. Unfortunately the next time I am in pittsburgh I will be dining elsewhere.

Christa is the man! She was my bartender for the evening, she also works at Perle right next door.  http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=V7uS5US4oTf-S9u36HJQCQ&q=perle

Any who I had the frog legs and also gumbo.  I love me some gumbo and I like that Nolas is keeping with Creole tradition and has okra in their gumbo. The flavors of the gumbo were on point , smokey, and spicy with sausage, veggies and as I mentioned okra and rice.

On to the frog legs. I would have preferred my frog legs battered and deep fried...but none the less they were still really tasty. 

Nola's is open on Sundays too, which is a bonus for me since I work Downtown on Sundays, and it's just a short 10 minute walk from Grant street. I now have a swanky place to enjoy a cocktail or two after work.

The entire front of the restaurant opens up to the square which is lovely in warm weather and brings in a lot of sunshine and it's great to see the owners working the floor and checking on you that for me is some quality service.

Cute restaurant located in Market Square. Valet parking and wait staff in ties makes the place look a bit more upscale then it really is.

Only split a shrimp appetizer here but it was good. The beer list was awesome and you can even order New Orleans style drinks like the Hurricane.

Get there and snag a table outdoors  for people watching, this place is frequented by ridiculous drunk middle aged women. I saw a woman take her shoes off grab onto a parking attendant and start running across Market Square.

Oh where to begin.  I have been to Nola's three times and have had three different types of experiences.  The first time was for lunch in 2012.  From what I can recall it was decent.  The next time I went to Nola was for brunch over my birthday weekend.  The Big Y Group, in case you didn't know, offers birthday dinners/lunch or brunches around your birthday if you sign up online.  You should sign up it's a good deal and you can use it at most of their locations.  So on to Brunch.

We made reservations.  Not needed, I believe we were the only people in there at 11:30 on a sunny Sunday in August.  We had a waitress who was training another girl.  We ordered some beer and OJ to make beermimosas , try it if you haven't.  It's not just for hipsters kids.  I ordered the Eggs Trivette, Toasted Challah Bread, Crawfish Tail Meat, Black Pepper Bacon, Crystal Béchamel, Over-Easy Eggs, Served with Fruit Salad.  The wait was a little on the long side being that we were dining completely alone, but not over-the-top long.  Our food came out and I did enjoy the eggs, but didn't taste much crawfish.  The sauce was rich but nothing said Cajun to me like I would have expected.  Still a tasty dish, but the fruit salad it came with was pathetic.  There was a mix of pineapple which was mostly core, =inedible, some dried up pieces of cantaloupe and honeydew and a few slivers of watermelon.  Who put this together?  It was clearly old and really disappointing for a restaurant that is supposed to be more upscale.  However, overall it wasn't bad, and had I written my review 3 months ago they would have received 3 stars, but I didn't.  This leads me to our last visit, which occurred over Halloween weekend approximately 5:30 in the evening.  


We headed to Nola's this time for drinks.  I was really in the mood to have some rye whisky or bourbon as I enjoy the finer things in life.  We secured a spot at the bar and was perusing the drink menu.  My husband really likes German style beers, and I noticed they had St. Pauli Girl on the bottle menu.  Mind you this is listed under their beer list and priced at $4.50, I encouraged him to order it even though he never had it since I've been known to dabble in the sampling of fine wines and beers and found it enjoyable in the past.  I went with a SAZERAC $10 BULLEIT RYE OR HENNESSY | HERBSAINT | PEYCHAUD'S BITTERS | ESSENTIAL LEMON OIL. 

 Side note.  This is Halloween weekend and everyone working there is in costume.  For the love of God I don't know why places encourage or make their employees dress for Halloween but I am off topic. 

 Anyhow, there were a couple of bartenders and waiters and waitresses kind of loitering at the bar, I am assuming since it was early and there weren't many people in the place yet.  I get the male bartenders attention and we order the pre-mentioned drinks.  He makes mine first then sets a non-alcoholic beer in front of my husband and walks away. Said husband notices a few moments after that this is not what was expected.  I was kind of upset, because I feel that drink had NO business being listed on the "BEER" menu if it is not alcoholic and doesn't come out and clearly say that.  Listed next to its name it says n/a.  Well I don't know what n/a meant maybe the restaurant should spell out Non-alcoholic, or put it in the section next to where you order soft drinks.  I was pretty upset, feeling that the bartender should have said something to warn us and just really wanted to get him another beer.  Well now the bartender is at the end of the bar talking to Donald Trump (waiter) laughing it up and I am yelling over excuse me.  Well bartender makes a half assed attempt at coming down to talk to me.  He starts to walk toward me as Donald must have said something that beckoned him back as I was only in mid-sentence of explaining that we weren't aware the drink was not alcoholic he dips back and turns to Trump laughing at whatever line came out of his mouth.  I said quite loud oh that's nice walk away while I am talking to you?  He just kind of looks at me and Matt says never mind I'll just drink it it's not that bad.  It was that bad and I am not only upset that the bartender didn't alert us of the non-alcoholic (in my world N/A means not applicable, but in this case is very applicable) drink, but that he found it more important to laugh with the other employees than speak to a customer talking to him.  To top it off I heard him insult a female employee about what she was wearing to a very negative tune when another female employee told her to ignore him.  It was very disrespectful.  I fumed the rest of the short visit and asked for the check from the female bartender.  I didn't want to tip anything but knew they probably all split tips so I did so sparingly.  Epic fail, can't think of a reason to return.  I will use my birthday coupon at another Big Y Group restaurant next year.

I had the blackened catfish, which was fine.  Not great, but fine. My mom got the jambalaya which was hands down the worst I've ever tasted, by a good margin. It was basically mushy, fishy shrimp and scallops and rice in tomato paste. Awful. The wait staff was great I'll say, but the food really lacking.

Took my mother here for dinner and the one bartender/server gave me the impression that he couldn't be bothered. We had to seek him out for refills and he seemed bothered by us wanting to order food. Definitely wasn't a welcoming atmosphere.

WOW. I was seriously so impressed with NOLA. My friend and I decided to go here for dinner on a Thursday night on a whim. I'd heard pretty good things about the place so I was excited to give it a try. We were seated quickly (the place is a lot bigger than it looks from the outside) and our server came right over. They were fairly busy but not packed. I was feeling somewhat confused by the menu because I am NOT familiar with Creole food at all, so I was very happy when our server asked if we've been there before and helped us a lot with the menu when we told her we hadn't.

She was extremely familiar with the menu, and even things that weren't actually on the menu but could be done by customizing a dish. She recommended the jambalaya and the scallops mac daddy, which is a scallop mac and cheese dish. My friend got the jambalaya and I got the scallops, and we opted for a flatbread pizza as an appetizer. We were so happy with our choices. Everything was absolutely excellent. And I can't stress enough how great the service was.

The manager came over and asked how our meals were and about our experience in general, which was nice of her and we told her how pleased we were.

As a disclaimer, yes it is a little pricey but in my opinion the food and the service is well worth it. And it's in a great location in Market Square. We will certainly be back!!

Today's visit for lunch was just ok.  Not as good as previous visits for lunch and dinner. I attended a lunch outing with my team.   Our server Kelli, was great, she was patient and attentive.  I ordered the mushroom panini and voodoo fries.  I also ordered the gumbo appetizer as a starter.   The gumbo arrived a short time later, and it was ok, but the base tasted just a little bit burnt.  It was good, but had a bitter aftertaste.  The panini sandwich was a bit of a disappointment.  The multi-grain bread would have been better had it been toasted correctly.  The bread had been buttered and not left on the grill long enough to toast properly, which left the bread greasy and soggy.   Also the portabello mushroom was much smaller than the bread slices, so there was LOTS of bread and very little mushroom.   I'll definitely return to NOLA, but would definitely order a different item.

It's fun and the food is good. But don't expect authentic New Orleans cuisine.  It's a festive atmosphere, and there's live music on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday.  Our service was fairly good. 

The dining room is quite expansive, and there's also a long narrow room that has the bar.

We were excited by the happy hour specials listed on the sign out front, but disappointed those were only available at the bar.  Why make rules like this?

Overall, the food is good, but rather pricey for what you get.
I love Nola...great service and great food! Consistent after 6 years and the new happy hour was fantastic!!

Fairly descent Cajun/Creole food, but quite pricey.  Considered more 'upscale', which I find funny.  Good drinks, great location and has charm.  They have live entertainment and their brunch is worth checking out. Drink specials and they are strong :-)
Visiting the Pittsburgh area found this place on yelp. The food was good. Fries was cold and my Gumbo was cold too. SERVICES WAS VERY BAD and it was not busy  it was on a Thursday at 3:00.

I really enjoyed my dinner at Nola. We ordered some reasonably priced wine and a meat and cheese plate when we first sat down. I would absolutely recommend the meat and cheese plate. It was simple but delicious and huge for the price. I had the jambalaya which was also very good. Our server was very courteous and made some good recommendations. My only complaint is that they were out of quite a few things- such as scallops and the fish of the day- and the kitchen seemed to be annoyed at our substitutions for the out of stock seafood. We heard one chef or cook admonish our waitress for allowing us to substitute catfish for scallops in jambalaya. If you are out of multiple menu items, it is only reasonable to allow some leeway with otherwise inappropriate substitutions. We did get our catfish but the chef could have been a little more accommodating to the server's request. Overall though, it was a really great meal.

Good Cajun food in the heart of Pittsburgh Market Square. It's cool how they've tried to recreate a NOLA French quarter-like look for the exterior, and a NOLA Bourboun street-like electrifying atmosphere inside. I hadn't imagined the place would be so huge before entering, but thankfully that meant there wasn't any wait for lunch on a busy Christmas weekend.  Loved the ambience and the decor inside, cool yet classy. Our waiter let us know that they were out of a couple of the menu items due to the Christmas craziness. No issues, the menu still had a number of tempting options. I stuck to classic Jambalaya, while my husband opted for the NOLA burger. Both of them were spot on. I loved the complex flavors of the jambalaya and the generous portions of meat and shrimp. 
So what's not to like about this place? The service. Well, I'm not sure if it was a one-off experience for us, since other Yelpers seem to be happy with the service. I understand that it was Christmas weekend, but the painfully slow service when the restaurant was half-empty is not quite acceptable. The waiter came to take our order minutes after we arrived, and when we said we needed some time to look through the menu, he went on a mini-vacation. Once he finally took our order, he went on a world-tour..our food took forever to arrive. No explanations for the delay, not even an update, our waiter seemed to really hate our table. I had to ask others for water, ketchup, etc. I could see the staff all around us very lively and sociable, and if I could interact with any of them, this could have easily turned into a much better dining experience.

What a cool place. The live music brought my friend and I in on a Friday night. We sat at the bar and our bartender immediately greeted us and was very inviting and friendly. 

My friend had a couple glasses of wine and I was in the mood for beer, so I tried hop gator by Abita Ales. Being the beer nerd that I am, I noticed that a lot of their featured "seasonals" were not very seasonal at all- at least three of them had release dates in early spring . BUT hop gator was quite good. Smooth and it was served in a fancy little beer glass. 

We weren't planning on eating but one of the bartenders gave us a menu and I couldn't help but look. I saw fried green tomatoes and had to order them. I also ordered the New Orleans style BBQ shrimp because I was curious how their seafood was- being a New Orleans themed restaurant and all. 

Yum. The shrimp was amazing! Perfectly cooked and seasoned! The sauce was amazing! The fried green tomatoes were good as well but not the best that I had. Wouldn't order them again. The shrimp alone is why I will come back and try some more New Orleans goodies!

Typical go to after your dreaded day at the office. Every spineless group of sheeple flock here during happy hour. Your drinks will be poured by your stereotypical xenophobic hungover bag of bones behind the bar. There's a great opportunity for a decent pub in this location, but for some reason, they chose to fill it with a bunch of robots hungover from yesterday's bullshit. Thanks but no thanks Nola. Keep slinging Bud Light drafts to Pittsburgh's finest
