2 stars for the amazing kitchen work. If you can sit through the inhospitable staff, order from the food menu.... if it's provided..... CHEERS!

Pretty good southern food fare! Reservations are a must, otherwise there may be a long wait, although last time we waited around 20 minutes when they had told us it'd be 45-60 minutes. There was a $5 off for joining loyaltree's iphone app and scanning the QR code inside the bill folder. So yay for unexpected and extra discounts.
The food was a C for us but I am a New Orleans regular. So I can't be easily moved with creole/Cajun cuisine. BUT the drink was great and the staff was AWESOME. so the experience was balanced.

We went to NOLA on a Friday night when we had tickets to a show in the cultural district. I had the crispy alligator bites to start, and the jambalaya for my meal. The aioli on the alligator was excellent - I was eating the crunchy fried bits that came off of the meat just to scoop up the sauce. The jambalaya had an excellent taste. As someone who has been to New Orleans, I can safely say that it tasted _nothing_ like actual New Orleans jambalaya, so if you are looking for authentic creole, you will be disappointed.  The jambalaya was very tomatoey, and not nearly as spicey as I expected. And, there were just 2 pieces each of shrimp and scallop on the top, and none mixed in with the rice. However, although I would not characterize it as authentic, it was still delicious. The blackened chicken and spicy sausage that was mixed in with the rice was really good. I would eat here again, and if I did, I would probably get the jambalaya again (again, the food tasted very good, as long as you don't expect authentic). On a side note, I mentioned to the server that we couldn't linger too long, because we had theatre tickets, and he told us that if we could show him the tickets, we could get a 15% discount. So that was a nice bonus, and if you come before a show, be sure to bring your tickets with you.

I had dinner at NOLA on a Saturday evening before a Pens game with my son. Our 5:15pm arrival allowed for no waiting and a relaxing meal with plenty of time, (almost an hour) to walk to Console Energy Center afterward.

   We received quick and friendly service. The waitress was very helpful with her suggestions. We enjoyed a Shrimp Po Boy and the NOLA Burger both served with fries in Voodoo Dust which were a big hit!! 
  
 The French Onion Soup is VERY good and also a great value as it is topped with gruyere cheese. A definite must try and worth the trip itself!

  We were both pleased that NOLA was our choice for our pre game meal and I will soon return!

Went here on St Pattys day. Empty restaurant, but had a good French onion soup and Cajun catfish that was only ok.  Only Pittsburgh knows how to make the BEST French onion soup! Don't know why....they just do!

I moved to Pittsburgh a year ago, and have been a solid fan of NOLA until last night.  

I had out-of-town guests and wanted to show the city off to them, thinking that a dinner at NOLA would be a great introduction.

Well, I failed to reckon that it was Friday, and, further, did not know that the live music was starting during prime dining hours.

What an embarrassment.

We were somewhat removed from where the singer was but, still, it was so loud that we were not able to attempt conversation.  We had much to talk about, but NOLA clearly was not the place.  I know that there are fans of ear-splitting music, but it completely ruined our evening.  After exiting the restaurant, it took us a while to stop shouting at each other to be heard. 

And NOLA, as you may know, is not cheap.  At the risk of setting off the ¨If it´s too loud, you are too old" crowd, I wonder if NOLA would consider postponing the music until after the time when people are normally eating their meals.  Or toning it down a bit.  

As usual, the food was delicious, the service was great (I have forgiven the restaurant for the time I asked for a pepper vodka martini that came with a layer of ground black pepper on the bottom of the glass) but any enjoyment was destroyed by the painfully loud music.

I would like to come back, NOLA, but...

I've only been in once for lunch but if the rest of the menu is comprable to the blackened shrimp I had, then I can certainly stand by NOLA. Best blackened shrimp of my life. Excellent little salad. Portion wise it was just right for lunch (maybe a bit on the small size but that's how I like to eat). Waiter was attentive and quick with suggestions. Overall a very successful meal. Would definitely try this place again.

I've been here several times and each time, it gets better and better. 

The ambiance is fun New Orleans.  Not trashy Bourbon street, but like if Bourbon street had a classier, older brother.  

The kitchen is open which I love, so you can see them making the food and see what other people are getting - the next time, I'll be having what she's having. 

The food is awesome.  I went here for lunch, so sadly no beer for me, but S had a Guiness and an Abita - a New Orleans beer which is awesome.  I prefer the Purple haze or Turbodog, but he had the seasonal that he liked. I got the spinach and strawberry salad with an add on of catfish.  It also had blue cheese - and whoa did it ever!  Tons of the pungent blue stuff - and cajun pepitas.  

Delicious!

Definitely worth it for happy hour (M-F 5-7PM), they have drink as well as food specials. However, the two dishes that I ordered (Cajun cheese sticks and fried Cajun andouille balls) were kind of bland and nothing special, but for $4 each, I can't really complain. 

The captain mojito (also $4), however, was amazing and not too strong! They have different flavors depending on the day and although mine was supposed to be grapefruit, I did not think it tasted like it. Still delicious regardless!    

The staff was attentive and food came out petty quick as well.

Being a native of Louisiana, I find the hospitality and decor a great remider of home. The atmosphere, food, and overall customer service makes this a perfect place to unwind after a long day, or meet with friends. 

For starters  you must order the Voodoo Doll drink (very smooth),  and Red Beans (SEASONED JUST RIGHT). 

Don't judge me becuase I also had the catfish entree and it was great, especially paired with the mashed potatoes. Now in Louisiana we take pride in our food and especially desserts and the beignets are as good as the orginial Cafe Du Monde.  

I love this place!!!

A friend and I stopped in Nola for Sunday brunch! Great drinks, service and cozy atmosphere. The Mimosa was bubbly the beignets were sugary and sweet! I had the Eggs Benedict a cajun peppery smoked pork topped with eggs poached to perfection!

I stopped by here this past Friday evening with my fiance for dinner.  We had made reservations on open table and arrived a few minutes before our time.  The bar and outside seating was absolutely packed and I thought that this was going to be a problem but we were taken into the dining room which was fairly empty at this point (5:30) and thankfully quiet.  The decor of NOLA is pretty cool as it incorporates many pictures and items that make you think of New Orleans like a picture of Cafe Du Monde, Mardi Gras related art and a picture of a jazz band walking down the street,

My fiance and I decided to start off our evening with the fried green tomatoes.  Whenever they came out I was surprised at the size of the tomatoes as they were not even close to be being thinly sliced like I had imagined.  They were breaded in abita batter and sat on top of a base of creole ranch mustard while being smothered on top with cheddar cheese.  The fried green tomatoes ended up tasting good and I thought the thickness of the tomatoes actually gave a good tomato/batter ratio and brought in enough acidity from the tomato that it paired nicely with the savory cheese.  For my entree I decided to go with the Bourbon Street Pasta.  It was a gemelli pasta that had 8 or so fried oysters around the outside and then tasso ham, peas and piave cheese mixed with the pasta and was topped by a single cooked egg yolk.  Breaking the egg yolk into the pasta gave the pasta a little extra creaminess which I enjoyed.  Overall it was a good dish with the salty fried oysters being my favorite part of it.

The bottom line for me is that I will definitely had back to NOLA again in the future.  I am actually surprised that I hadn't written a review of this before as I have been to NOLA many times and have always been satisfied with the service and food that I received.

Food was delicious (based off of the soup they remembered to give me and my parents food. My family and i came in for lunch here. It wasnt busy at all and it took over an hour to get our food. The waiter was fantastic. The cooks in the back, not so much. Although the food tasted great, they were so slow, the waiters were standing around with nothing to do. They forgot the salad I orderd and it took them so long to get me another one (IT WAS A GARDEN SALAD)  I had to request it to go. They also forgot to add the dressing, which the waiter realized and was kind enough to go fill up a container of it for me himself. I would come back again, but only if I have nothing to do for the next two-three hours. My parents had a Pirates Game to get to.

I grew up in Louisiana so I was excited to come across a New Orleans themed restaurant. The server even said the restaurant was approved by the City of New Orleans, so I was quite anxious to try out the different dishes that I've been missing. First of all, I have to say that the ambiance is very inviting. When my boyfriend and I went, they had a live jazz band performing.

While the service was excellent, the food itself was subpar. First, we had the fried alligator. It was ok, but I think they should consider serving blackened alligator instead, because alligator can be quite fatty and frying it makes it even oiler. The frog legs were actually great. Super flavorful sauce. My only complaint with that dish is that I wish they gave us some bread to mop up more of the sauce because there wasn't much meat to the frog legs (of course) and there was a lot of yummy sauce left. We got two seafood jambalayas. Strangely, one of the dishes was lukewarm, while the other one was piping hot. The jambalaya tasted ok, but didn't resemble the jambalaya I grew up with. I think the rice was a bit too mushy and there wasn't any spice to it. We also ordered the crawfish tapenade flatbread. This dish was the worst as the flatbread was soft and mushy, and the crawfish and olives didn't go well together. We had to use utensils for this dish because it fell apart in our hands (as flatbread should not). For dessert, I had to try the beignets. The were the worst beignets I've ever had. I think what went wrong is that they fried the dough and then completely caked the beignets in the powdered sugar. If you let that sit around, then the powdered sugar gets mushy and crusted on, instead of lightly sitting on top of the fried dough. If I could recommend a change, I'd say they should try dusting the powdered sugar on, instead of tossing the fried dough in a bowl of powdered sugar. I have to say though that the housemade sorbets that were oddly paired with the beignets were excellent. Last suggestion to the restaurant is that they should hire a chef from New Orleans. I think that would help a lot. 

Sorry this post is a bit of a rant about what they should change. I don't want to be too down on the place, but I came in with high expectations, and ended up paying a good amount of money for food that doesn't do New Orleans justice. Next time, I'll just save the money towards a plane ticket to NOLA.

Pretty average place. Alligator appetizer was overly greasy, hard to tell what kind of meat was in there. The mains were over-sauced but filling and relatively tasty. A better beer selection would improve things as well.

Last night in Pittsburgh on a Sunday and we were walking the 'Square' to find dinner. Checked out the menu and got our appetites ready. The Mrs. and I couldn't decide so we shared 2 different entrees (one being the grilled chicken and dumplings and I ordered the pork tenderloin). We ordered fries and mac and cheese for our little one. He enjoyed the fries. They're definitely much better than Primanti's! The mac and cheese was a nice take on the traditional kid friendly item with corkscrew pasta in a creamy cheese sauce. 
Onto the good stuff, my pork tenderloin was heavenly for lack of a better description. Ok, it was tender and flavorful in a sweet potato purée. It was delicious to the last bite. My wife had ordered the grilled chicken and dumplings. That was light and delicious and was complemented with grilled carrots and peas. The flavor and seasoning of the chicken was spot on. I had asked for hot sauce. Both entrees didn't need any additional seasoning or condiments! 
For dessert we had the beignets with ice cream. It was made to order and a good complement to a great dinner.
Service was friendly and on target. The food was brought out quickly. All of the waitstaff was friendly, attentive and on their game even though they were closing within the hour. We never felt rushed, and everything was timely.  People watching on the square is a whole other thing to do while you dine.

Based solely off of customer service- I live in Orlando, but my dad was having his birthday dinner at Nola's about a month ago. I called and spoke with a friendly girl and asked if I could send a drink to the birthday boys table and she was more than happy to assist me promptly. It was a busy night for them plus and unusual request so, I was pleased that she was so willing to help!

I've been to NOLA twice, once for lunch and once for drinks and an appetizer. 

I really enjoyed both experiences. My lunch with delicious, I had the Chicken & Andouille Po Boy with a side of fries and salad. I really enjoyed the flavors in all of the dishes! The fries were probably my favorite. 

I couldn't help put love the decorations and layout of the restaurant as well. 

The second time I went my friends and I split a bunch of apps. I was most impressed with the amazing french onion soup (hello, Gruyere!) and Abita Battered Shrimp Basket. 

Can't wait to go back and dine again!

Eager if not expert service (lots of "who gets what dish" when the food came). Mediocre but decent French onion soup (served only wam, rather than hot). Catfish was nicely cooked, but swimming in butter. I didn't so much mind that, being a big fan of butter....however that is, of course, a lazy way to make something taste good.

Service was horrible.  Sat for over a half hour before we got our drinks, after we waved down 2 different people asking to place an order. I typically tip 20% or more.....i will begrudgingly tip under 15 which i have not done in 15 years...service was that bad. Food was good, borderline great. Unfortunately the sevice was do shitty that it ruined the meal.

I checked out this restaurant on a Saturday night, and it had a very lively atmosphere. There was live music at the restaurant and a community market going on in market square. Our food and drinks took realllly long, but the atmosphere made up for the wait. Upon request, they have a separate menu of vegan and vegetarian options. The fried green tomatoes were delishhhh and so was the squash salad. The couscous dish from the vegan menu was below average. The bread pudding dessert was AMAZING highly recommend. Cool place and I would go again :)

Our second visit to NOLA was a long time after our first.  We last came here when NOLA first opened.   What impressed us most the first time, the quality of the service and the food, impressed us once again.  I had jambalaya (again) and my wife had the blackened redfish.  We both loved our meals, even though we took home a lot of them.  Anton, our server was very attentive and evened offered to hold our left-overs until after the show we were attending.  We asked to be seated in the back, away from the bar and were taken to an attractively decorated room off to the side and well away from the noise of the bar.  From my seat, I even had a bit of a view into the workings of the kitchen.  We remarked that the noise level was actually lower than what we usually experience in other restaurants.   We had recommended NOLA to several friends, and the feedback we got from them wasn't positive.  Some complained about the service and  everyone complained about the noise level.  Our seating in the back would explain the difference in the noise level, but regarding the difference of opinion as to the service,  that I can't explain. All I know is that on both visits, service was superb.   We'll try not to wait so long for our next visit!

The happy hour lasts about an hour past every other one in town! Loved the drinks! We had flatbread, stuffed mushrooms and pierogis. The pierogis were ok, I've had better but definitely homemade. The flatbread was good. We were there for appetizers.

This place would have been at least a 4 if I hadn't been to New Orleans last week. My food was pretty good. I got the Jambalaya. It needed a bit more of a kick, so they provided hot sauce, but that's really not the same. As mentioned in the other reviews, the red beans and rice was amazing, and the quail that my brother got was awesome. My problem came with the ambiance, the price, and the beignets. Even though my group was seated in the dining area, the jazz music overwhelmed any conversation that may have been had. We also got the beignets for dessert and they were more cake-y and dense than any other beignets I've had, resulting in a really underwhelming desert. On top of that, the price was a bit high for the quality of food. I would recommend this place more for the bar and music than for the restaurant end.

I have been to Nola twice - the first time as a willing foodie, the second as a prisoner of social graces. The only enjoyable dish here, in my experience, has been the eponymous 'Nola Salad.' It's really a lovely salad - the candied walnuts, arugula and fresh goat cheese are definitely a winning combination.

Unfortunately, everything else suffers from the too much salt, too much grease or too little taste malaise that seems to be the defining characteristic of Nola. Even the jambalaya - their signature dish - was one dimensional and salty. 

So.

Long story short:

Is Nola conveniently located in Market Square? Yes, BUT that shouldn't stop you from going to the other excellent restaurants that are in the same area or nearby (Eleven, Sienna). Extra star for the yummy salad.

My work group has been here a few times for happy hours and I think we're all pretty happy with the place. Drink specials are decent and service is fast.

And they have really great happy hour food specials. $1 for a small bowl of gumbo really hits the spot during happy hour.
The jambalaya is great, they can make it as spicy as you like. Paired with a Purple Haze....didn't want to leave.

We have been wanting to try Nola for awhile . We finally made it there last night. I would give this place a HORRIBLE review.  First I had the French quarter chopped salad.  The ingredients listed on the menu made the salad sound amazing. It was absolutely tasteless. The lettuce was ice cold. It literally tasted like ice cold lettuce with a drop of dressing on it. I then had the crawfish flatbread. Once again the Ingredients on the menu made the flatbread sound delicious...... Once again tasteless.  The service was okay but the price was outrageous for how tasteless the food was.  My fiancée had the jambalaya.  The jambalaya was good.  But it definitely was not good enough to pay $29 dollars for a small bowl of it. I would definitely not go back to this restaurant.  There are many more over priced restaurants in Pittsburgh that serve much better food. Thumbs down!

Excellent brunch which includes a starter, a cocktail and a main dish for $25.  A very different menu and it was great.  I had e cajun pastrami and eggs which were served with Lyonaisse potatoes.  Everything was awesome.  Flavors were very different.  Also had the grits - yes grits - and the apple crepes.  My son has the pumpkin waffles and fruit with granola as his starter.  I highly recommend.

As good of a restaurant as I have ever eaten at. The food was amazing, the service was excellent. I ate here two nights in a row and it was amazing both nights. First night, Shrimp and Grits and an amazing waiter named Chris. Tonight, Venison Chili, Seafood Jambalaya and a free beer. I'm eating 2500 miles away from home and feel like I'm having dinner in my dining room. Too cool.
Terrible terrible food. Oversalted, overcooked, the fried alligator had more breading than alligator, the beignets were flat and not crispy at all. Skip this one.

far and away the best food and atmosphere of the 3 restaurants in this , for lack of a better word, chain.

Trully authentic Creole cuisine.  Loved the po'boy

Went here with my boyfriend when we were on our way home from vacation. Saw that there were great reviews on Yelp & all those reviews were spot on! 

We got sat at a high top table in the front of the restaurant, and had ordered drinks shortly after. The manager came up to us about 5 minutes later to ask if we wouldn't mind moving to their dining room because the table we were sat at was reserved. We didn't mind, especially when he offered to pay for our first round of drinks!! 

We ordered the gator bites for an appetizer, which were amazing! Neither of us had had gator before, and it defied our expectations! The breading and seasoning was so delicious. For our meal, we both ordered the gumbo and a Shrimp Po Boy sandwich to share. We got the gumbo first and it was so simple, but had tons of flavor!! There was tons of okra in it, which is one of my favorite vegetables. Then came the Po Boy! Which is huge, btw. The shrimp were easily the size of tennis balls, lightly fried, with a slaw sauce and I'm pretty sure their bread is homemade. To top off that sandwich, were easily the best French fries I had ever had. My boyfriend & I are French fry junkies. We both agreed this was #1 on our top French fry list! 

If you are in this area, I definitely recommend Nola, if you like New Orleans type food. I wish this restaurant was closer to where I live so I could eat here all the time!!

NOLA has been on my list for quite some time and I'm happy to report that my first experience was pretty good overall. I went with a group so I got to sample everyone else's food too!!

We started with the frog legs and fried alligator. I preferred the gator to the frog legs. 
I had the shrimp and grits, which was a massive portion. It was good, not as spicy as I expected and slightly on the greasy side, but I ate around the puddles. We also had the steak frittes, seafood jambalaya, red fish and the cat fish. No complaints from the peanut gallery regarding their meals. 

I'm anxious to go back and try something new!
Great food but slow slow service !! They think they are at its peak in terms of upscale dining scene in pittsburgh , but they have a lot to catch up !!

I went to NOLA for lunch with 3 colleagues. I got the salad and sandwich option, the NOLA salad and the catfish po' boy, which also comes with their fries. The po' boy is usually beer battered but because I can't have certain fried foods, the server checked with the kitchen and suggested that I get the catfish blackened. The salad was great, I always get it in my combo meal, and the fries were hot and perfectly seasoned. The blackened catfish on the sandwich was so good, exactly what I wanted. I enjoyed the sandwich overall but I think the sauce on it was just mayo and this made it bland. If there was a spiced aoli on there that would have made it outstanding. This is why I rated this meal as a 4 instead of a 5. Service was great and I really enjoyed my meal.

On a busy night on the square it may be your only choice...food is sub par.  Rice in my gumbo was hard/uncooked....the catfish meal was $20 & it wasn't anything I'll ever remember, other than it was $20. The beignets are a total joke, not even close to a beignet...if you're lookin' to find NOLA food in Pittsburgh, you won't find it here. Gross sticky tables too.

We tried their jambalaya and po-boy shrimp. The jambalaya was modelately spicy but kept good flavor. Shrimp po-boy was de-licious!!!!! They have a special cole slaw that was tangy and went well with the meals we got.
There was a piece of paper in my $30 duck dish. They took the plate away, didn't bring anythig else and still charged me full price for it. Need I say more?

The service is great (been here 2 times), the food is tasty, and the atmosphere is appropriate for the theme. I had the jumbalaya, the NOLA salad with scallops added, blue crab etouffee, & bananas foster mousse. Everything was great. My favorite was the etouffee. The jumbalaya was baked in a iron skillet and any sauce that should have been in there when served was baked out. I like it with some sauce running around. Therefore, I picked out the meat and left most of the rice. But the shrimp and especially the scallops were awesome.

To our embarrassment our stinger was made with green creme de menthe.

The pasta was just loaded with oil, loaded!

The apps would have been tasty but sauces and sweet coverings ruined them .

Service  is good , the band is festive.

I had a great time at NOLA!   It's different and fun and definitely a place I would go back to.   We had a reservation after spending a few hours at the PPG ice rink.  We were seated promptly in a little table near the kitchen.  The décor is New Orleans style, but a curious mix between casual and fine dining.  Overall, I thought it was pleasing.  The place is way bigger than it looks for the outside.   

All of the food was great.  I highly recommend the alligator appetizer, the catfish entrée, and the seafood mac and cheese (it wasn't called that, but you'll be able to figure it out).  Our server was friendly and prompt.  Definitely a good date night place.  I'd go back.

We recently for a client meeting there and had a reservation for 14 people. Were seated timely in their upper level room. The server was knowledgeable and knew the menu by heart. I ordered the Steak Frites et Salade and was not too happy with it. The fries were on the mark and were freshly made and the salad was average, but i was hugely disappointed with the Hanger Steak (Medium) what was chewy and cold as if it was lying for a while until they prepared everyone's order and ready to serve. The ambiance was average and the carpets could use a makeover too.

I love cajun and creole food. LOVE IT. I know this isn't New Orleans and what can you expect from a Pittsburgh restaurant offering cajun food. Well, how about some crawfish??? Is that too much to ask? None on the menu. None available off the menu. Zero. Considerable disappointment. Oh, ok, you can get excited about the novelty of alligator bites. I've had alligator in every form (including ribs) all over the Gulf states and in a dozen restaurants in New Orleans, and these are nothing special. They're good for an experience and to tell everyone you ate alligator but how much joy do you get from that. You won't order them twice.

I'm a jambalaya afficianado. NOLA's is complelety unremarkable. Wait, I take that back. It's remarkable in it'soddity - they use 3 whole chicken wings for the chicken component. Messy and not a good call. And where's the mudbugs? Jambalaya needs crawfish!! And where's the ettoufe? Nowhere, that's where. 

I love Abita beer and they have  a good selection. But that's about the most positive thing I can say about the place. Sure, it's a novelty. Yeah, it's a great place to take your out of town guests for someplace new and different. But if you ask me, it's not a place I'd recommend. Go once. You'll agree with me.

2nd Visit - Drinks and Appetizers.

I highly recommend the Pork Belly / Corn Bread appetizer.    It was extremely satisfying with my adult beverage.

I don't know, it's a nice place, but I really felt that the options were kind of limited, especially for vegetarians. It's also kinda pricey and I paid about $12 for a salad that didn't leave me satisfied.

My wife and I both had excellent meals at this restaurant. I had the grilled catfish which was perfectly spiced over mashed potatoes. I asked the waiter to make s suggestion between the catfish and the voodoo pasta and he recommended the catfish. Great choice. My wife had the special which was a seafood pot pie and she raved after every bite This dining experience was so good that I sought out the manager on the way out and thanked her for the way her staff performed.

As out-of-owners we went to Nola on the recommendation of a Pittsburgh local and we were not disappointed. Glad we were not deterred by the noisy bar scene at the front of the restaurant, however, because the dining area was well insulated from the noise level at the bar.  This is convenient to Heinz Hall for those attending a concert, and the Cajun style food was well prepared.
Great cocktails. We went for pre dinner drinks I had the blackberry old fashioned which was great but all the cocktails looked good.

It pains me to only give NOLA 3 stars, but I have to.  As a former resident of Baton Rouge, I expected a little more from this restaurant.  That's not to say that the food isn't good - it is good.  It's just not as Cajun/Creole as it should be.

I started with the Abita Amber (which they have on tap!).  We then ordered frog legs and the alligator to start.  Both of these were solid.  The frog legs seemed fresh, and the gator was not chewy.  The sauce that came with both of these dishes were tasty with a little zing.

I had the seafood mac and cheese, which had lobster, crab, and crawfish in it.  The flavor of this dish was great, and the cheese bits that got darkened under the broiler were to die for.  Please note, though, that the locals down in NOLA don't eat lobster...

I'd love to see an etouffee added to the menu.

We came here for a non-Valentine's-Day Valentine's Day dinner on the 13th (because I like to avoid the actual-day rush at restaurants), and this was a fantastic non-traditional romantic dinner.

First things first, you can't come here and not try the alligator.  Our waitress recommended it, and I'm so glad she did.  Imagine a cross between popcorn chicken and fried calamari with a spicy aioli dipping sauce: that's what the alligator was like.

We also loved our entrees, but be warned, they are gigantic portions.  I got the cajun pork chop, which was easily enough for two meals, and my husband got the scallops mac daddy, which looked like two pounds of homemade gourmet mac n cheese.  Flavors were great, and I loved the little bit of spicy kick in everything.

NOLA also has a sizeable specialty drink list, so we tried a few New Orleans-inspired cocktails from that.  They were healthy pours, and a decent price.  I'm not much of a bourbon drinker, but their Bourbon Street Blues cocktail was pretty good.

Finally, you have to spring for dessert, and you have to get the beignets.  They're like a donut and a funnel cake all in one, loaded with powdered sugar, and served alongside a trio of yummy sherbets.  I mean it: no matter how much you eat beforehand, save room for this dessert!

NOLA also hosts live music and special events (like an upcoming Mardi Gras celebration).  They're located in Market Square, but they also have free valet parking if it's crowded and you can't find a spot for your car.  We loved it, and we'll definitely be back (for more alligator).
Terrible service. Sat outside and the waitress was extremely rude. Left before we even ordered because it was so bad

Very disappointed in this visit. Went with friends to watch the live music. Hostess told us the bar tall tables were open seating so we waited for one then when we went to sit down, were told there was a list, but that we could have the next one opening up.  Waited again, sat down, then were told that it was promised to someone else too. We finally got up and left. If there's no seats at the bar where they give you great service, best to leave because the hostess has no idea what's going on.

Three stars for our waitress, alone! She was absolutely amazing! But the food took entirely too long to come out, was really expensive, and REALLY mediocre. We came because of their "vegan menu," but they only had rice available for my vegan coworker. Both of my boss' steaks came out overcooked. The jambalaya tasted spicy, yet lacked flavor (think El Monte canned tomato paste mixed with raw peppers). My other coworker had the shrimp and grits and had to force herself to finish, as it was over-seasoned. I hope our phenomenal waitress takes her talent somewhere that deserves it! I would not come again, at these prices.

If you can only eat one dish and have one drink from their menu... get the fried alligator and the hurricane...NOTHING on this menu matches up to them! I have tried several other dishes on the menu including the flatbreads, seafood jambalaya, shrimp and grits etc...these are all good... but these guys sure know how to make some mean Fried Gators!! This dish is sooo delicious that if you go in for a late dinner (ie after 8:30 pm) its ALWAYS sold out!...i have only gotten to eat it twice of the 8 times I have tried ordering it...Sigh!

The restaurant is conveniently located at market square in downtown and is bubbling with life....especially during the weekends ...it is hard to find a seat even at the bar. They usually have live music on the weekends which adds to the ambiance...

This restaurant is like a piece of New Orleans in the heart of Pittsburgh...Worth a try!!

I stopped at Nola for dinner and drinks while on biz in Pittsburgh...and YEZZIR this is a good spot!  If you go, you gotta try the Scallops Mac Daddy...good stuff!  Had some live music poppin and drinks were flowing.  Right in Market Sq so overall nice atmosphere.

Nice place. In the heart of downtown. I can say that it is a nice local bar :) with a great food. My friend got an alligator, for me it was a little bit fattie but it tasted good. I got a salad with a catfish which was very good. Large variety of beers and full bar. Highly recommend for tourists like us :)

(Happy hour review only)

I've only been to NOLA for their Happy Hour... and I've got to say I was very happy during that hour!  Their drink options are average, eh, not bad....BUT food prices blow me away!  Gumbo for $1.  Rice and bean, also $1.  Half off their flatbreads (margarita was great, the other one was way too oily).  It's probably all I will ever want from NOLA.

I will be interested to return on a lunch hour next.

I love NOLA, we've been here twice. The selection are always pleasing to our large crew. A nice selection of cocktails and daily specials. My only complaint is to have the live music go on a little later.  I love the live jazz music but a 7 pm reservation becomes  a yelling match for conversation. Will definitely return .. note to self ask for medium spice on the jambalaya.

Loved it. Went on Sunday afternoon and everything was great. The staff was very friendly, the bar/restaurant was very clean and the food was fantastic. I got the fried chicken and waffles with chorizo gravy, and it was exactly what I'd hoped for. My friend got the club and she enjoyed it, but I don't think it was anything to write home to mom about. However, we shared the beignets and they are AWESOME. I didn't want to share after I tried mine. They were like fluffy little pieces of heaven, floating around in a sea of powdered sugar dreams. Seriously, get the beignets. Will be back for sure.

I let sister Stenquist pick this one out. I gave up perusing Yelp from my Hotel bed and we just stumbled into market square hoping something would be open before 11am on a Saturday. Oddly not a lot opens before 11am in Pittsburgh. And alcohol before 11 and after 9pm seems to be frowned upon. And makes me frown.

But as we sipped our mutual coffees, she decided on this place since it didn't exist when she used to live out here. We were seated super fast and the service was super. Fantastic waitress and not an ounce of complaint. I was just really bummed with how bland and flavorless everything tasted. 

We split an order of fried green tomatoes. Which, are huge and have a ton of additional decoration on top that doesn't seem necessary. Sprinkled cheese with greens is weird. Not to mention the batter just didn't seem right. I just like simple, normal sized battered green tomatoes. Frown. But that wasn't where I was even terribly disappointed. The sandwich and soup or salad combos both failed. At least, my sister's sandwich was better. She got a creole pulled pork and I stuck with a creole cordon bleu. It was charred chicken with bacon and swiss cheese. So freaking dry I could scrub the dishes with the chicken. There wasn't any sauce on the pieces of bread either that seemed to have come fresh out of a cooler. Her rice and beans tasted obviously canned. Both of our sides of fries tasted like mesquite wood chips. I ate about 2 or 3 of them and gave up. The best thing I had in all pure honesty was the side salad. Because I would find it incredibly hard to eff up a wedge of iceberg lettuce. I hate to give this a bad review because people seem to enjoy it. But I really like to eat and I ate about only half my food.

Awesome place! Abagail made great recommendations. Ordered the Eggs Bene app, when she saw the egg wasnt runny enough she took it back without any hesitation and it came out perfect. The star of the show was my Pork Osso Buco, it was the best put together dish I have ever had. The pork was cooked perfectly to fall off the bone. The blacked eyed peas, roasted brussels sprouts and spinach blew me away. The depth in it was mind blowing, citrus and garlic tones on it. It worked. I will be back every time I'm in Puttsburgh. Abagails service was second to none. Thanks.

Maybe I am just not a fan of Creole/Cajun food. I thought that the food was just OK. The waiter was nice and brought out our food and drinks at a good pace. The carpet and walls seemed a little dirty to me.

This is the best cajun food I've had since visiting actual NOLA.  I've been wanting to try this place since moving to the Burgh and my only regret was not trying it sooner.

From the front (and even in the bar area), it appears fairly small, but once you enter, there is a large dining room way in the back.

We visited on a Friday night without a reservation, so we waited about 15 minutes before a table in the bar was available.  Despite being very crowded, service was fantastic and friendly.  The downside was that it was VERY loud.  Especially once the band started.

We had the gumbo and rice and beans as our appetizers.  Both were fantastic and had a little bit of a kick.  The grit cake and the shrimp and grits were both amazing.

My one complaint is that the prices are quite high.  The food is high quality and the environment great, but $25 for shrimp and grits did seem a bit extreme.

I will be back!

I'll be fair, I only tried one dish, but at the moment I'm annoyed - and starving.  I ordered shrimp & grits, which is a lunch entree.  The other plates I could see around me looked generous, big sandwiches, lots of fries, or a big bowl salad and half a sandwich on the side.  My entree was more expensive than the sandwich plates, and  it came with ... nothing.  I got a gigantic plate-bowl with about half a cup of grits and four shrimp in the bottom.  An appetizer sized portion at best, and no bread, crackers, salad or anything else.  The grits were bland and runny, and the shrimp was overcooked and too salty.  Basically, this "main course" was a small cup of mediocre soup for $20.

I think the restaurant was okay. It's in the market square do it's a bit self important . The food is okay, I don't get an authentic NOLA vibe . True southern way crawfish and pull them apart, it's just what we do and how we prefer to eat crawfish. 

I had a wedge salad and asked for no tomatoes. I got a wedge salad with tomatoes. No biggie, I just picked them out. We then had to ask for silverware, not that the runner cared. We also had to edit for napkins. This is not including the long wait for service or the okay food.

Overall, I'd go back just not in a hurry.

Second stop here in a second city, have dined here in Downtown Dallas as well. To its name obviously bring New Orleans flair, but traditional Pennsylvania incorporated as well - with delicious pirogies. Not a veggie eaters paradise, but the pirogies were stuffed with creamy mashed potatoes, really a hit - and the NOLA salad was fresh, with crisp produce. Service was pretty good, not over the top, not any complaints. Right inside the market square, still easy to get to PNC Park afterwards.

Oh my gosh Nola - now when this place opened everyone talked about it and loved it and raved and I never went. Finally this weekend I got the chance to experience and I thought it was great. The wine selection (which was what I wanted) was great and to be honest I just wanted some pasta so when they turned out to have pasta I was a happy camper. I very much recommend the dish I had, the Pasta Pontchartrain. There was a little kick to the sauce and the meat and crawfish in the dish were perfect.  Everyone in my party had a great meal - I'm pretty sure the grit cakes were called the best meal my dining partner had ever had. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable and the environment was fun -I'm going to go ahead and highly recommending trying this place.

Taste nothing like food in New Orleans. Maybe they can fool people in the area because they are so far from N'Awlins. My appetizer came out waay after my entree. However, the waiters especially the host guy were VERY friendly. Great customer service here, poor food

Great spirits from the TOULOUSE MARTINI (Vodka, Ginger Snap, Pineapple Juice, prickly pear Granita, Mint) to get me groove of thethe NOLA music in the background.

Once my food arrived, the smell of the deliciousness as I heard the sizzling of my Jumbalaya (Carnaroli Rice, Wild Caught Shrimp, Sea Scallops, Chicken, Andouille).  Nicely seasoned and the heat from the spices was just right.  I could tell when at the end of my dish I was snifflin' a little.  That is usually an accurate indicator of good dish.

To finish of my meal, I had to end the night NOLA style...an order of Beignet, which came with 4 pieces and two scoops of blackberry sorbet.

I was completely satisfied and will definitely be coming back for to try the Shrimp and Grits.

Went here for lunch on a weekday when downtown for a conference. It was just before 1 and I was able to snag an open seat at the bar. I did a half-sandwich and salad lunch combo, which also came with fries, for $12....I have a hearty appetite and I couldn't even finish it all. Fries and panini were hot, and salad was crisp and not overly doused in dressing. Lot of vegetarian items, too. The bartenders were very friendly. I don't get downtown often so I was really glad to try out NOLA and will be back!
Knowledgeable and polite service and good food. Had the salmon and etouffe. Good size portion for lunch, great flavor as well. Glad I had the chance to try this place while here on business.

Great meal, Great atmosphere. Fast, friendly service.

Met a friend for a late lunch, and it was perfect. By 2 pm, the lunch Rush was gone and we received fast service from a team
Of servers. I had grilled catfish, she had seafood jambalaya, both dishes were excellent. Best part was the sweet&spicy martini, mango and jalapeño. Yes please!

I go to NOLA for one main reason...the Seafood Jambalaya!  I has huge shrimp and scallops and just the right heat.  And I can handle that heat.  Andouille sausage and chicken are in there, too.  I was stuffed and didn't even finish it all!  
Oh, and don't forget to have a cocktail.  I had the Cajun Martini.   Wow, that one is spicy hot!!  It's really tasty, especially mixed by Troy the bartender.

Super slow.  
Came with a table of 8 for brunch and were seated promptly since the restaurant was essentially empty.  Orders were taken and it was a solid 50 minutes before our food arrived.  When we asked about the timing we were given some lame excuse about how there were orders in infront of us, but like I said the restaurant was empty when we got there...

Food ranged from awesome (French toast special) to passable (most everything else).  Service was polite engaged and friendly, but somewhere between the front and the kitchen there were big problems.

I won't come back.

I will try this place again.  I'm convinced I got the wrong thing.

One thing though that was very very right was the fried alligator appetizer.  OMG it was great.  Perfect.  One of the best appetizer's I've had in awhile.  

I got the pulled pork po'boy and I think this is where I went wrong...it was more or less just a pulled pork sandwich.  Which, when looking back, I"m not sure what else I had expected, so I think its my fault.  Next time, I'll get something more New Orleans-y.  Great atmosphere, seated right away, very pleased over all.  My husband thoroughly enjoyed his burger.

And scanning their code on loyaltree gets you $5 off your check.  Nice.

Walked in and sat at the bar. At exactly 8:43pm on a Sunday after the Steelers home opener, we were told they just had last call. Bartender then promptly walked away. The don't close until 9pm on Sundays. I understand we were close on our timing, but we were denied dinner prior to closing time.

The food was good, but definitely not five star.
We started with the butternut squash flatbread, and something about it was way too sweet. Maybe it was the maple glazed andouille? I didn't care for this dish. The NOLA salad (dinner size, $5) was good, however. My favorite dish was the crawfish tapenade, which is much like a personal-sized pizza. The saltiness from the kalamata olives was nicely balanced by the sour dressing on the abundant arugula.
There was a rather-loud band playing out front (A friday in January, about 8pm) and we were able to get a table for six in the back, without reservations, where it was quieter.

It's annoying that the menu they hand you does not list the vegetarian options they have available; ask for the vegetarian menu. The excuse we were given was that the type would be too small if they added the vegetarian options to the existing menu. That excuse would not apply to the online menu listed at http://www.nolaonthesquare.com/menu.html , but I don't see the vegetarian menu items listed there, either. Weird.

While the atmosphere is good, found the pulled pork bland and the service soooooooo slow - and there is no one here (I wonder why...) If you decide to come here block off 2.5 hours because that's how long it takes to get served for lunch. Next time I am back in Pittsburgh I am going to pass on coming back here.

Meh. I was sick and in the need of some soup or something warm to soothe my the throat.I came across this place and wanted to try the gumbo. I ordered it to go, and had my husband pick it up and bring it back to the hotel. The gumbo wasn't what I expected, the flavor was so so. My husband ordered the fried green tomatoes and a flat bread. Both were gross, the flatbread was lukewarm when he picked it up, he even arrived earlier than the given time. With all the amazing food places in Pittsburgh, not sure why anyone would choose to come here.

I was not very impressed with Nola as the service was extremely slow and I felt the food was average. Lots of fried food to go along with the New Orleans theme but still felt it seemed like traditional American food. Decent prices for lunch though just get there earlier if you are on a time crunch.

We were here for our friend's birthday.  We were sat at a table in the back room which was very cute.  The food was very good.  As for the service it wasn't very good.  I'm not sure if it was because we were slightly off to the back, but we had to ask for refills multiple times and had to wait pretty long for our condiments.  The server maybe have just had an off day.  

The food and drinks were great, but the service was best described as, "meh", haha.  It won't deter me from going back, every server has an off day.

We tried this spot over Memorial Weekend. The waitress was very friendly and described the menu thoroughly. In her words, this was cajun creole inspired food "with a Pittsburgh twist." I'm not exactly sure what that means, but I think that gets them off the hook with some of the Bayou Purists here.

We tried the frog legs and fried artichoke appetizers. I really enjoyed the frog legs, but I'm not much of an artichoke guy. I had the gumbo for a soup course while my mom and wife had salads that looked fresh and green.

For the main course I had the shrimp and grits. The shrimp had nice size, texture, and flavor. The whole dish came together well.

For dessert, I ordered the beignets.  These beignets were heavier or more dense than I was used to.  I did not enjoy them as much as I have at the famed Cafe du Monde, or even at a local church fair. However, even bad beignets are still pretty good. 

We were seated near the kitchen, so it provided some nice entertainment and distraction as we waited. We took our meal very slow, enjoyed some drinks, and ordered each course individually.  We were waiting for a friend and never felt rushed by the staff -- but weren't ignored either.

I like their mixture for the hurricane cocktail. The fresh juices add a lot. 

The bar scene up front was very busy and very loud, but it is quieter in the back and more fit for conversation.  The bar crowd was young, hip, and attractive.

They have valet parking; I think it might even be complimentary, if I remember correctly.

Yay it finally opened! Pittsburgh really needed the southern touch and taste! This place used to be 1902. The bar and set up is still the same just revamped. They were serving red beans and rice for the St. Paddy's day opening. I am so excited to come and have some New Orleans cuisine! Po Boys, Jumbalaya, Muffaletta, and crawfish are shown on the very creative menu. Soon, very soon I will be savoring some NOLA dishes.

Food was okay. Had the flatbread, which was a little burnt. The shrimp appetizer was underwhelming. Service was good. Good wine selection. Would go there one more time to try the jambalaya and alligator meat.

A taste of Nawlins on Market Sq? Close...

Although the drink menu was extensive the actually menu was a bit limited and wordy.  I'm all for describing your foods but, to who's determent?  

I had the fried shrimp which was delicious but, became a bit too much about the 5th shrimp.  My dining companions all loved their food and drinks but, would have loved a bit more variety when it came to actual dishes.

We arrived around 2pm on a Saturday during which the Market Square Christmas Village was active so we were expecting chaos but were surprisingly able to get seated immediately. We were quickly greeted by our waitress and learned that brunch was still in session. 

My wife ordered the French onion soup and Nola salad and I ordered the pulled pork po' boy sandwich. The salad was amazing (all ingredients complemented each other well and the amount of dressing was just right)   and the soup was average. My pulled pork was juicy and the voodoo fries were delicious though the onion rings topping the sandwich could have been fresher. 

With tax & tip we were out the door for $25.

This is a restaurant in downtown Pittsburgh with a New Orleans twist. During the afternoon it is a little more casual than if you would go at night. They also have love music on certain dates at night. We originally sat outside but then it started raining. Our waitress was great about finding us a seat inside and making sure we were taken care of. I ordered a cocktail which unfortunately was watered down from all the ice they put it in. If a drink is going to cost $9-$10 I would love to be able to truly taste the liquor in it. 

I ordered the shrimp Poboy with voodoo fries (which are fries that are seasoned). Honestly, the sand which was average - there wasn't anything that made me go "wow!" Or that it stood out. It still was good though! The inside of the restaurant is dimly lit which would be nice for a couple that want a date night together.

I just haven't been blown away by this place.  I've gone there for happy hour and lunch, so maybe all the great stuff happens for dinner, but I likely won't make it back for dinner b/c of my experiences with hh and lunch.  The drinks are good but I'm not impressed by the food.  For happy hour I had gotten the crawfish flatbread and the crawfish was not fresh and had an overwhelming fishy taste and rubbery texture.  While I expect fishiness to some degree on crawfish, it was too much and distracting.  I couldn't even eat another slice of the flatbread after the first few bites.

For lunch I got a vegetarian sandwich b/c this was a few weeks after my hh experience and I didn't want to deal with another bad fish ordeal.  So while the sandwich was fine, it was lacking some flavor - granted there's probably only so much you can do with veggies, but come on let's flavor it up a bit, this is supposed to be New Orleans inspired.  I will admit that the fries were delish and perfectly seasoned.  That was the only highlight of my meal and my experience at NOLA.

The entrance has a very "bar" like feeling with Super Loud music (live band) and people holding beer bottles. at first I was a little worried because I had come here for a relaxing dinner rather than beer and loud music, but the waitress took us to near the back where there was a nice big area with large tables and a relatively quiet atmosphere. It was next to the kitchen. Great quality, thought out food that seems to have been carefully made.  The scallops were amazing in one of the steel pan dishes I forgot what it was called, but overall nice experience.

I wasn't sure I was going to like NOLA initially looking at the menu, but they really surprised me and were fantastic.   I myself had the Jambayla and split a flatbread with some friends and would order either again.
     The service was fantastic as well both as we waited at the bar for a table and during the meal as well.

I went to Nola with my family, being a very loud party of seven.  We walk in and the atmosphere  is phenomenal. Very New Orleans vibe, fitting exactly what they are going for. Great music and great ambiance.   We sat down and met our waiter, William, who is one of the best waiters I've ever had at a restaurant. He was very knowledgeable  and quick, funny and nice and extremely attentive to everything we asked. So after we get settled, we order our drinks and kudos to the bartender who make us some off the menu whiskey drinks that were to die for. And then appetizers. I'm gluten free  so I have the raw oysters. Phenomenal. Incredibly fresh, half shell, over a bed of sea salt. And then when I think it can't get better, he says the special is a tuna dish prepared over a bed of fresh vegetables. I, of course, order the tuna and It was one of the most delicious  meals of my life. Everyone in my party seemed to love their food and the service was amazing during the entrees. Check out their dessert. Order one of everything because it's impossible to decide which one to get. All are ridiculously  delicious. Overall, amazing staff, drinks to brighten up a bad day, and food that I will go back for over and over.

I've never had a bad meal at NOLA. They have great lunch specials (think half po' boy with fries and soup ). They have authentic Cajun cuisine with an atmosphere straight out of the French Quarter. I love that you have the option of traditional creole dishes like frog legs and gator. Plus you can accompany your meal with their take on traditional New Orleans cocktails. NOLA is definitely worth the trip to experience it for yourself.
There were four of us. Two had jambalaya, one had catfish and I had quail. All of us loved our meals and the service was excellent. Highly recommend it!

There was a band playing inside which made it too loud to talk to my wife.  The food was good but overpriced for what you got.  Thus would probably be a great place to hang out and get drinks but not a great dinner atmosphere.
Great food & great service! Definitely recommend reservations. The crab bisque & seafood jumbalaya were amazingly delicious and made to order

My husband & I stopped in here for a few drinks and to listen to the band they had playing.  The bartenders were super friendly and the drinks were awesome!  The band sounded awesome too!  We hung out at the bar for almost 2 hours before leaving to head to the next stop.  We will definitely be back the next time we are in Pitt!

We only stopped here for drinks, so that is what my rating is based upon.  The atmosphere is nice, love the New Orleans theme.   At 6:30 on a Saturday, we were the only patrons at the bar.  I ordered a cosmopolitan and my husband ordered a Moscow mule.   The bartender was efficient and made wonderful drinks.   The cosmo was perfect and very cold which I love.   The mule was served as it should be, in a copper mug, and also the right mix of ingredients.   Since I liked mine so much,  my husband asked the bartender how he made it, so hopefully I can have one at home now.

We did see some of the entrees and they looked and smelled yummy.

We stopped here while killing some time before Tako opened up at 3pm on a Sunday afternoon and came away  happy with our experience. We only ordered a couple of drinks but would've ordered food from their menu had we not intended to eat elsewhere. Their menu looked pretty good.

Sharpie is a wonderful service professional!! She is very knowledgeable of the menu and spirits. She has a great smile and a winning attitude. Very personable and a great conversationalist. She made some great recommendations, and lunch was great. Management: Give this girl a raise and keep her for as long as you can.
Been here a few times. Good representation of New Orleans food, but wish the menu was a bit broader.

I was really excited to come upon New Orleans cuisine in Pittsburgh, but I should have known: good Creole cuisine is hard to find outside of the Big Easy. Having been to New Orleans, I had an idea of what the food should taste like, and was sorely disappointed. I came around brunch and was really excited to see beignets with a chicory coffee dip as an option. That was an obvious choice. But as a main, at the recommendation of one of the waiters (not the one that was helping me), I decided on the shrimp and grits (was thrilled to see they use Anson Mill grits!) The shrimp and grits came first, smelled amazing... and that's where the excitement stopped. It was four small pieces of shrimp, swimming in a pool of spiced salt, with a small cake of grits hidden underneath. The salt content was unbelievable. It's been a long time since I've eaten ANYTHING that salty. And when I mentioned it to the waiter who had suggested it, all he had to say was "Oh, that's why I like it". Great. I didn't even finish it.
Suddenly I was really looking forward to the beignets. But the first course should have been an indicator of the quality I was going to get. The beignets were soggy, with the icing sugar just soaking into the dough... not hot and fluffy, like they do in New Orleans. This was a very poor imitation. 
The icing on the entire meal, though, had to be my very unenthusiastic waiter, who clearly would have rather been anywhere else but there. Aside from introducing himself, very little was said and not once did I see even a hint of a smile. After receiving my food, he disappeared for a long while, I even had to go inside (I had been sitting outside) so I could ask for my bill because I didn't know where he'd been. All in all, a very disappointing experience from start to finish.

The food would have been a 2, but the service and management were a 5, so I settled for 3, and hope to let them redeem themselves.  Here goes... First, we were seated early on a busy Friday night, and they did it with a smile.  The waiter was prompt and efficient.  Our appetizer was boudin.   Now, we are truly Cajun food foodies.  We throw a Cajun food fest every year in our town, and we have dined in some of the finest shacks in NOLA.  We KNOW from Cajun food.  This was not it.  First thing I said was, "how do you eat boudin without saltines?"  All jest aside, though, it wasn't right.  The boudin was in ball form, which is fine, but it didn't have enough liver.  It didn't have the good boudin funk.  It was sweet, which was weird, and not very flavorful.   I asked for hot sauce, and they brought me Tabasco ....crystal would have been better, but, whatever.  Second course for me was red beans and rice for me.  Serviceable, not great.  I like big hunks of andouille in mine.   This had none.  It was listed as an ingredient, but I couldn't find it.  Phil got a "smoked " Cesar salad with white anchovies.  The dressing reminded me of a creamy dressing you would get at the Colonnade in Atlanta....a rich southern old white guy's restaurant....creamy and flavorless.   Finally, I was very excited about the main course.  The special fish was wolf fish which is an eel-y type thing that has terribly flavorful flesh.  Unfortunately, I finally had to complain (which, believe me, I never do).  I think Lot's wife would have become human again next to this dish.  It was so salty that Phil, who LOVES salty food, said it made his mouth turn inside out.  I tried to make it work by eating the fish with the greens, but the greens were just as bad.   It was inedible.  The side of mushroom and crab Mac and cheese was ok, so I ate that.  Phil's Mack daddy duck had an excellent duck confit on top, but the pasta was really sweet.   He ate all the duck, but the pasta was just kind of gross.   

So, they get up starred because of the service.  When I finally broke down and told the waiter that the food was inedible, he was quite apologetic.  I explained that we didn't want anything, but that we felt the chef should know that the fish special was terrible.  It was early in the night, and it could be fixed.  He then brought the manage over, and he apologized.  Again, I explained that it was fine, we just wanted to let the chef know.  Eventually, they actually comped my meal.  That gesture by the waiter and manage,net is enough to make me think that it's worth another shot sometime.   Anyplace that is willing to listen and cop to their mistakes is a place that I'm willing to revisit.  Hopefully next time I'll have a better experience.
Lunch menu, Lame. OK service, not well executed food. BORING. No real creole food. Waited 15 minutes for our reserved table, and it was not even busy.  Would give a second chance for dinner.

Say what you will about Nola. All I have to say is Happy Hour! They have a $4 menu of both drinks and appetizers. Fried pickles! Po'boy sliders! I can even get a decent martini! There aren't enough places in the city that have a truly great happy hour but Nola is one of my favorites! I don't honestly know if I've ever eaten an item or drank a drink that was over $4.   There is also live music and a patio. Both are beautiful things!

Terrible service on Take Your Child To Work Day, 4/26/2018. Waited for food for 50+ minutes, which never came. Server didn't bother to give us any update. Finally, when he did, he blamed the kitchen. My daughter was terribly disappointed with the experience. I am not sure if I'll ever put my feet on that place again.

Surprisingly good and attentive wait-staff who actually give recommendations. Beautiful bar area, wall mural, and open kitchen. Live music 3 nights a week. This is the same team that brought us the top-notch Sonoma Grille and Seviche, and it shows in their glossiness and attention to detail. Their only big failing is that they are a little too conservative with the spices. 

It's not vegetarian-friendly or waistline friendly, but it sure is tasty. The soup and sandwich lunch special may be the best bang-for-your-buck at a higher end downtown restaurant. Don't miss the French Onion soup - which could be a sizable lunch on its own. 

Nola is a good, fun addition to Market Square, and it sure does buzz on a weekday afternoon as well as a weekend afternoon. Stop by next time you're craving cajun.

NOLA is a hidden treasure! I have only been here once, but the environment was awesome and the staff is super friendly! I went during their happy hour (mon 5-7, tues-fri 4-7). They have $4 grapefruit mules! I don't know if this changes ever, but it was delicious, and you rarely find mules on happy hour menus, so this was a plus (also deciding factor)! They have a happy hour menu with select apps and drinks and everything is $4 with 1/2 off flatbreads as well ($5-$6). Pro tip - sit inside because they don't do happy hour outside. I also ordered the Cajun Aricini, having no idea what to expect, but they were so good! The crust was a little salty, but they were basically fried balls of rice and Cajun sausage and they're huge! I will definitely have to revisit NOLA!
William recommended the fried green tomatoes to me. They were amazing. He was a great server and ready attentive. My first time at NOLA and I will definitely be back!
Get restaurant with food that is very reminiscent of my visits to New Orleans. The atmosphere is great, the staff friendly, and the prices fair. A must try if you love spicy Cajun food!

Top quality food and drinks in Pittsburgh's downtown Market Square. This New Orleans themed restaurant replicates the tastes and ambiance of Bourbon Street, while keeping things classy. Though the menu focuses prominently on seafood fare and traditional New Orleans favorites, something is available for all patrons' taste buds. 

Bonus Points: Extensive "Gluten Free" menu options

Great spot for dinner in Market Square. We had a lovely dinner with live music, great food and lovely ambience! The frog legs were amazing and so were the crawfish flatbread. We had a large table and our server was so friendly and helpful. I would highly recommend NOLA...

I could eat here every single night.  The atmosphere is nice and the food is yummy. I had to try the Catfish with Zapps chips, who would have thought it would be so good. I even ate my leftovers and I never eat leftovers.

A special date night started in Market Square and to Nola's. A crowded and hectic entry way soon passed when we were led to a private little booth. We started with the sangria and it was the best I've ever had!  So, my wonderful date and I had a few more of those smooth wonders.
Then for the appetizer:  The fried green tomatoes were amazing. Not sure what the sauce is that comes with them but it makes them pop.  A wedge salad was very good then for the main course I ordered the trout and he went for the jumbalia (can't spell it, but you know what I mean). Totally hot and spicy, it was almost too much for me! My boyfriend and I like to share dishes so we switched mid dinner.  The trout was mild and the rice with it was a great contrast to the hot hot hot Jumba- you know- the Brussel sprout side dish that came with the trout was the only disappointing part of the meal. An odd horseradish sauce made them just not good enough to finish. 
A server with a less than sweet attitude was okay but provided good service. 
The fun artwork added a nice touch. We definitely recommend this place and will be back again! Thanks Nola.

Have to say, used to be my favorite place until my recent visit. Plus recently went to new Orleans and this place is far from authentic. The best thing to order is the blackened catfish. The red beans and rice is not authentic at all. More like red beans chili.  I do come here for the live blues bands and some drinks. But I advise you to go to new Orleans for your southern delights.

I have to rave about this place. A friend and I were out and about on Saturday around 2pm and I really wanted to check NOLA out. We walked in and were seated near the bar at one of the high tables. The first thing I noticed is how much bigger it was on the inside versus what it looked like on the outside. Nice little surprise. I instantly wanted to bop my head to the music and enjoyed looking at the art on the wall. The atmosphere was perfect.

The hostess brought water over and then we had a waitress by the name of Stasha who talked to us about the menu (my first time there) and asked if we were interested in drinks/appetizers. I ordered the Abita Mardi Gras Bock beer and for an appetizer I got Zapp's Potato Chip Crusted Catfish. I was blown away by the flavor/spices of this catfish. It was delicious! Perfectly crispy and a nice, tender flavor on the inside. We were informed that our waitress had a big table she was tending to so we had someone else who came over, introduced themselves, and took our order. Then our lovely waitress came by to make sure our orders were in, which was then brought over by the manager (I believe that's who it was). I ordered seafood jambalaya and let me tell you how much I was in love with it. It had big pieces of shrimp, scallop, sausage, rice, and the spices...ohhh the spices. It was definitely spicy though not overpowering. I loved every bite.

While we were waiting to ask for a to-go box, one of the bartenders walked by and stopped to ask if we needed a box. Good timing. Then Stasha came over and asked us about dessert/got the check. She was so sweet, fun, and had great knowledge of the menu. I definitely appreciated her enthusiasm and interaction with us. One of the great things about this place was the customer service. I mentioned a few different people who came over to help us and they all made our experience that much better. It was the team work that I noticed and loved. You had the hostess, waitress, another waiter, the manager, and a bartender all pitching in for each other, which was so wonderful to see and experience. They did a wonderful job and I'd be more than excited to come back to try other items on the menu.

Great concept! I love new Orleans and Cajun/Créole food.
Great service, great portion sizes and tremendous atmosphere.
Will definitely he back.

Have been there twice on weekend afternoons.  Food gets an A+ for wonderful jambalaya and bisque, salads, and sandwiches.  Service, however... the first time we went there I attribute it to "working out the kinks" but the second time we went and waited about 20 minutes for our waiter, and he was downright RUDE.

Still, the food is so good I'm willing to give it another try.

I just don't understand how this restaurant had such good reviews. I went with 4 colleagues (one of whom is my wife) tonight (Wed. night) and just about everything about this place was terrible.  

We were originally a party of 10, but due to a whole lot of problems, we went down to 5. We told the restaurant ahead of time, but somehow they still put us at a large table for 10. No one could hear each other talk. Half the restaurant was empty and we asked them to move to a smaller table but they said they were all reserved. After enough complaining, they moved us, and not a single one of the tables filled up at any point during our meal (we, more or less, closed down the restaurant side of Nola). 

We ordered red wine which came hot. Not warm. Hot. We trudged through the first bottle figuring this was a fluke, but when the second bottle came, we had to ask to put it on ice for a while to cool it down. Where are they keeping these, by the oven?

The appetizers were actually okay. The fried artichoke was tasty and the lamb ribs were flavorful. The raw oysters however were chewy and bland...a sure sign of them not being fresh at all.

No one liked their entrées. I had the Creole Tartiflette and it was way too creamy. Imagine a big bowl of heavy cream with some potatoes in it. That's the Creole Tartiflette. My wife had the scallops, which the waitress pushed. Imagine bland Mac & Cheese with 4 scallops on top. Two people got the jambalaya which was nothing special. And one person got something else, which I can't recall right now.

For dessert we had the bread pudding, which was okay and the beignets. Has the chef ever been to New Orleans? The beignets were tough, not soft and fluffy like they should be. They clearly left them in the deep fryerfor a bit too long.

This restaurant failed. If you want the New Orleans experience, buy a plane ticket and skip Nola.

My boyfriend and I visited the Holiday Market this past Saturday and afterwards  we wanted to get our grub on so I decided we would try NOLA since I had only been there a few times previously for drinks and wanted to taste their food. We arrived around 1:15pm and immediately noticed, while it was crowded, there were 2 seats at the bar so,naturally,we snapped those up. Service began horrendously, and honestly, that is being quite kind. There were 2 bartenders, a male and a female, who were much more into their own private conversation than any of their patrons. Once they decided to start doing what they are paid to do (and I worked for 5 years in the restaurant industry as a server so I am quite patient and understanding but this was just pure.awful.service.), each one of them had to have walked by my boyfriend and I a minimum of 5 times each. I made eye contact multiple times with the male-and he also made eye contact with me more than once-but we never got an acknowledgement of "be right with you" or, even better, "what can I get you to drink?" After, and oh yes I timed it, 13 minutes, the female and I finally made eye contact, and she put down two napkins and said "I'll get you waters and be right back". I'm sure she could read the look in my eye when she finally did notice us because she immediately went over to the male bartender and reprimanded him for not getting us drinks and menus. Service did get slightly better after this point, however, I already had a pretty sour taste in my mouth from not being acknowledged for 13 minutes.

We both ordered Stella drafts and were given menus quickly. For some reason, although we made it clear we were going to order lunch, the male bartender dropped off our tab for the two drafts. My mouth nearly dropped-$14! Since when has Stella ever been a $7 draft beer?! We only ordered those 2, thank god, so our beer portion of the tab was not going to be any more than that. Now we were given lunch menus, obviously, and I was disappointed that some of the items (like the alligator) were not on the lunch menu. I did like the option of soup (or salad) and half of a sandwich though. I had been wanting to try their gumbo for quite some time so I decided to go with a cup of the gumbo and 1/2 of a turkey cuban sandwich. The gumbo ya-ya was served at the same time as the sandwich, which was also served with voodoo fries. The gumbo contained chicken (I could tell it was dark meat just FYI),andouille, Okra, Filé, and Steamed Rice. Honestly, I did not taste any andouille in my portion and there was, in my opinion, too many ingredients to not enough broth. It wasn't spicy but was a decent flavor-better than canned gumbo at least. The turkey cuban is described as being on a Baked Baguette with House-made Pickles, Creole Mustard, Jarlsberg, and Sweet Pepper Jam. I really enjoyed the creole mustard-it had a nice kick to it but was not overly hot. I did not taste any of the sweet pepper jam on the sandwich so if it was present, it was in a very small amount. The bread was extremely hard and almost difficult to chew, although I could tell it was not stale tasting. The pickles were delicious but I have a thing for pickles.....the best part of my meal,honestly,were the fries. There was some type of seasoning salt with a cajun kick on them and wow-they were so,so yummy! It's kind of sad though when you say the fries were the best part of your meal. 

My boyfriend ordered the Creole Pulled Pork Po Boy, described as being served on a Fresh Baguette with Pulled Pork Shoulder, Slaw, Onion Rings. It also came with the same fries. I was originally leaning towards this sandwich but I'm glad I chose what I did. His sandwich, in my opinion, did not look appetizing at all. The pork looked really dry and the two onion rings on top were about the size of a quarter each. He ate most of it,however, he will eat nearly anything. He was in agreement that the fries were the best part of his meal too.

This experience was rather disappointing as I have wanted to try the food at NOLA for quite some time and was highly looking forward to it. Although I only gave NOLA 2 stars, I do want to come back and try it for dinner when there is a bit more variety on the menu. I just hope when I do come back both the service and the food are improved for that visit.

Food was absolutely delicious.  Best jumbalaya I've ever had.  

Came for lunch at 11:30 and waited about 15 min for our server despite our being one of about three customers at the time.

Our waitress didn't tell us the specials as well which is why I withheld a fifth star.  

Would definitely eat here again.

Loved this place!

We took the boys and they had no problem w/ children in the restaurant.  The boys loved our server and his handlebar mustache!  My oldest obliterated his pizza and my youngest finished his chicken fingers when we left.  I had a ham sandwhich.  I think it came w/ gouda...but it came w/ the apple dipping sauce!  MMMmmmmmm!  I annihalated that sandwhich.  Oh, it came w/ a side of voodoo fries, which were yummy.  Hubs had the salmon and loved it.  We will definitely be back.

Came on a friend's recommendation- definitely a good one.  Came for lunch on a weekday so it wasn't busy and our server was very friendly/knowledgeable.  I ordered the Shrimp and Grits and had to order a side of the Voo Doo french fries once I saw an order pass by me.  This was my first time getting shrimp and grits and I was very satisfied- the grits were nice and creamy, and the shrimp were huge and plump (although I will say that there weren't TOO many of them, just enough to have a bit with each scoop of grits).  The fries were also great, I think they're slightly breaded and then have some cajun seasoning on them- definitely order a side of them if you don't get some with your order.  The price was about right, a little high if anything.  Overall, I would definitely recommend this place.

My friend and I came by here one rainy Friday evening for dinner. While waiting to be seated, we decided to split a hurricane. The hurricane was very tasty and strong, I definitely recommend it. For dinner, we ordered the fried green tomatoes, gumbo, and the pork tenderloin. We also had the bourbon ball and beignets with sorbet for dessert. We were told by our waiter that the food at NOLA is comparable to New Orleans' food with a touch of Pittsburgh, and were expecting mediocre food but everything was absolutely delicious and brought back fond memories of my trip to New Orleans.  Service was great as well and the waitstaff was superb. NOLA is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh and I am looking forward to returning soon.

I've already given Nola a awesome review for dinner but why not do it again for lunch when it's well deserved. I've been to Nola two times now for lunch and my most recent visit has caused it to climb to the top of my list of favorite lunch spots downtown.
