Their menu gives you the option to choose between two of the following: half sandwich, salad, or soup. You get the best of both worlds. Why choose just one when you can have both?! My absolute favorite is the Nola salad with the Nola club. It's served with voodoo fries which are probably some of the best fries out there. I've also tried the Caesar salad and the pulled pork po boy but I would not recommend them.

Better than last time. First time since remodeling.  Nola salad was decent.  It had mixed greens and roasted nuts. The jambalaya improved from the last time i had it. On the expensive side for $27.  Wish it had more seafood and less rice. Tough to eat here on an expense account. Drinks are around $10. Add tax and tip and you have 40 bucks and i just had water. 50 dollars per day doesnt go far.  Service was ok. Nice to sit outside. Water refills were slow with a spicy dish. Had to ask for bread and then it was nothing special.

I came here for lunch during the week and we were able to get a table walking in with no reservation. I didn't realize how deep and far back the restaurant went, but there were a lot of tables in the back. 

I am from Houston and I have pretty close access to real cajun food... that being said, I ordered a shrimp po boy and was sad to see that it wasn't quite the same. It was so close, but yet so far. Instead of putting just mayo, lettuce, and tomato, they used coleslaw which changed the entire taste of the poboy sandwich! I was not excited about this!

The service was fine, just disappointed as it was definitely not authentic cajun food... so beware if that's what you're expecting!

First of all, I'm from New Orleans so I have high standards when it comes to N'Awlins food.  Overall this place was pretty good when it comes to places outside of New Orleans.  

The gumbo and crab etouffee were made from a nice roux and were properly flavored which I was impressed by.  I would've liked a bit more meat in it and some French bread on the side though (that is the only proper way to eat gumbo!).  When I asked for some bread I was informed there were 2 choices which were a "complimentary baguette" or cornbread for a charge.  I was wondering why we weren't offered this complimentary bread in the first place and by the time we got it we were almost finished our gumbos.  And the bread was cold and not actually French bread.  I long for that flaky airy bread that is crispy on the outside and soft on the inside that is so ubiquitous in New Orleans. 

We also had the fried gator appetizer which was tasty though could have used a bit more of a kick to it to spice it up a bit more.   I tasted a friend's jambalaya and another friend's cheesy scallop pasta and both were really good (though the scallop dish was not a typical New Orleans dish).  

I had asked about the oyster appetizers which were market price but they were very expensive ($28 for a dozen or $12 for 4, no half dozen options allowed).  I asked the waitress if they were from the gulf, and she disdainfully replied that actually Gulf oysters are small and tasteless so they get theirs from Rhode Island.  Umm seriously? You are trying to celebrate the food of N'Awlins and you just dissed our oysters?  Gulf oysters are delicious and often quite large.  I grew up on them so I was offended by her comments.  And the oysters they served that my friend got were actually super tiny -- tinier than anything I ever get in New Orleans.  And they were not served with the proper accoutrements (Tabasco, horseradish, etc.).  

It would have been nice if the PoBoys or Muffaletta sandwhiches could be ordered for dinner but they are only on the lunch menu.

We also had the bread pudding which was very good, and the red velvet ice cream was an unusual touch.  

There was a small jazz band playing in the bar area which was a nice touch, especially for a weeknight.

I'd go back and I think they did a decent job for being so far from New Orleans.  But I think there are some basic things they could work on that would make this place even better and more authentic.

An update on NOLA that evening....
The manager ended up comping what we had ordered prior to us leaving, which was the right thing to do.

Was in the mood for classic Cajun & Creole ... NOLA was just the ticket! Ordered the Oyster Po' Boy. Oysters were jumbo, fried to perfection. Lunch service was quick and friendly. It came
With a side of Voodoo fries - they tasted just like the voodoo chips they have everywhere in New Orleans! I will go back!
Outstanding!  My filet was cooked perfectly, great atmosphere.   I Highly recommend eating here!

Let me say this. I am so thankful I did not review this place after my first visit. I had went during their grand opening phase it was not what I anticipated at all, however, I thoroughly enjoyed my experience this week.

As a person with a sensitive stomach I am nervous to try many different things with unknown spices or possible ingredients I could get sick from. I did try the red beans and rice which were amazing. I definitely would get that again. And it should be good. I mean. If a New Orleans inspired restaurant cannot make good red beans and rice, why is it open?

Since I was there for lunch I knew I wanted a flat bread. The waiter suggested I try the eggplant and chevre. I like it but would not run back to order it again. The flat bread itself was good, I just was not feeling the flavor. In the past I have had the pissaladiere which was very good. I also stole a few of my coworkers voodoo fries which were amazing. Honestly I'd go back just for the fries. The sandwiches all looked great and I really like their lunch combination ideas and the way they are presented.

It is just such a neat place inside. I hate describing things as neat, but it really is. I wish it were more voodoo decorated, but that is just me. I think for it's location (being in the north), it does New Orleans justice. I cannot wait to go back and get the shrimp po boy!

Parking: there's a garage right across the square that's $5 in the evenings 

Happy Hour: 5-7
Includes half priced flatbreads, $1 red beans and rice, $1 gumbo ya-ya, $4 bites and drinks on the insert

Tip: sign up foe the birthday rewards for Big Y group. You get a $30 entree voucher to choose from at their family of restaurants.

I've been here for happy hour and think it's delicious! Good food, decent portions and a fair price. I went once for dinner and honestly thought that the portions were small for the high price. The meals were alright. I didn't leave feeling wowed. I was glad that the meals were covered by the birthday coupon. I highly recommend going for happy hour!

I've eaten here a couple times and the atmosphere is nice and the interior of the restaurant seems clean. Service when we went both times pretty quick and the servers were nice. 

I am not a major fan of this type of food as it turns out which is disappointing so I'm probably not the best judge of that. That being said, I do like shrimp and grits which I tried here. I thought the grits were a little bland but it was otherwise okay and I would give it another shot if I came: Also, I have had their flatbreads which I did really like and would try again. I'd recommend it to anywhere coming if you don't really like creole. I have had better food in the real NOLA though of course but this isn't bad. 

Everything here seemed sort of average to me so while I'd come back if someone else wanted to but wouldn't pick it myself.

Stopped by for lunch and ordered the gumbo and the Chef's special, blackened red snapper sandwich. The gumbo had a nice flavor and color to it but I prefer a little thicker soup then this was.  It was also very short on meat and veggies.  Mostly broth and slightly undercooked rice. The sandwich was pretty good, slightly on the salty side but nicely cooked and nicely presented. Overall, nice menu, average food, good service and pretty cool atmosphere.  I'd try the place again.
Market Square is a very nice spot for a plethora of options to choose from for food. NOLA has a great vibe inside. I had the Jambalaya, and it was very good.

Ok food but the service was ridiculously bad. Don't waste your time - and it will be a lot of time. We were seated for over 1 hour before our food came and it wasn't even busy! Waitress had such an attitude when we inquired pleasantly about when we would be getting our food.
Never say never, but almost never going back there. Too many great alternatives to waste your time or money there!

I have dined here 3 times now so I feel like I have tried enough to give it a fair shake.  To be fair, this is a 5 star restaurant in Pittsburgh but I have actually left the city limits unlike some of my neighbors and dined in cities all over the country.  I would not visit this restaurant if it were in New Orleans.  I own a house there and am there quite a bit so they have a pretty high bar to reach with me.  It might do ok in the touristy part of the city on Decatur St but would certainly close if it were out in the neighborhoods.  

The service has been pretty good.  Although last night we had 3 members of the waitstaff try to take our drink order and give us the spiel.  I was pretty irritated by the 3rd person and had to tell him to stop and tell the others he was duplicating service.  The rest of the night, blessedly, they left us to enjoy our meal.

I like the flatbreads.  I had them the first time I visited.  I also think the pork chop dish is really good.  I don't love the beans and rice.  They've missed here and it's a serious offense for someone who loves this food.  There's too much grease on the plate and there's chili powder or something in there.  It should just taste more like beans and andouille.  I fear they've tried too hard on this one.  I had a perfectly cooked redfish and I like the slaw.  The duck and oyster special gumbo was good but is missing the umami of a terrific gumbo and if it were my first one I would probably have thought it terrific.  The food all the way around is solidly good but I am not a 4 star fan.  It just misses for me.  

If you've never had this cuisine and live here you should definitely go and check it out.  It's a lot of fun and I am sure you'll have a good meal.
We came here for happy hour and it was great. Service was quick and and I like the location! No veggie items but that is to be expected at a cajun place.

My taste buds are still strutting and waving white handkerchiefs in my mouth they were so happy today!  My very first visit to NOLA was the first of many more visits to come, for sure.  Three of us walked through downtown on a gorgeous sunny day, through the hip and happenin' farmers' market, past the live music in Market Square and through the wide-open doors of NOLA to quite a crowd.  And no wonder....what fantastic food!

I've had shrimp n grits all over the south...NOLA's was one of the best I've ever experienced....and most certainly the best in Pittsburgh.  Cheesy, Anson Mills stone ground grits, at least 8 or 9 great big ol' sweet, perfectly cooked shrimp, smoky bacon, the classic trinity of celery, bell peppers and onion all played together for a sweet, sweet song of the South in my mouth.  

My dining companions both had the NOLA salad.  One had the croque monsieur, the other had the muffaletta.  Both were very, very happy.  

Curtis, our server, was friendly and efficient; Ann, one of the managers, stopped at our table to make us feel right at home.  Heck, she even walked me over to the Chef's Table and told me about the special dinners they hold there.  Nice.

Our table was at the back of the restaurant right by the "pass."  The line moved together in harmony to pump out fine food with exquisite attention to detail.  Serving plates were wiped clean of any stray drips before being whisked away to the lucky recipients.  

Welcome, NOLA!  Make yourself at home and stay a while....a long, long while.

Working downtown, you're always looking for new and good lunch spots. It's nice to see classy joints like this popping up all over the downtown area. Especially in the newly renovated Market Square. When they first started renovating the area, I just had this "what's the point" feeling. Market Square was a haven for the homeless and unemployed. Driving property value down, and detracting your average downtown commuter.

I'm happy to say I was sorely mistaken. The face-lift Market Square has gotten has made me look at downtown Pittsburgh in a whole new light. A nice open airy atmosphere with plenty of trendy eateries all around. Sure you can't drive out all of the "riff-raff," but they certainly tried.

A co-worker and I stopped by NoLa to check it out a couple weeks ago. I thought the decor was cool, an over-the-top (in a good way) vision of Bourbon St and Mardi Gras. We both got the Chicken and Andouille Po Boy, which was tasty.  We found the homemade mustard was a bit overpowering though, as it was not evenly distributed and sort of gobbed onto the sandwich.

The service was good. In fact, it was too good. My co-worker and I were approached, no joke, six times by four different people asking how our meal was and how everything was going. This was excessive, and borderline annoying, given that we weren't even there an hour.

Overall I think this place is pretty good, and has the potential to be better. I feel like they are still trying to work out some of the kinks, and once they do, things will definitely approve.

If you love somewhat-pricey cajun food, and are downtown, this place is right up your alley.

This experience was the WORST! 40 minutes after ordering drinks - they arrived- but only because I reminded the waiter 3x that we were still waiting. The wait staff was overwhelmed, the food was below average. Meals: 2 of 4 were 'okay, good' and 2 were not cooked properly and very fatty (chicken). Dessert took another 35 minutes (slice of chocolate cake). They did comp us the drinks but I left the restaurant hungry. There are so many great places to go in Market Square-- do yourself a favor and go elsewhere.

Limited menu but everything sounded amazing. I settled with the seafood jambalaya-DELICIOUS! Great portion size and generous with the seafood compared to the price. I came during a cocktail hour on a Tuesday which resulted in a bit of a wait but I'm glad I was patient

Had a couple great experiences here! The live jazz on Friday night is great.  Returned the next night for dinner and was not disappointed. The red beans and rice were seasoned wonderfully...add the shrimp!  You won't regret it.

Lovely venue inside and out from the décor, ambiance, pleasant waitstaff, menu options, and taste.

It's much bigger inside than the entrance would lead you to believe.  The inside seating is very charming and atmosphere very soothing.  I have to admit to not being a huge Cajun menu fan but there are plenty of options.  I selected the Seafood Mac Daddy and the portion size and flavors all hit the spot with lobster, shrimp, pasta, and plenty of great cheese taste.  

It was such a nice walk from here to Heinz Hall, as well.  

I'd definitely choose this place for a nice date night, anytime.

Great food, great service and a really great place.
The gumbo was excellent.  The beer selection is very good.  Our server - Tommy was top notch - he took care of us very well.  That always makes the whole experience so much better.  
And - on our way out - I ran into Mel Blount and Joe Green who were coming in to have dinner.  It was a great night!
Really liked this place.  The cuisine was good.  Haven't tried the jumbalaya yet, but will definitely go back when I get a chance.

My daughter and I had reservations at NOLA before going to see a Friday night performance of Wicked.  We were over 30 minutes late for our reservation due to traffic and weather, but were still seated almost immediately.  We let the host and our server know that we had theater tickets, so we were kind of restricted on time, especially since we arrived late.  

Our server thanked us for letting him know and was very attentive throughout our meal and got us out in plenty of time for the show.  He was also very knowledgeable on menu.  

We shared the Crispy Fried Alligator which was perfectly light and crisp and tasty.  My daughter opted for a bowl of French Onion Soup.  As soon as hers arrived, it smelled so fantastic that I ordered a bowl too.  The veal broth, vermouth and caramelized onions made for a slightly sweet, total delectable soup.   If you love French Onion Soup, be sure to try this one.  You won't be disappointed. 

My daughter got the Steak Frites et Salade.  Perfectly cooked steak, tasty fries and salad.  She enjoyed it.

I got the Seafood Jambalaya.  Perfectly caramelized rice, seasoned with a pleasantly spicy kick,  plump scallops & shrimp, generous pieces of sausage and crispy chicken drummettes.  Definitely another hit. 

And sitting near the kitchen, we could see the desserts and had been eying them since we sat down.  

We decided to share a Bananas Foster.  It was made with moist delicious banana bread pudding, crispy sweet banana fritters and homemade rich luscious caramel ice cream.  Every bite was amazing. 

We'll definitely eat there again!

The shuttle guy from the hotel recommended this place. I realize I am from Texas, so getting good, authentic Cajun food isn't hard. With that said, this place is awful in terms of food. I ordered the crawfish andouille flatbread, and it was terrible. Firstly, it wasn't a flatbread; it was a pizza. Secondly, there was brown oil dripped from the andouille, which made the pizza soggy. Thirdly, because the pizza was soggy, it was hard to eat. I was picking at it so badly that the waiter and the owner talked me into getting another dish.

I decided on the Scallop Mac Daddy. It was better, but not by much. I've decided seafood and macaroni & cheese probably aren't the best combination. The scallops were big (see picture), which was good, but they gave the mac & cheese a weird flavor. I realize the two dishes I picked aren't true NOLA style, but there's no crawfish etouffee on the menu (blasphemy in my book)! In fact, most of the dishes aren't really indicative of NOLA, in my opinion.

The long island was terrible. The bartender used spiced rum instead of normal rum, and this always makes a long island un-drinkable. I had already sent back a dish, so I didn't want to complain about the drink too, but I only took two sips. I left a full drink behind.

The only good thing from the meal was the caesar salad. I don't like anchovies on pizza, but I do like anchovies in a caesar salad. The salad had fresh ingredients, was crispy, and light. But after spending $45, including tip, the meal was not worth it. I will not come here again.
Delicious food and a great atmosphere. I had the jambalaya and it was great. I definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for creole-style food done right.

So I was at NOLA this past Saturday and actually ordered some food. Of course I mean I started off with my milk punch. That drink is so yummy.

I did a half-and-half soup and sandwich. I chose the gumbo and the pulled pork. The gumbo was pretty tasty, especially when I accidentally dumped a buttload of habanero sauce on it. I thought it was going to be way too spicy to ingest after that snafu, but I think that made it taste better. The sausage in it was absolutely delicious.

The pulled pork sandwich (with onion rings on it, oddly enough) is the best I've had in Pittsburgh thus far. Which is not really a compliment to NOLA as it still wasn't that good and I wouldn't order it again. 

The meal also came with voodoo fries. Yum-my. I would order a side of those at any time, they are so good! I don't know what spices they put on them, but they're great.

We ended lunch by sharing some sorbet, mixed berry and peanut butter. The peanut butter one was great, but I am a big lover of all things peanut butter-flavored. It also came with some fried and sugar powder bread that I cannot recall the name of (and can't find on the website!). It was all delicious.

I also upgrade the rating one star because our waiter was kickass. I wish I could remember his name. He was friendly, humorous, came back and checked on us often enough.

I was hesitant to dine at NOLA after seeing the reviews. I do not understand how this place at the very least isn't a 4/5, but let me tell you, my food was deserving of a 5 star review. 

The staff is incredibly friendly and willing to recommend menu items. After going back and forth with the bartender I chose he gumbo and the catfish. It was fantastic and the flavors were on par with my experience in New Orleans last year. 

Food: 5/5
Staff:5/5

Good atmosphere and the food is not bad. However, if you're looking for authentic Cajun/Creole cuisine, you will be disappointed. Very disappointed. My date and I had the fried green tomatoes, alligator, red beans & rice,and one other forgettable appetizer. Like I said, not bad but not the real deal and pretty unremarkable.
The Frog Legs are 2 die 4! And then the Oyster Stew with artichokes! Great ambiance, artwork and cool hanging lamps! An eminent hipster's paradise! Delicious.

One and Done!
I tried this place today with some co-workers, there were 6 of us in total.  We were seated pretty quickly considering the size of our party and the fact that it was approximately 12:30 or so.  
Our waiter had the personality and friendliness of a rock.  So despite our pretty quick and good start things quickly went south from there.  After taking our order they began bringing out the food roughly 20 minutes later.  That is food for 4 out of 6 of us. 
After 10 minutes our waiter realized that two of us didn't have any food and came over to ask "what ya order"?  Apparently the cooks 'lost' our order.  A couple minutes later one more of our party had their food but the last person still did not. 
10 minutes after that the manager greeted us, apologized and said that the last person's meal was on the house, and offered him a free soup in the mean time.  
Everyone was now free of guilt to eat their food as the last member had some soup.  The food was pretty good, but nothing great.
The icing on the cake... our bill was wrong and we were over-charged by roughly $30.  We had to speak with the manager to get that sorted out as well.  
I will not be going back.

I was so disappointed in this place!  It started at the door!  There was a band playing with music 100% too loud!  the speaker was aimed right back into the restaurant making talking to anyone almost impossible.  When the host made it up to the host stand after us waiting at least 4 minutes I asked for a table outside.  Her response was and I quote "Did you see any out there?"  WHAT?!?  I calmly responded with "I don't know, I didn't look."  She went and checked and sadly there were no tables.  We were placed in a two top on the back of the place by the kitchen door.  Our waiter explained one of the specials as "the crabs sit on berries, they look like you can't eat them, but you can."  Now is that something that would like to order?  Our waiter took our drink order and left, then a busboy came up and faced his back to us while holding a plastic sauce container of water and turned his head and asked "would you like some water?"  it was like it was a drug deal and he was trying to be shady about it.  It was very weird.  After asking "what" three times because the music was so loud I couldn't hear him and the fact that he wasn't facing me, I just gave up and said yes.  He quickly came back with two wine glasses of water on a tray.  While handing placing the one glass down on the table the other tipped and fellow right in the lap of my dining partner.  Now I have been a server as he was at once also, and we understand that these mistakes happen.  However it was very odd that the busboy gave the wet guest a napkin then went right away to cleaning up the carpet.  That was the tipping point and the proof needed that the guest does not matter.  We decided that it was better that we just leave and go somewhere that will respect us and treat us as a guest should be treated.

Four (4!!!) overcooked shrimp on a whole shrimp po boy for 12 bucks?!? How can they serve this without being ashamed of themselves? Red beans n rice was average at best. Nothing close to authentic. Gumbo? Meh. Bland and boring.

I will say though that the service was above average...though it didn't make up for NOLA's lazy take on Cajun cuisine. This restaurant wouldn't last a day in New Orleans.

What an enjoyable experience!  The weather today is perfect for outdoor seating, and today's special was fantastic.  It is the apple cole slaw that made the po-boy.  It really added a fantastic kick to the blackened chicken.

The service was also stellar.  I was seated right away, where I wanted to sit, and the table service also was quick yet not hurried, and courteous.

I finally had a chance to come here and see what the buzz is about! I came here for a diner date and was surprised by my experience. On walking up I was confused by the store front making it blend in as I was expecting it to be "poppy". It was a Sunday so on entering it was dead maybe two other tables dining. We where greeted and seated in the back by the grill. It was much different than I was picturing in my head with a name like "NOLA" thinking New Orleans and it's colors and liveness. But that's ok because it did have a few cool art pieces. Now for the menu I can say it's a bit updated from what's on yelp and there site. I was disappointed to see there was no frog legs on the menu like I've read about from past reviews. It was much smaller than you would expect from a place like this but maybe it's a good thing cause they can focus more on there main dishes. I decided to try the "gumbo ya-ya" for a soup starter. I was impressed with the taste and the large chunks of okra and the meats. The rice was great not over cooked at all. Overall for the soup the flavor was nice I just wish it had a kick of heat. For my main dish I decided on the "country fried pork chop" and I'm very happy I did. Now for this  it was so rich with flavors and blended so well it really was a New Orleans style dish. It was a large portion pork chop that was still juicy with that crispy breading coating. The andouille mustard greens where out of this world so delicious and packed with flavor. As for the white rice it was sadly kinda cold and it was noticeable cause everything else was so hot. But the gravy really pulled everything together! A side note and I think it was a mix up because it says the dish comes with a side of "apple butter" but I got a side of cranberry sauce. The service was very nice and the waiter did answer questions about the menu. Overall I would return again to try a few other things on the dish.

Stopped in late Friday night for dinner with my girlfriend. We split appetizers of fried alligator and fried green tomatoes. 

The alligator was good, tender and crisp. Think popcorn chicken...errrr alligator. It was plated with a  remoulade dipping sauce. 

The fried green tomato were sliced about a half inch thick, battered and fried. They were plated with sprinklings of cheddar cheese, micro greens and a creole mustard ranch sauce drizzled on top. Normally I am anti-ranch, it has a strong flavor that overpowers most things (think cool ranch doritos....bleh). This was not the case here, the dish was great! Would definitely order again.

We split an order of seafood jambalaya for our entree. They thoughtfully split our dish between two individual skillets which were lined with rice topped with a spicy red sauce, a scallop, 2 shrimp, grilled chicken, and slices of sausage. I wish the sausage was crispier/rendered out more but the seafood and chicken were all prepared great.

My girlfriend had the classic New Orleans drink, the Hurricane and I had a boring plain old Yuengling draft. Would definitely return to try some other menu items.

This place has fell off quite a bit since my first visit. Firstly, they removed the Lobster Mac n Cheese from the menu, which was my GO TO and replaced it with a duck Mac n Cheese (gross). 

Once a month my friends and i do a couples dinner night and we came here. The service was mediocre, the staff wasn't very accommodating, but what saved them was their food. The chicken and dumplings was really good and the alligator is the best thing on the menu, although their portions are the same! My girlfriend ordered the same thing as me and her portion looked like a kid size, she was disappointed. When it was time to order the dessert the waiter took our order only to come back 25 minutes later and tell us that the kitchen was closed, what a huge disappointment being as though there was only 2 other people in the restaurant and nothing slowing the waiter down from putting in our order.

Went here for lunch and was thoroughly impressed. Service was quick, friendly and very good. We had gumbo soup, fried green tomatoes, po' boys (shrimp and oyster) with fries. The shrimp had a great batter though it was unseasoned. Paired with this sandwiches is a 'pepper jam' that is well balanced as consists of honey and chili pepper. Absolutely amazing jam that could go with a number of items. The shrimp was a good size and tasted fresh. The seasoned fries were also very good. I'll definitely be returning. 

Nola is also a Yelp Cash Back participant, so you'll get 7% of your meal cost sent back to you in cash, as long as you sign up on Yelp for the program.

Came here today for Sunday brunch. There was no wait I was seated immediately with my dad. Service was very good, however, for brunch the menu isn't all that expansive. They have a starter and entree special for $18. I got the beignets as a starter and the crab cake benedict. The beignets were divine. I wish there was more than 2! The crab cake benedict was good. I usually love Cajun food and seasonings, but I feel they over do it a lot. We got the marghertia pizza as an appetizer and it was just okay. I'm not a fan of green tomatoes, and they sort of put a lot of Cajun seasoning on it. But my dad enjoyed it. He got the catfish po boy, it was huge! But he said it was very good. Overall a good experience. I definitely want to go back and try something different.

Went to dinner with an old friend from school. Appetizers Friend Green Tomatoes and Alligator were very good. Drinks took forever to come. Dinner portions were varied...but dishes: Jambalya and Chk n Waffles were quite tasty. Second round of drinks came quicker and were better than the firsts. 

Enjoyed the live music. 

Will patron again to try new dishes. 

Pretty pricey.

We came here for a quick drink and a snack. The place seemed promising. We love creole food so we were excited. That excitement quickly turned into disappointment.  

First off, the service is horrible. The waiters and waitresses seems disinterested. And one of our plates were dirty! We tried to signal for a waiter but no one came by so we had to go up to the manager for a new plate. The food was no better than the service. We ordered the sausage and crawfish flat bread. The whole thing lacked flavor and was way too oily for my taste. I will definitely not go back there.
Love Cajun food... but this place is not the place.   Very expensive, food is not that great, decent atmosphere.  Service is decent.  Wouldn't come back.

Went here for the first time this past week and was excited to try something new. I ordered the hanger steak and for the most part everything was very good, especially the salad and fries that come along with it. The steak itself was a little low on seasoning. I ordered the meat as medium and received it as basically raw so that was a little disappointing. Overall, I think this place is decent, but over-priced.

I was going back through my old reviews - and I HAD to add a star back to NOLA.  Their happy hour is one of our favorites.  Half off flat breads (which are all insanely good) and $1 red beans and rice or jambalaya.  Don't quote me on this, but I think the draft beer is also $1 off.  There's usually a new flatbread depending on the season, so its nice to always have something new to try.  Since I've been more of a regular here, the food has really grown on me.

We hit NOLA a couple of weeks ago on a Saturday night.  We got there pretty early and were part of the show crowd.

The place is misleading, size-wise from the outside - it's pretty large inside, with at least three distinct seating areas.  It also seems as though there should be one table removed from the area where we were seated.  While understanding that table turn $$$ is why every restaurant is in business, it was like dining in a NYC subway car at 6pm.

Seasonal House Sangria was tasty and different.  Of course it included bourbon and also sported a bruised rosemary sprig instead of fruit - Yum!  It indeed tasted like the perfect winter sangria - we both loved it.  Fried Green Tomatoes are an obsession of mine so I couldn't wait to sample NOLA's version.  While they were good, the tempura was overpowering and left me still wanting fried green tomatoes. Two entrees were enjoyed.  I had the Wood Roasted Quail which was served with the best prepared asparagus ever - nice and firm.  The quail was well done and flavorful with both the rice and cranberry sauce complementing the bird.  The oyster dressing was not great; mushy describes both flavor and texture.  My companion had the Scallop and Shrimp Mac Daddy which was served in a cast iron pan and had great flavor.

I would go back only to try out the sandwich side of the menu, as it also looked tempting.  They were very busy, but I feel like if I go in with diner expectation I would be better satisfied with the loud atmosphere, tight quarters and rushed staff.  Muffaletta or Po'boy... sangria can make the jump!

Also - made reservation through Yelp - how much easier can things be???  I wish more restaurants used this feature!

NOLA is our go-to lunch spot at work. It's pretty great. I have mostly had sandwiches there, so I can't comment on their entrees on the menu. The have solid and interesting food, at a good price. Their fries are can't-help-yourself good. Really. They have one of the best veg sandwiches (Pan Bagnat) I thinkI've ever had. They offer combos of soup+salad or soup+sandwich or salad+sandwich, which is my favorite thing to get. The French onion soup is pretty amazing, salty, cheesy, and with thick chunks of bread under a thick layer of gruyere. Basically the food is great, and I haven't heard anything negative from anyone I've gone there with, with the exception of an off day in the kitchen, that happened maybe once. For a new restaurant, I think they got their chit together pretty quickly, and made some minor changes to the menu after a few weeks, which I think improved the place. I can't speak to their authentic-ness, but they are pretty damn good. 

The staff is friendly and the atmosphere is always nice and inviting, with a nice little outdoor area for those beautiful days in the square. They do, however, have one of the worst entrance/lobby/hostess stations in the world. You are basically standing in the middle of the main thoroughfare through the restaurant while waiting to talk to the hostess. And if you happen to have to wait for a table, then you are awkwardly trying to find a place to put yourself with out being in the way. There is basically no where to stand without bothering someone, and that bothers me. It's nice that they have the most amount of seating possible in there, but it would be even nicer if that awkwardness was done away with the removal of one or two tables.

I've been to Nola's a few times before and have always had good experiences. The fully stocked bar always has a "relevant to the season" selection of Craft Brews and the staff is courteous, knowledgeable and professional. They offer a New Orleans Nouveau Creole menu with live jazz on select evenings. The outdoor seating with a view of the bustling Market Square presents a wonderful atmosphere (if you're lucky to get a seat) on a hot summer day while the interior provides a feeling of being in a tavern on Bourbon Street (I know, I've been there too).

A couple of days ago during my lunch break I had a hankering for something spicy so I headed over to Nola's and ordered up a serving of the jambalaya. It took only about ten minutes for a hot cast-iron dish to be placed in front of me filled with shrimp, scallops, chicken, andouille, veggies and of course beans and "dirty" rice. The spices blended together to make the meal flavorful without being too spicy... a delicate line to tow.  It was truly delicious; I know I'll be back again. Perhaps one day I'll muster up the courage to try the Frog Legs or the maybe the "Crispy Fried Alligator".

The staff is top drawer. We had a large party arrive at prime time dinner hours with no advance notice and still got a wonderful table. It was a spur of the moment thing. The place was packed, and I was worried we would have to go elsewhere, but, no, NOLA was up for this challenge. We were assigned a feisty, diligent waitress who was everything you want in a server and were treated like royalty. 5 stars.

The food was not as sensational but agreeable. I started with the alligator tail appetizer--it was compromised to a certain extent as the batter had too much chili pepper--made it difficult to taste the meat. Once I pulled off the batter, the alligator was tender and of good quality. 

We all shared our various main courses a la family style--so got to taste a lot of NOLA's entrees in one visit. Steak marchand de vin was excellent; blackened catfish was respectable; chicken and dumplings was below average; and seafood jambalaya had way too much heat (and was even ordered less spicy). Also partook of the NOLA salad and the smokey caesar salad and both were just okay. Nothing jumped out at me in terms of the desserts.

It's a fun spot with lots of charm and gaiety. There is live music, and that is a very nice feature however it was almost too loud for us. Perhaps reducing the decibel level during peak dinner hours might be a consideration.  

NOLA is a place where "laissez les bon temps rouler" is for real.

Had a very nice dinner there traveling in for business. I grew up in New Orleans and this place is certainly upscale Cajun/Creole. I had the half of Cajun duck plate. The actual duck was cooked perfectly and tasted amazing. The vegetable that came with it were good but some of the sauce over it wasn't my style. Not bad just took away from the duck. All in all a pleasant experience.

My sweet friend took me here one night after hanging out, and I was a little nervous. I don't like to let people pay for me, especially if it's not "cheap" food. I was also worried there would be nothing vegetarian. Well, one fear was confirmed. There really is next to nothing vegetarian here. 

I ended up ordering the single item that was. I think it was a flatbread with pesto and tomato. We sat outside listening to the (very loud but good) music and sipping on one of the most amazing fruit-type beers I've ever had. This was in July, so I honestly forget the name of it. I won't forget the taste, though! 

The flatbread came out, and I was surprised by the generous size. It was incredibly flavorful and well made. I typically loathe little tomatoes on top of food, but these were perfectly ripe and delicious. I'm getting hungry remembering this meal. 

Oh, did I mention my meal was $9, while hers was $27? Vegetarians are cheap dates.

Jambalaya is outstanding and all of the entrees have a great Louisiana kick! Staff is super friendly and were very accommodating to my little one! It's also on Market Square which is just a great place to visit when in downtown Pittsburgh.

Poor service and sub par food overall. First, it took at least an hour to get our appetizer and soups which I'm pretty sure were only brought out because we reminded him... his response was, "oh I thought you wanted it all out at the same time." Not sure where he got that idea.. we ordered the soups and appetizers in addition to our full meals.

Next, of course after we asked, he brought out some rolls. The rolls were hard and so was the butter. Spreading wasn't even an option. 

Mind you we also ordered drinks when we got there. They came out timely, however in the 2.5hours we were seated in our back booth (a table of 6... large enough to have the potential to get a decent tip, but not too large that we were at all hard to handle) our waiter never asked us if we wanted more beverages. He checked on us a total of 3 times throughout our time at Nola and never asked us if we would like to see a dessert menu. We also had to flag him down to get his attention in order to pay for our meal.

The fried green tomato appetizer and French onion soup was the only good part of the entire meal. The portions were small for the price and not anything earth shatteringly delicious.

We will definitely not be going back for dinner. Maybe for lunch if we aren't in any hurry or aren't very hungry.

Atmosphere is nice. Food is okay, though not real New Orleans style presentation. I had the jumba yaya soup which lacked a little of the Cajun punch, I didn't care much for the lack of bread on the side.  The entree was the blackened salmon with pecan rice and shrimp etufee. The salmon was tasty the etufee was bland. The dish was good but not four stars. Seems like a popular place although I have found that after six years of travel to Pittsburgh, you don't come here for the food.

Imminently forgettable.  Bland, boring, and tasteless.  I tried the fried alligator appetizer and the jambalaya for the main course.  The best part of the jambalaya is the andouille sausage, and that's not saying much.  The shrimp were as tasteless as the chicken and the rice was worse than tasteless.  And it's not spicy.  A jambalaya that isn't spicy?  That makes as much sense as calling white chocolate chocolate.

They get an extra star for putting in the effort to have frogs legs and alligator on the menu, though the alligator was so drowned in aioli that all you can tell is you're eating fried...something...in aioli.  I got the distinct impression they only have these things on the menu to seem edgy, which is a huge disappointment.

All this with New York prices make for a fairly lame experience.  Granted, this is right in tourist central, but for some reason I was hoping to get more than the usual tourist razzle dazzle and sky-high prices.  I was very wrong.

I can't believe that I have never written a review for this restaurant.  How rude!  And now one of my favorite lunch spots is being sold to another local chain. I just hope that the new owners don't screw everything up....  I've seen that happen where a new owners takes over an existing restaurant and decides to make too many tweaks.  Bleh!  ("Oh, let's just add turmeric to all of the existing recipes and that will be our "signature" touch")  You get my point.  I just feel bad that they have been so negatively impacted by several fires within the business and I'm sure that has screwed around with their business.  However, if you want some decent New Orlens vittles, Nola on the Square will treat you right.

I have had almost their ENTIRE lunch menu.  (I know, that's ridiculous)  You can't go wrong with any of SOUP, SALAD, & SANDWICH DUOS.  Seriously!  Your tummy will be as tight as a drum after eating one of their po boy sandwiches. (Shrimp, Catfish, Alligator or Roast Beef, you can't wrong, especially served with the Voodoo fries.)!   The lunch entrees are bomb diggity too. Shrimp and Grits, Grilled Catfish and my favorite, Poulet Frites et Salade!   Oh my!(Do you know how hard it is to get a chicken crispy on the outside and moist on the inside?  As someone who cooks, it's not the easiest hat trick to pull off.)  The appetizers (Crispy Fried Alligator, Fried Green Tomatoes) and soups (Red Beans & Rice, Gumbo Ya-Ya and French Onion) are also, right tasty! 

I'm trying to stay in town one night for their Grilled Chicken & Dumplings, because I've got a feeling that that dish is going to be off the chain.
My sister, Luch, was stationed in New Orleans and they have some AMAZING restaurants.  However, if you can't make it there, go check out Nola on the Square and I think that you will be pleasantly surprised.

The outdoor seating is great and part of it is covered so if you want to stay out of direct sun, this is the place.  Great view of the square and the fries are really delicious. I didnt like the smoked tomato bisque, it was vinegary, but my boyfriend loved it.

We made it there for restaurant week and it was AWESOME !!!!   We had the shrimp boiled skewer for the app the ribs for dinner and a desert !!! Everything was cooked perfectly .. The ribs fell off the bone !!! The skewer had shrimp sausage and potatoes over a corn like salsa !!!! WOW !!!! Highly recommend it !!

I've been to New Orleans and eaten my way through that glorious city and I can safely say that NOLA is not really representative of New Orleans food.  The Partner In Cuisine and I split an alligator appetizer, a po'boy, and a mufaletta, but they had been "Pittsburghized."  The Voodoo Fries were just french fries with seasoned salt.  Fortunately for them, the lack of New Orleans authenticity didn't take away from the fact that the food was tasty.  I'll definitely go back  to indulge in some Abita (since it's not an easy find in Pittsburgh) and perhaps the alligator, but I think I'll leave the other dishes for when I go back to New Orleans!

NOLA is wonderfully located in Market Square.  And it has decent food and great bartender service.  Valet parking is great.  But keep the receipt as we were ticketed by Pittsburgh for not parking .... even though we paid the valet service.... 

NOLA refused to allow for reservations in the "bar area" for watching/viewing bands.  We used to go about 2 hours early to wedge our way forward toward the performers.  But the management's view is not conducive to getting decent seating.  We have been there before and told to "wait" at the bar, then others come in and get band row seating.... (secret handshake?).  We used to call the manager over and ask for decent seating.... "maybe."

My party of 8 decided, after this call to reservations today before 1 pm, to go elsewhere as we told there could be no assigned/reserved seating toward the band(s).  But others come in and are seated.... 

Sigh.  There are so much better Pittsburgh venues for appreciating music, and having seating/reservation service.  

Amusingly, BJ's in Wexford doesn't take reservations per se but puts one on a priority list for seating depending on traffic.  And they discuss the options and timing of arrival.  Stunningly different customer experience.  

Fred.
I'm used to the real thing in NOLA and Baton Rouge, but this is very reminiscent of them.

I had the BbQ shrimp & House cured pork belly appetizers, both recommended by our waitress. I loved the shrimp, it was so flavorful that I cleaned my plate with the bread. The pork belly was by far one of the best dishes I have ever had. Totally recommend NOLA!

Nice for lunch and dinner, and fast enough for a work lunch. 

I got the Heirloom Tomato & Wood Roasted Corn salad with salmon added; delicious! The spiced watermelon and pickled radish in the salad are so good - never had watermelon or radish that way. 

Service was quick, and we sat at a hightop near the open terrace. 

They serve yaka mein, which I saw on Anthony Bourdain or Andrew Zimmern (I forget) once, which I am definitely going to try soon.

It is nice to have a somewhat decent, somewhat cajun place north of the Mason Dixon line.  While the food is pretty darn good (not great), I have to give the place high marks for bringing this style of cooking up north.  Keeping with the style, they have several Abita beers on tap, which are hard enough to find in bottles.  The gumbo is really good, but the portion is small and relatively expensive.  The blackened seasoning has been salty, but when I ask for less salt they do comply.  The waitstaff and bar tenders are very friendly.  Stay away from the banana foster bread pudding dessert, it is so unbelievably good and decadent I'm sure you're selling your soul to the devil.

My first time here was a terrible experience. I didn't get served after sitting at a table for twenty minutes. I ended up just leaving. Recently I gave it a second go and I was pleasantly surprised. The staff was helpful and attentive. The atmosphere is awesome. I had the jambalaya that I shared with a friend thanks to the waitress telling us that we would be better off sharing. That waitress changed my whole view of this place. I would definitely come back for the jambalaya.

This place is excellent! My girlfriend and i have been here twice; we sat at the bar both times and both servers were very nice and knowledgeable. 

The first time we were there during happy hour and we got the pork belly and the flat bread - both were amazing. The cocktails were very good as well - I had something with jalapeños in it and it was flavorful but very spicy as well.

We ended up going back the next morning to try the beignets - they weren't as good as Cafe Du Monde but they were still worth getting. 

I would definitely go back next time I am in Pittsburgh, sounds like the live music would be exciting.

Wonderful taste of New Orleans cuisine. The hush puppies and the sauce they were served with were very filling. By the time my flatbread ($9) arrived, which was big enough to split as an entree, I had it wrapped to take home. I had to have beniegts wrapped to go fo dessert as well. That was a huge portion, big enough for two to share. They were still warm when we got home. Four, palm-sized, light beniegts coated with powdered sugar, served with sorbet. My husband ordered a cup of gumbo and the featured dinner-blackened kobia (fish) with roasted peaches, chantrel mushrooms, and corn served on endive leaves. (see  picture) Service was excellent, tables were available inside and on the sidewalk out front. Had to wash it down with an Abita brew. Looking forward to our next visit.

I came here on the day after my birthday because I am on the mailing list for this restaurant group. And as part of that you actually get a $25 certificate to use at any of the restaurants that they have. I mean, how good is that? I have been on the list for a few years now and have never used this perk. Am I an idiot or what? Anyways this year I thought, well, lets start 34 off a little different and use a coupon. We took an Uber down to Market Square. I suggest everyone who is trying to go here to just get an Uber or Lyft and not worry about parking. There is nothing worse than trying to find a parking spot when you know your reservation is soon. Yeah, they have valet and parking garages, but why spend the money and have to drive yourself home (aka no drinking) if you can just request an Uber. Seems like a no brainer to me. 

Sadly I did not indulge in a drink, but after the two weeks of celebrating my birthday, it wasn't that big of deal. The table was ready right when we got there and the service was top notch like usual. Our hostess was really nice and even indulged us a bit when we considered sitting outside instead of inside. We opted to sit inside, as a side not, I am not a big fan of sitting outside usually, especially in the dark, so, we sat inside near the kitchen where we usually head to anyways. Another sad part of Sunday was that there wasn't any live music. I would have liked to hear some fine tunes while I ate. 

Starters:
Oysters: A foursome or dozen; wood roasted bbq or raw half shell. I of course ordered this and of course ate it all myself. Yeah, my partner is not really into the whole raw oyster thing and I absolutely love them. I will eat them each and every day if I could. I will say that they had a little bit of a different take on the cocktail sauce which I do not know how I really feel about. And they then had some sort of red pepper jam cocktail sauce that I liked, but it wasn't what I was used to. While good, I think that they were a little bit small in size for the price. I may not get them again, but that night I was happy I did. 

Salad:
Cajun Cobb Salad: Romaine, Tasso Ham, Edamame, Cucumber, Radish, Point Reyes Blue Cheese, Hard Boiled Egg, Tomatoes, House Made White Balsamic Vinaigrette. I wanted a salad but not a large one and the server suggested that I just get a side salad of any of the salads that they had on the menu. While smaller it was also just $3 less than the original price for the usual portion. If I knew that I would have just gotten the regular sized salad and brought some home with the dressing on the side. The cobb was good. Nothing out of the ordinary or outstanding. A solid salad for sure. 

Dinner:
Seafood Jambalaya: Cajun Rice, Chicken, Wild Caught Shrimp, Sea Scallops, Andouille Sausage. So the server asked if I liked spicy food. My answer was, sometimes. So he suggested that instead of the cajun rice I get the white rice. He said that the cajun rice had a lot of the spice in it and if I was not in the mood for a 6 on a scale of 1-10 then maybe to skip it. I took his advice and I think that next time I might ask for a mixture of the white and cajun rice. The dish was good but it lacked something, maybe the spice? It just needed a bit more to make it a real mouthwatering moment. The dish also came out so hot, its in a skillet, that it took a good bit of time to cool down. The shrimp was plump and juicy and the sea scallops were amazing. I was not the biggest fan of the shredded chicken, it tasted a little dry to me. It was a solid dish but I would hesitate to get it again. 

12oz New York Strip Steak. Loaded Mashed Potatoes, Sautéed Leeks, Wild Mushrooms, Demi-Glace. This really stole the show. I do not know how a steak could taste this good but boy, did it. I had more than a few bites of this steak and would have been ok if I too ordered it. My partner got the mashed potatoes but then substituted the leeks and mushrooms for peas and edamame. The mashed potatoes were amazing. They were just so good. And I cannot tell you enough good things about how well the steak was done and how juicy it was. YUM.

We took leftovers home for both of the dishes and ate for another day. It was a great time and it was even better with that $25 dollar off discount. AND!!! Nola is part of the Yelp Cash Back, so I was super surprised to see money in my account on Yelp! I totally forgot about that and it was a nice surprise. So come here with family and friends, sign up for their newsletter, and link the card you are going to use so you get cash back! Its really a great deal for a great place to eat!

Whether or not NOLA is serving up bona fide Cajun/Creole cuisine is a non-issue to me. Whatever it is they're dishing out has successfully channeled the spirit of the late Justin Wilson, a colorful bard of a television chef who introduced me to Louisiana cookery when I was but a boy...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eK4umRMJlrs

Before taking in a show at Heinz Hall, I decided on NOLA for my pre-event meal and was favorably taken aback by each and every dish I consumed. I was welcomed by a sociable staff and was seated promptly without a reservation. The patrons were a diverse bunch that ranged from middle-aged couples to teenaged skateboard anarchists, and the ambience was closer to time-honored than cutting edge; if a long-defunct, dimly-lit, and bygone Bourbon Street tavern was plucked from the timestream and into modern, urban Pittsburgh, you'd have an approximate rendition of NOLA. Jazz, conversation, and laughter nudged the air jovially, gently...

Finding it difficult to choose an entree, I was tempted by a threesome of appetizers, and in a fit of lunacy and foodlust, I ordered all of them.

The Crispy Fried Alligator comes to your plate in a bronzed mound of protein morsels artfully littered with chives and accompanied by a smear of spiced aioli. The dislimbed swamp dragon recalled lobster, scallops, catfish, and of course chicken with its meaty, juicy flavor and mouthfeel that was punctuated by the piquant orange cream. 

Barbequed Oysters on the half shell came next, and the slithering, slimy, slightly saliferous creatures were eviscerated swiftly by me, tart sauce, buttery cheese and all. The rocky chassis of each mollusk was left to creak in the dusk winds.
