I love Noa! I have been here for dinner twice and lunch twice. I love the menu and the cocktails. I am new to the area and this is the first place that I really enjoyed.

Went here for lunch and had the crab cake.  It was really well cooked and not too heavy. The waitress was really friendly and the atmosphere was pretty laid back for downtown lunch. It didn't take very long to get our food.

NOLA gets packed in the evenings and on weekends, but for good reason.  The bar is nice, the food is good, and the service is great.  Everyone that helped us was friendly and attentive, and made for an all around enjoyable experience.  I also never felt as though the restaurant was over-crowded, as some restaurants feel when there is a line out the door.  Also, Market Square is a great place to be on a nice afternoon in the Burgh too (or before a show at the theaters nearby).

The menu is more of a northern version of Cajun food than authentic, but there are some interesting appetizer and entree choices, both for the timid and the daring.  

My table ordered fried zucchini and alligator apps, and I had the quail for dinner, which was cooked perfectly.  The portions were very generous, and I was not able to finish my entire entree.  One of my friends had the scallop entree, and while it was a bit heavy and rich, it was also fantastic. 

Definitely worth a try if you have never been here before.

Everything about this restaurant was average.  I went here with my mom who came to visit me on a whim.  We ate outside, which was nice.  Our waitress was very prompt.  They really try to give you a New Orleans feel here.  And I give them props for trying to do that in downtown Pittsburgh of all places.  But....the food was ok. There wasn't a whole lot of unique to it.  I mean, one of the specials was a New Orleans styled salad.  Salad.  As a Special.  It's just lettuce and some "stuff" in it right?  That's the special?  

Adding cajun fries was nice, but it's not what's bringing me back.  The French Onion soup was good, but salty.  The burger I had was very greasy.  The service, outside of the initial promptness was slooooooooow.  I think the waitress forgot to put in our order.  We waited a long time from order to delivery.  The people behind us didn't even get waters for the longest time, and they weren't that busy.  The watress apologized, but still got my mom's salad wrong, as she asked for no onions, but gave them anyways.  Either way, nothing here from preventing me from going back, but I'll probably check out the other restaurants in  Market Square first before going back.

Fantastic food and service. 5 star dining at its finest? Exclusive, authentic, gourmet cajun dishes combined with affordable prices makes NOLA a go-to get you southern fix. I've been here at least a dozen times and they have yet to disappoint.

A must-have every time we come is the fries alligator. Its surely the only place that I know of in the city the offers it, and every time is just like the first time. Today we stopped in for happy hour and we're delighted to find a handful of appetizer items for $4, small sides for $1 and half off flatbreads. Get the Peato Crawfish flatbread if you can. They also had house wines for $5 and beer and cocktail specials.

NOLA is a fun experience no matter what the occasion. Stop wasting time and get here now to see for yourself!

Enjoy the seafood pot pie with no seafood , excellent for vegans. I also appreciated the lobster who waved at the seafood pot pie from a couple of meters before they closed the pie. I think I wrote a review 6 years ago but this was worthy writing a new one.
Place is awesome!  Chicken Andouille Po Boy is off the hook!

Went for lunch; not speedy service but not slow either; it's a nice place so don't expect rush service. I read reviews about the service but I had no problem here. In any case, I had the gumbo ya-ya and gulf lump crab cake; both were terrific! Hope I get back to Pittsburgh to try some other items...
Great food and good service but I think this place deserves three $ instead of two $ mains are priced from $20-39.

Visited twice, for lunch and dinner, and both meals were great.  Good portions, although the shrimp po' boy was a little heavy on the bread.  The bar was extremely loud, and we found it difficult to hear each other even when we were screaming from a foot away. Definitely recommend the red beans and rice though...and most noticeable was the great service!

Wow this was easily among the most disappointing food experiences. My friends had brought me here for a birthday dinner and I was super excited because I love the Nola styles of cooking. The decor was lovely and our waitress was nice but that was all that was good. I ordered the Crawfsh Mac Daddy and for such a promising name the actual dish left so much to be desired. For starters, rather than a rich, creamy cheese sauce that coated the noodles and the seafood I received a thin, vaguely cheese flavored water that sloshed at the bottom of the cast iron dish. And rather than well seasoned seafood and tender vegetables, I got rubbery, nearly to the point of being inedible seafood that had no seasoning, much less anything that could even begin to bring to mind Creole or Cajun flavor, and raw vegetables. I didn't even finish it even though I was pretty hungry. There was hardly any flavor at all. For $26 dollars I expect actual seasoning and something that I, as someone who doesn't cook for a living, could not do better. I'm sad to say you'd  get more flavor at Popeyes.

Slightly contemporary and good food. I had the chicken and dumplings and blueberry bread pudding. I would highly recommend the bread pudding! The chicken was a little dry but the dumplings were made well. 

Live music at the location. Sitting outside is a little difficult if you are in a date or want to communicate. 

Casual or slight dressed up attire is needed for this venue. 

Bar tenders do a good job with the odd drinks and he drinks are very well made.

I was in Pittsburgh for work and a coworker recommended this place so we went here for a late dinner. I chose the seafood jambalaya. It was not so great. There was so much heavily seasoned sausage that it really muted out a lot of the other flavors I was enjoying. I ended up pushing several pieces of it to the side. I should say here that it's been my experience in this part of the US that restaurants seem to serve a lot of processed meats like sausage and cold cuts so if you're not used to that it can be overwhelming. 
The scallops were not fresh at all and poorly prepared. One was so fishy tasting that I couldn't eat it. I was really disappointed since I love scallops and this wasn't a cheap meal. 
Nice ambiance and the service was great but sadly I wouldn't recommend.

I've been wanting to try NOLA for a long time, and we finally made it for brunch last weekend. I think New Orleans has the most amazing food scene, and I was so excited that I might get to have some of that food-joy here in Pittsburgh. Unfortunately, we just weren't very impressed.

My husband and father-in-law had the chicken and waffles. It's soooo much chicken--like a huge portion--although it was not specially seasoned which we kinda expected it to be. It was just really good fried chicken. The waffle was good, but not incredible.

My mom had the shrimp dish; I had the crab and asparagus omelet. We both liked our food, but again, we weren't blown away. My daughter liked the french toast although it was a little dry. It comes with a marmalade and a little light sauce, but maybe it needed something a little more liquid-y?

The highlight of my meal was the grits. The GRITS are GREAT although in my opinion, Carmi still has the best grits in town.

I tried one voodoo fry (not gluten-free), and it was good. I'd have more if I could, but I wouldn't go back just to have them.

The service was uneven. The assistant manager greeted us and brought us to our table. She was very nice. Our server was nice, but sometimes it was difficult to get his attention and he kept forgetting things, and as soon as he got another table, he disappeared. I don't think he was a bad waiter, but he wasn't very quick.

Bottom line: Not bad, just not great.

Stopped in before heading over to PPG place to ice skate. Kassandra was our bartender, she was awesome!! She helped my picky self choose  something great to drink. She had a lot of recommendations and was super friendly, efficient and attentive.  The French onion soup is by far the best I have ever had! My boyfriend had the shrimp fried sandwich and he really liked it as well. The other guy bartenders didn't really seem to care about us considering they came after we have been eating and they just seemed to care about talking about their personal lives right in front of us, must not have cared because they probably weren't getting apart of the tip, besides that everything was perfect!!!

I must say, the Nola salad is absolutely delicious and if you do go, you should definitely give it a try. I ordered it with no tomato and dressing on the side. And as far as restaurant salads go it is relatively healthy. However, we went at lunch time, 12 PM on a Tuesday. They were by no definition busy. All we ordered was salads and half sandwiches and we were waiting for our food for about 45 minutes. I would not return for this reason alone. Not exactly what you're looking for when you just want a quick bite on your lunch break.

First of all, I'm a fan of Seviche and the Sonoma Grille, so I had fairly high expectations walking in to the newly renovated NOLA...and I wasn't disappointed.

I have nothing but good things to say! The band was outstanding - sort of a Cherry Poppin' Daddies, jazz rock, kind of vibe. Our waitress was great and the food was excellent - the service was immediate and fast. We only had appetizers but I was impressed by the freshness of the fried green tomatoes, the perfect grill on the in-house sausage, and lack of grease with the hush puppies. 

Overall, I absolutely intend to go back for a full meal; and, expect this to become a 5-star rating.

The atmosphere at this restaurant is great!  Its in Market Square, they have outside dining so I really love to come here in the summer.  Its nice to sit outside and eat and watch all thats going on in the square!  They usually have a band playing there in the evenings which is nice.  The service was pretty good, and we didn't have to wait to long for our food.  Oh and I forgot to mention we were there on a friday so we did have a half hour wait , but it went fast because you can walk around the square, or sit at one of the tables in the square and watch all the people, so it was entertaining.
Great food but overpriced.  Food is good and lunch prices are OK.  Oyster po-boy and jambalaya were very good, although the po-boy has way too much bread.

We went in for a late Saturday lunch.  We had a reservation, not knowing if it as really necessary.  On this particular Saturday, it was not.  We were greeted right away by the host.  We were surprised when he gave us a "tour" of the restaurant showing us the rooms in the back for large groups.  We must look like party organizing people.  We are not.  We were seated near the open kitchen.  

Being a huge fan of red beans and rice, we decided to share a bowl.  Their version is totally unlike any I have ever eaten.  It was incredibly thick and tomato based with a lot of ham shank.  We liked it anyway.  For my meal, I ordered the half salad/half sandwich.  I got the NOLA salad with candied pecans, red onion, tomato and sweet potato chips with yummy vinaigrette.  For my sandwich, I picked the Croque Monsieur.  It was stuffed with tender, thick carved slices of smoked ham, grilled rustic bread, my favorite Gruyere cheese with apple butter and dijon.  Even though this was 1/2 sandwich, it was more than I could eat!!  BJ got the Seafood Jambalaya.  He really liked it.  Of course, we didn't have room for dessert. 

Enjoyed the atmosphere, food was great, service was passable.  We can't wait to eat here again!

I liked the food, but it was nothing too memorable. I do however remember being turned off by the service. I don't think I've ever had a hostess be so rude to me in my life. I'm a pretty relaxed person, and totally understand that the food service industry can be stressful....but when it's a Monday night and not crowded, the hostess rolls her eyes at you, doesn't say hello, and just grabs menus, I'm going to be a little bit upset.

Great downtown restaurant. The ambiance is intimate and cool, and their menu is definitely different and refreshing from typical Pittsburgh dining that can get stale. Nice wine list, creative menu. However, not much for vegetarians--maybe 3-4 salads/entrees/appetizers that I could actually have. But the vegetarian dishes available all sounded delicious, so I didn't mind at all.

Has gone wayyyy down hill! I've eaten here about 10 times and each time I've enjoyed it less and less, however last night was my last night eating there. 

From the poor wait staff, to the over cooked porkchop and sad jambalaya, ending with a 35 minute dessert delivery and silverware washtubs being carried through the dining room I've had enough. 

I came into work today and told everyone about how awful is was and how upset I was just to hear they had the same experience a few weeks ago. 


The service- I've had good people before however this girl was slow, didn't know the menu, left all of the wine glasses on the table even though I was drinking a martini and the others beers. She didn't check on our table so I had to get up and request a manager to address the over done pork chop. (ordered medium came wayyyy past well- replacement chop was great) 

The Jambalaya- just a cheap version of something that used to be amazing. Made with no attention to detail, so much chicken and not enough seafood and andouille. This dish used to be two small chicken wings now they use huge grilled tenders and cut down on the actual meat you're interested in. Something else about the way it tasted was just off-- I feel like they are just cutting corners. 

Those are my thoughts--Sorry NOLA but you lost your touch
Stopped in for lunch and had the crawfish flatbread. Service was attentive and prompt without being intrusive. Pricing very reasonable considering the huge portions.

Maybe it's because I had high expectations based on reviews I had read, but I was a little disappointed in the food. 

We had the seafood jambalaya which wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be. It had a very... interesting flavor (for lack of a better word). I'm not an expert at jambalaya but it didn't taste like what I remember. It had a bit of a sour taste to it which I decided I didn't like because it reminded me of food that was spoiling. 

We also had the Gumbo Ya-ya, and Creole Pulled Pork Po Boy. The gumbo was pretty good. As for the Creole Pulled Pork Po Boy, the pork  was pretty bland but it tasted good when eaten with the gumbo. It was served on fresh bread. 

The restaurant itself was pretty loud. Our waitress was really friendly and nice and the bathrooms were clean which is always a  bonus. Overall, I only gave NOLA a 3 star because I really did NOT like the way the jambalaya tasted. I had higher expectations for the restaurant.
Love the atmosphere.  Had a fun jazz band Friday night came back saturday to eat.   Had Voodoo pasta with blacked catfish tryed 2 specialty drinks. Both yummy.

My co-workers and I ended up here since Meat & Potatoes was booked till 11pm. The entrance looks small but its a lot bigger inside so it's a great place for groups. I was very excited to try this place from what I heard from friends but I was underwhelmed by the food I had. Although the catfish was cooked well it wasn't as flavorful as the name of the dish. It didn't have any kick to it for something described as cajun. I was able to try the grits too and thought it was bland. The aligator bites were good though, very tender. I've never had alligator and it tasted just like calamari! I unfortunately didn't get to try the gumbo that Yelpers rave about.

They had a very enticing menu of special cocktails and I ended up ordering the Bayou royal tea. It was described as having lavender and honey but I couldn't really taste the lavender. It was pretty pricey too imo.

I have been to NOLA two times both around lunch time and both times we had amazing experiences.  We had flatbreads to start.  They are SO yummy!  I had the shrimp and grits both times we were there.  They are SO good I actually crave them!  I am not one for spicy in food but they add just the right amount of heat to them.  The Beneigts were just amazing!  We had terrific service!  We will DEFINITLEY return for the shrimp and grits!  Oh, and the atmosphere is sublime!

I went with a friend on a Friday for dinner and drinks. They had a live blues band playing at the time. We sat toward the front of the restaurant to be near, and it was super loud. Of course we didn't complain since we wanted to sit there, but others further back did. 

Unfortunately, the quality of the food and drinks were bad. We ordered fried green tomatoes, frog legs, brisket sliders (on special), and crawfish flatbread. The tomatoes came out first, well before anything else - they were very bland. So about 20-25 minutes later the other appetizers came out with an additional plate of tasteless tomatoes. They advised the additional plate was on the house for the wait. Now for the frog legs... They were prepared differently than describes on the menu. Instead of being breaded, they came out in a broth... This was also very bland. The crawfish flatbread was soggy/slimy, but the brisket sliders were okay. They were dry, but the only decent item that we had. For a Cajun/Creole restaurant, the food was disappointing. The drinks were also very disappointing. We were going to order actual entrees, but given the quality that night - we opted out of that. 

At least the service was good. The waitress brought us everything we asked for, and came to check on us often.

The last time I was at Nola the food was very good, but that was a couple years ago. Not sure what happened, but I won't be visiting Nola again any time soon...

It was very good food and I can't believe it's taken me this long to come out here and try it.  I loved the atmosphere and our waiter was attentive and helpful.  We went with a large group which sometimes means dinner can take a long time, but I didn't feel like we were a struggle for the restaurant.  
A bunch of us tried the fried alligator which was very delicious.  I'm a huge fan of duck and pretty much get it anywhere we go, and NOLA was no exception.  It was cooked well and they even made the swiss chard taste good.  I ate everything.  The sweet potatoes were legendary.  I would love to figure out how to make my own version of these.  To finish we all ordered beignets with ice cream or sorbet and they were delicious.  
We definitely left with a hefty bill, but the food was worth it.

My boyfriend and I had a very pleasant experience on a Friday night at NOLA.  I normally don't like loud dining venues, but in this case, I loved it! The live band was awesome...I was getting excited to hear what song they would play next.  The food was also really good.  I had the Brie and leek pasta because it isn't a very common dish to see served at restaurants, and although it was certainly a large enough portion, I found myself wanting more of it!  I also ordered several drinks and appetizers and was very pleased with all of them.  Our waiter was great, but I felt bad for him because he practically had to yell all night over the band to his customers.  I would definitely go back for dinner again!
Been to NOLA several times.  The food is great!  Service always excellent.  Trendy spot.  Don't forget the beignets and alligator.  We came for drinks.. Thumbs up on the hurricane. .

I had the quail and it was great. I thought the atmosphere was nice and since I did set at the bar I had a BB game to watch. 

The only thing negative that I can see with this pkace is the beer was too expensive. 

The food is a little pricey but it was good.

We had tickets to go to the Pirates game on this Sunday afternoon.  So we made brunch reservations to Nola so we could have a few drinks and some good food before we walked over to the baseball game.  
     
     We weren't sure if it was going to be busy or not so we made reservations just to be safe.  They opened at 11am and our reservations were at 1115.  We were the first customers to arrive that morning but I'm still glad that we made reservations.  Soon after this it did start to get busy.  

     We were greeted right away and taken to our seats.  Our waitress was training somebody so we have to girls waiting on us.  I felt a little rushed with our drink orders and looking at the menu.  They gave us a minute to look it over and came right back.  This is usually fine but we really needed a few more minutes.  We both ordered Beermosas!   We used Miller lite and mixed it with our orange juices.  It was a good combination for the morning and a perfect drink right before afternoon baseball.

     My wife ended up ordering the Eggs Trivette.  She said it did sort of remind her of an eggs benedict.  She liked it.  I really wasn't hungry for breakfast food right then so I ordered their Nola Burger.  That really hit the spot for me.  It's a big burger with cheese, cornmeal fried green tomatoes, and onion marmalade.  It was juicy and delicious!  My hamburger came with their Voodoo fries.  They were seasoned very well and I enjoyed the fries.  This early lunch was really good and it was the perfect combination right before the Pirate game.

     Overall we did have a good brunch.  I wasn't that big of a fan over their brunch menu but my wife did like hers.  The lunch and dinner menus are probably more for me which is why I really enjoyed my burger.

Brunch was meh - their "brunch jambalaya" is a heavy portion of cubed potatoes mixed with tomato sauce, 4 slices of andouille sausage,  2 shrimp and a very runny sunny side up egg. Photographs well but is not a good dish.  I should've known when our waiter in training (who greeted us with "how are y'all doing tonight" on Easter Sunday morning) said it was his favorite....  hubby liked his fried alligator po boy (but commented that bc it was so breaded he couldn't taste the alligator (which to me may have been a good thing?), and girls were satisfied with their french toast and vegetable cheese omelet.  The fruit that accompanied it was standard cut up melon and pineapple and grapes, like what you might get at a hotel's free breakfast buffet (aka institutionally packaged). Beignets were lukewarm and underwhelming, as was my coffee.  I chose this place at the last minute from a short list of available open brunch places for Easter... so I was grateful they were open but bottom line disappointed in the food and wouldn't recommend it.  Positives- reasonable prices, big space, and lots of tables.

I love New Orleans, so when I heard about this place I was super excited to try it out. I was hoping that they would have some et touffee (spelling?) but they don't. Sad face. Anyways, my disappointment quickly disappeared after I tried the shrimp and grits. I would recommend it to a friend and even a best friend. My girlfriend  had the pork dish and it was amazing. Get the beignets for dessert!

Started out with the Royal Street Blues Martini and delicious fried green tomatoes. 

For dinner I enjoyed the blackened salmon over crawfish etoufee. Seasoned and cooked to perfection.

The weather was unseasonably warm so I sat on the patio.

Excellent service from the entire staff.

Stopped by tonight with my friend and sister for drinks during happy hour. The drinks were large and mixed perfectly. We ordered the pierogis, stuffed mushrooms and margarita pizza. All of of them were really good! Our server was very attentive. It was a very good time. Definitely somewhere I would return to check out dinner service!

to people who had problems with their service if you go in their slow times you will see great awesome service! I got french onion soup it wasn't probably traditional but really good. Soup, felt like it took hours. Also, the shrimp were cooked perfectly on the poboy it was very flavorful every bite till the end! shrimp were huge too, and the crunchy breading stayed attached. glad I kinda wimped out on alligator it made me a really happy camper. I know I and other people sometimes substitute on the entree or if you wana call a meal; please dnt take anything off here.  today sorta felt like royalty. but, it's probably more southern than cajun. it is worth trip and money.

Amazing food!  Atmosphere is perfect!  My husband ordered French Onion soup and Jumbalia, I ordered the roasted vegetable salad and grilled chicken and dumplings.  We were not disappointed!  They brought my husband's soup and forgot my salad, when the waitress realized, she went to the kitchen (pretty cool, you can watch them cook!) and got on it!  She brought it out and apologized.  I told her it was ok, everyone makes mistakes.  About 2 minutes later the manager came over and apologized and took the salad off of my bill!  I would go back in a heartbeat!

NOLA is always on my list of go-to's for Market Square restaurants. I have had dinner and lunch here are various times and have always had an excellent meal. 

My latest foray to NOLA was for drinks before a late dinner. So let's move on... 

Atmosphere: Love the atmosphere at NOLA, it's why I continue to come back! I've been to New Orleans and it definitely takes me back. It has all the pomp and circumstance that I expect of the Big Easy. The one downfall was when I was visiting they had a jazz musician singing and while the music was fantastic, it was so loud I couldn't hear or talk to my date unless we were screaming at each other. 

Service: Our bartender was fantastic! He chatted us up and answered questions we had about the drink menu. Made and muddled my drink in front of us. The drawbacks were the one drink is actually hard to drink bc there is so much stuff muddled into it, and then when I ordered wine they were out of wine glasses for a solid 30 minutes. For a busy downtown bar / restaurant, how do you run out of wine glasses?! Needless to say, neither ruined my experiences with our night, just minor inconveniences. 

Drinks: Solid beer draft choice. Drink list was very interesting, but like I said above, it was hard to drink one of their cocktails because there was so much in it. Wine list was solid. 

All in all, I'm always going to make NOLA a stop.

Step into Nola and suddenly you're transported directly to New Orleans. The decor here is so charming and inspired entirely by the city. The color scheme is all purples and greens, and there are many historic touches such as a beautifully detailed ceiling. You almost forget that you're still in Pittsburgh!

The staff here is fantastic. My boyfriend and I enjoyed our waiter who was very personable and talkative with us. He even gave us pointers for some of his other favorite restaurants in the city that we should try out.

We started with the red beans and rice as an appetizer, which were so packed full of flavor I couldn't even believe it! You won't find a bland dish on the menu here. I had the shrimp and grits for my entree, and they were the best shrimp and grits I have ever had. The presentation was stunning (see the photo below), and I talked my boyfriend's ear off about how delicious it was for basically the entire time I was eating it. For dessert we shared this phenomenal chocolate and caramel cake that was also expertly decorated. I highly recommend the food here. It is on the more pricey side, but in my opinion is absolutely worth the price. This is a great place for a date night or special occasion. I have always wanted to travel to New Orleans and have never been able to, so I'm thrilled that I have such a delicious and authentic creole restaurant right here in Pittsburgh!

I'll try NOLA again, but I have to say my first experience was less than stellar.

We had a reservation but sat for 45 minutes at the bar waiting for them to get us a table.  I went up to them about 30 minutes in to see if they had forgotten us and got a confused look and finally a yes, we have you on the list.   They never seated us and never came around to offer alternatives or anything.  There were open tables.  Finally, we left and ate elsewhere.

Beyond the service, there was loud music--too loud to talk--blaring in the dining area.  I like music.  I like restaurants.  I don't mind when restaurants have music.  But when you cannot hear what the person you are eating with is saying to you and the bartenders cannot hear what you are ordering, the music is too loud for a restaurant.  I go to restaurants to enjoy a good meal and have a nice conversation with whomever I'm with.  I would guess most people share that belief.  If I want it that loud, I'll go to a bar, not a restaurant.  

Oh, and the beer from the taps tasted funky.  They either aren't cleaning their taps or are cleaning them improperly.  I tasted both an IPA and a wheat beer.  Both were weird.

Sorry, NOLA, but nothanks.

I hate to seem like a pretentious snob, but I wouldn't say the food is really all that authentic "Cajun" or "Creole". Been to NO many a time, and I know what authentic Cajun food tastes like. The food was okay, but I've had better.

Even so, I'd still rate this place fairly high. As I said, authenticity issues aside, the food is okay. The service was definitely over par, so if you're not hung up on the fact that it's not quite what you'd get in the French Quarter, then go there and you'll probably have a good dining experience. The decor and ambiance are definitely high on the cool meter. I'd probably go back.

Great place for lunch! We were visiting over the weekend and stumbled upon this place. We read the previous reviews and were iffy about it but tried it out because they were really the only places that had a full bar and was open during the time (got there around 10:45) they accommodated us very well and our server, Emma, was more then willing to go out of her way and explain the menu for us.

Delicious Lunch! Decided to head to NOLA for a Monday Afternoon Lunch! Nice Creole New Orleans menu options. I got the Brassiere Steak Salad and it was delicious. Even though there were a fair amount of fries, the salad was still a healthier option from their menu. Steak was cooked perfectly as ordered Medium. Waitress / bartender was very nice, got my order and my coworker's order correctly ordered! I'm sure I will be back very soon!!

NOLA is a can't-miss for all you adventurous diners. There are definitely some unique options on the menu. I was skeptical, but any restaurant that offers a vegetarian/vegan menu earns some brownie points automatically. The decor exudes an upbeat, jazzy atmosphere to complement their New Orleans vibe. I'm a sucker for unique restaurant themes, no matter how corny. 

They provide lunch specials where you can mix and match soup, salad, and sandwiches, but unfortunately, the vegetarian selections are not included in this deal. I ordered the Spinach Summer Salad to start and it was delicious. Fresh and fruity with a nice crunch from the almonds. After cleaning off the salad, it was time for the Vegan Rice Creole. Amazing!! It's essentially rice mixed with a tomato salsa topped with carrots and peas. I know it sounds a bit off, but trust me, it's phenomenal. The portion is also big enough for a second meal which is always a plus. 

Oh, by the way, the voodoo fries are a must! I'm not sure what dark magic they use to season the fries, but I couldn't stop eating them until every last one was gone. Insanely addicting!

We ate here on a Saturday night and I have to tell you it was fantastic. The alligator and pork shank to start was awesome. We shared the quail, jumbolia, scallop Mac and cheese, and shrimp and grits. Everything was awesome from the food to the service to the plating. 
 Next time I am in Pittsburgh I will be coming back

I've not been to NOLA since they first opened and I loved it then. But what was I thinking waiting so long to get back?? Seriously I know we're becoming a foodie city and have so many choices but this restaurant is a staple; New Orleans style. The decor is a chic take on the French Quarter with a superior wait staff and quality management style. The food is simply fantastic. Fried green tomatoes sprinkled with shredded white cheddar and drizzled in a hearty ranch mayo. The grilled chicken and dumplings---scrumptious! Ricotta dumplings with peas, wild mushrooms and carrots in a flavorful sauce. Chicken is grilled with fragrant spices that bring Bourbon Street to mind. If you're like me and not been in forever or have never been, you need to get there to enjoy what they have to offer.
Fantastic food! Amazing well stocked bar. Try to go during a jazz night if you can for the full experience!  Try the pork tenderloin! I don't know what's in that purée but it is absolutely delicious!

I've passed by this restaurant so many times that I had to give it a try! 

NOLA was pretty good! I had the jambalaya and it wasn't as flavorful as I thought it would be. It was spicy but that's the only flavor I could taste. 

The service was a little flakey at times and we had to wait a while for our food. They were very accommodating and even gave us a bread bowl because we were so hungry. 

If you love New Orleans cuisine with a Pittsburgh Twist, give NOLA a try!

We started off with the crab bisque. I ordered the jumbalaya and my wife went with the  shrimp & grits. Both dishes were excellent. We finished off the meal with creme brûlée. Excellent food, excellent drinks, excellent service. Top drawer experience.

Yay for new restaurants!  Yay for fun new restuarants!  And a final yay for a good exerpeince at a fun, new restaurant!

I always love walking into a restaurant which looks super duper tiny from the front and then surprises you by being large on the inside.  The colorful pictures and art make it a bright and fun atmosphere.  Just like you'd expect from a 24/7 Mardi Gras party, minus maybe the flashing!

First time's a charm with this place!  Service was fantastic!  The server came up and explained everything to us in terms of drinks, apps and main courses.  Since it was for lunch I went on the light side with the Crawfish and Sherry soup and the Nola salad.  

The soup was delicious with just the right amount of kick for me.  Sometimes if things are too spicey for me I become a watery mess, and not in the emotional way!  I think the soup was just creamy amazingness!  

The salad was also very fresh with some great toppings such as candied pecans and my personal fav, little mini potato chips.  Of course the later mentioned doesn't end up making a salad healthy, but whatever, it was tasty!  For a final send off we ordered the fried artichoke's as our "dessert."  They were incredible!  Nice, crispy and huge with a spicy mayo type sauce.  I'm all about the sauces, so it was just the right touch.

I really can't wait to try out this place for dinner and/or a happy hour!  I will definitely be back.  I hope they have some idea's for events, because I think the place will be a great host for special parties.  Great addition to Market Square!!

Really not good.  Shrimp and grits is really salty small overcooked shrimp soup with a square of dry tasteless grits.  Service was good as well as atmosphere.  Others in the party liked their food and some didn't.  Very inconsistent.

First, this should be 3 or 4 dollar signs.

Great food, but not for the money.  There should be more seafood in the seafood dishes.  We went with a group of seven.  The waiter kept giving us things that we didn't order - 2 dishes and a drink.  He left the things at the table and said I won't charge you for this, at which point we shared them or asked to have them packed up.  At the end, all of these mistakes showed up on the bill, inflating it by around $30.  He refunded one of the three items.  If they want to charge prices like they do, the service and customer satisfaction should be better.  

There were also a lot of other little mistakes.

A better server could have made this 4 stars.  Also, if I didn't dissuade you from going, try the Bagnettes (awesome powdered doughnuts.)  A very nice desert to share with 2 or 4.

Visited here with the family for a light dinner and live jazz. Had a great time. Theirs flat breads are delicious, nice fresh salads, good choice of drinks. But the main highlight is the atmosphere. Loved the jazz band performance (Benny Benack), had lots of fun.
Great location, music and fun decor/ambiance. The food was pretty good - our favorite was the side dish of jambalaya.

Had a delicious, quick lunch here. I ordered the summer spinach salad. It didn't look like it had any dressing on it and I was nervous I would feel like a koala bear eating it but it was perfectly dressed with a peach tea type vinaigrette . Everything in it was perfectly seasoned from the spicy almonds, goat cheese, and pickled tomatoes.

I enjoyed my meal here, but the atmosphere was quite loud, and I think geared a little bit more towards the younger, 'trendy' crowd.  There was a live band playing, and they were decent, but very loud to the point where it was pretty difficult to hear my date.  I got the salmon etoufee as my entree - I asked them to cook it medium rare, because so often I find that my dishes are slightly over cooked.  When it came out, it was definitely very rare - basically just quickly seared on both sides.  Now, I love raw salmon/sushi - so this actually didn't bother me as much as the average person, but both the seasoning and the sauce that it was in was very salty - and I love salty foods.  Though enjoyable, I don't think that this would be a destination for me, unless I happened to be in the downtable/Market Square area.

Service 4/5
Decor 4/5
Food 2/5

Nothing we ate had much creativity. The frog legs were okay, the salad, and Jambalaya were mediocre.

Interesting Cajun place midst a number of other restaurants in market square.  Interior was honestly pretty gaudy, I understand embracing the New Orleans feel but the sheer quantity of decorations was distracting.  Service was excellent, we were seated and served quickly.

Po' boy sandwiches were good, but dry.  Excellent fries and slaw with the meals.  Soups were among the better choices at our table, especially the oyster stew.  I was a little underwhelmed by spice usage in all of our dishes, I expected more of a punch.  Prices were reasonable considering the location, and the drink selection seemed fair enough.

Pretty tasty food, worth a try if you're hankering for some Cajun, but be cognisant of other options in the immediate area.

I went for the first time for an early dinner around 4:30 PM on Sunday prior to going to see a show at Heinz Hall.  We opted to sit inside instead of outside to avoid the cigarette smoke coming from people smoking outside the restaurant but nearby to the outdoor seating.  My cousin has been here many times and loves it and we've traveled to New Orleans together around 20 times over the last 15 years so I was excited that she recommended it so highly.  The restaurant has a fairly extensive cocktail, beer, and wine list and my cousin ordered a beer but I ordered a glass of wine and felt that the pour was very small for the price.  For our appetizers and main courses, she ordered the gumbo and the BBQ shrimp (from the appetizer menu) and I ordered the Cajun chowder and was torn between the shrimp and grits and the scallops and shrimp mac daddy, but upon our servers recommendation and because I'm a sucker for shrimp and grits, I went with the shrimp and grits (which at least another reviewer mentioned that it is really overpriced at $27 - believe me, the quality of the grits and the amount of shrimp that you get for the $27 is far from worth the money).  My cousin tried my chowder and I tasted her gumbo and I found the flavors of both the be tasty though I felt that the gumbo was a little under-seasoned while the chowder was flavorful but overly salty.  Our main courses arrived and again we shared a taste of each other's dishes.  The BBQ shrimp was very flavorful but again overly salty and the shrimp and grits were a mixed bag in my opinion.  The sauce on top of the grits with the shrimp was the same as the sauce on the BBQ shrimp plus it had the addition of very salty bacon yet the grits on their own were rather bland and even mixing them together to mingle the flavors did not cut down on the excessive saltiness in the dish.  I am someone who actually prefers my food on the saltier side so the mere fact that I am actually complaining about how salty everything was means that it was quite over salted.  I could feel my ankles swelling as the meal came to a close.  We also shared the beignets for dessert.  The trio of sorbet that came with the beignets was delicious and refreshing and but the beignets were a little flat and dense compared to the beignets that I've had in New Orleans but tasty.  Overall I would go back but I would probably keep to the lower priced items because I feel that much of their menu is overpriced for what you get.

Larkin Larkin Larkin... I cannot say enough about this server. She was not only knowledgable about EVERYTHING on the menu, but also incredibly sweet and efficient. Food was amazing but I will come back for the service.

NOLA on the square has nicely decorated the old interior of 1902 cafe.  I loved the open kitchen, and the beautiful artwork on the walls.  They serve up very tasty and almost authentic New Orleans Cuisine.  

I ordered the shrimp po'boy and it came with 5 huge fried shrimp served up on a soft Italian bread.   The breading was quite tasty but you could tell that the shrimp was not seasoned properly and was slightly overcooked.  The slaw that came on it was sweet too even though the description was Cajun Slaw, Spicy Papaya Ravigote.  I expected it to me spicy!  To my dismay they only had one type of hot sauce - Tabasco.  Come on my friend if you want to serve New Orleans cuisine you better serve food that is spicy and have a selection of hot sauces to choose from. My friend ordered a Croque Monsieur, which she really enjoyed because of the hand carved ham.  For dessert we shared a banana bread pudding with caramel ice cream.  The ice cream had a ridiculous amount of caramel in it, and was very overpowering.  The bread pudding was good on it's own.   

A few additional grips: it's slightly expensive for lunch (our bill was about $40 total with tip+tax for two people), and waitstaff is overattentive (i had about 4 people come towards me as I walked through the door to be seated, proceeded by our waitress who came back every minute, literally to ask if we were ready to order).....  Alas, I'd still come back for the food.

Tip: portions are huge so bring your appetite, or a partner to share!

This was our first time at Nola. We ordered the alligator appetizer, which was plenty for two to share and had a nice tasty sauce that came with it. I wasn't crazy about th appetizer but it wasn't too bad. I also got the chicken and dumplings for my meal for the first time and it was delicious. It was also very filling so I would definitely get this meal again! We were seated right away on a Saturday night and had no wait.

Another place that I enjoy but is presently closed but due to reopen soon. 
My fiance & I love love LOVE their Louisiana Cajun style food. ...SOO OOOO good.  Our favorite is the alligator tail meat appetizer that's fried & seasoned to absolute perfection.
They also have an excellent fully stocked bar & they have a nice cocktail list too.
Looking forward to when they open again, the live music is also awesome & gives the place a great atmosphere to kick back & enjoy.

The service was wonderful, not too busy on a Wednesday afternoon around 2pm was seated right away. Out door seating available which was very nice. I had the steak salad and it was cooked to perfection and tasty. Pricing was reasonable 13.00 for a salad isn't bad with the lovely ambience. Would recommend with spot to anyone looking to have lunch with a friend or by yourself:)

Friend is the manager so down here for lunch. I'd been hearing about this and was treated pretty well since I was with the manager, but the server was not very good. My friend had to get up and get our own food, drinks, etc... The gumbo was just ok, the beer was great, and the desert was tasty.

Came here for a beer and quick snack.

French onion soup was flavorful...salty, but very tasty! Will come back for it if I'm craving soup in this chilly weather.

Fried green tomatoes were excellent. First time having beer battered fried green tomatoes...usually see them crusted with bread crumbs or panko. Sauce and cheese topping were on point.

Nothing on the dinner menu caught my eye, but I would come back for sure!
